cheap and quite okay japanese at the 100am mall in tanjong pagar. the first time I came here, we thought the food was impressive: large-ish portions, pleasantly-surprisingly-small prices and a huge menu composed of a clever permutation of a not-so-huge selection of dishes. this decent experience prompted an enthusiastic return, but it proved less sparkling: the food was too salty, the cooking of a lower standard - and the pater didn't much like it.which brings me, really, to a less-than-effervescent recommendation than I'd initially thought: this place will do you well good for mid-week/office lunches - cheap japanese food with large portions and a big menu for everyone - but if you're thinking of a sit-down meal where you have nothing else on your mind but the food, it's not ideal (or close to, in fact).the place has an open concept - it's more (nydc-style) cafe-like than anything else, and though I'm under the impression that the mall is pretty new, the chairs and tables show sign of wear. it's a little dingy, actually - very food-court like - so while it'll do for a harried lunch, it's not really the sort of place you'd linger.the menu is very cleverly composed of a small set of dishes that are combined rather ingeniously into a bible of a menu - a quarter of the menu populated with a la carte meats and dishes, and the remaining 75% a composition of set meals based on the very same. quality-wise, it's a mixed bag: there are some dishes that are really quite enjoyable, though a lot of it is bog standard middling japanese-chain.the best way to describe the food here, really, is that it does what it says on the tin. nothing more, nothing less - precisely what you'd expect from a middle-to-low ranged japanese chain (probably hovering about the sakae sushi level). the low prices make for a compelling argument at lunch - but at dinner time, when I'm hoping for a meal to wash the work week away, this place will not do at all.

Good place for lunch - yummy, fast and reasonably priced Japanese food. There are iPads at every table so you can order quickly instead of the usual pain of trying to wave down busy staff. My water and dessert showed up 3 min after I punched in my order, and my main course 7 min after ! Super efficient ! Mixed Toji set at $13.90 is a good choice for indecisive people like me who want everything :) Katsu, 1 prawn tempura, some stir fried beef and egg all over. Comes with small appetizer, yummy Japanese rice and soup. The Tonkatsu and fried chicken are YUM !

I visited this place last night after a yoga session nearby, and I really have to say that I was surprised that the food was so good! I was half expecting the standard of an ichiban boshi, but I can really vouch at least, for the katsu (fried) set meals. I had the seasonal fried oyster set meal, and for 16.90 you get rice and 4 huge oysters with two different sauces, cold tofu, a salad with yummy sesame dressing and miso soup. Besides the fact that it was a lot of food, the taste was excellent. The greens were fresh and the salad dressing was delicious. The rice (I'm particular about my rice) was fluffy and aromatic, and the oysters were big, fresh and fried just the right way. Crispy, but doesn't taste too oily, and with the tartare sauce, I was in heaven. The tofu and soup was alright, but in all, it was great. My friend's chicken katsu was as good, with the chicken still moist and the outside crispy and good. I am particular about fried oysters because I've been spoilt by the ones at saboten, but I have to say that this place is on par, and the menu is about 5x as extensive as saboten. Grilled, broiled fish and meat dishes, and they even have a cool online ordering system. Will definitely go back!

I dig the coffee at Five Oars Coffee Roasters. Â It's quite aromatic and bold. Â The flavors remind me alot of Blue Bottle in SF. Â Our latte and cappuccino were perfect. Â I did not have any food, but my partner's avocado toast looked rather amazing.The shop is gorgeous with all the decorative plants. Â  The staff were quite friendly. Â I would definitely return for brunch next time.

Fish and chips ($22 + $2 for sweet potato fries) - 3.75 starsSolid.Ambience - 3.5 starsNice big space but too noisy and the tables are close together so you can hear your neighbour's conversation perhaps a little too clearly...

I travel all over the world for business and go out of my way to find small local restaurants that serve amazing food. I had one of the most amazing breakfast at Five Oars during my recent trip to Singapore. The food is absolutely incredible. It's rare to find such a flawless gem. If I could have given them more than five stars I would have.

Amazing breakfast, very friendly staff, great coffee and tea (lychee rose iced tea is heaven) nice environment overall, ideal for tourists looking for a breakfast for champions, totally recommend it!!

Wow this place is whats up. Huge portions and everything absolutely delicious, coffee is spot on as well. I had the five oars benny and it was amazing. They have a big menu with many choices, everything is fresh. If you want to have a breakfast of champions this is the place, would def be back.

Went for lunch with about 8 friends on - Tuesday. Expectedly not crowded but it has big space and it filled up quickly during peak lunch time. Â The ambience is simple and open. The overall food and presentation was good for the price. The service was prompt and nice. Overall 4/5. No real complaints. We averaged about 25$ per person which included main items , coffee and desert.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Came by for dinner the other night and it was a tasty Michelin 1 star experience. Made a reservation 6+ weeks in advance and the restaurant posted a $150 SGD "deposit" that will supposedly be "manually refunded" post dining.Labyrinth is located inside the Esplanade mall in the CBD and is connected to the Esplanade MRT via underground walkways with the CityLink mall.Service throughout the meal was attentive, although there were slight wrinkles in the service with some of the staff members being a touch too intrusive. I also had trouble understanding Singaporean English from some of the staff members... The dinner was a ~2.5 hour "show" with numerous courses with a different "setting" along with narrative by the staff during each course.The memories from the Chomp Chomp hawker center were excellent. All of the dishes were a premium version of what can be found locally. For example, the pratas featured super fragrant black truffles and the orh luak featured caviar. Flavors and textures were excellent.Moving on to the plates, this was also extremely well executed with high attention to detail. The crispy roast chicken rice was a stuffed chicken wing with black truffle. The kwai teow featured fish maw instead of noodles.The main course being a tribute to a local steakhouse was also extremely well executed. Opted for the "regular" 48 hour Angus shortrib and it was heavenly. Their shortrib had high levels of marbling and cooked to a perfect medium rare. The golden pompret was perfectly grilled and complemented this nicely with the white asparagus.The dessert courses were also an adventure. The shaved ice was a little too much for me although the cereal prawn and the kaya toast were definitely highlights to the meal!Meal ended off with a couple chocolate truffles to enjoy!~$302/ person after tax and service. They take Visa.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: How does this place only have one Michelin Star??This was my favorite Michelin Star experience in Singapore (table65 and White Grass being the other two). First off, I have never been so touched by the personality and story of the food served here. This is Chef LG Han's life and it shines through each dish.I won't talk about all the dishes, but the highlights:"Memories of Chomp Chomp Hawker Centre" was a tribute to hawker centre foods. They may have looked simple but each was truly an elevated dish and of the highest quality ingredients.The chili crab ice cream, while a little too spicy for me, was a culinary marvel! To capture the essence of Singapore's chili crab in an ice cream dish--fantastic! I have never had anything like that before.The most heart-touching dish was definitely the "Tribute to Cairnhill Steakhouse", a steakhouse that the Chef's grandfather owned. The meat was nothing special but the presentation was very honoring to his family.Last but not least was the Kaya toast with caviar. This was the BEST kaya toast I had in Singapore and I would come back for this sweet treat alone!Can't wait to see what Chef Han will do next as he grows. Will be back next time I'm in Singapore!

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Labyrinth menu focuses on highlighting Singaporean dishes utilizing locally sourced ingredients. The restaurant is located in the second floor of a mall and is a bit hard to find because there really is no signs anywhere with the location. Although it took a while to find I was delighted by the meal that I had. Â Service here is top notch and the staff is extremely knowledgeable about the menu.Food: 4.5 starsService: 4.5 starsEnvironment: 4 starsOverall: 4.25 starsStand outs: clay pot chicken rice, crystal de chine caviar, nippon koi farm silver perch I came here for lunch and was presented with either a five course or seven course menu. I choose the five course which is also the same menu as the pre theater menu. The meal starts off with a trio of snacks: tea egg, oyster takoyaki, and laksa mussel. All were quite nice and the mussel was my favorite of the three. The laksa broth paired with the mussel was really delicious. Following the snacks were four tapa sized main courses: barramundi crudo, tempura wild shrimp, silver perch, and clay pot chicken rice. Â All were quite tasty and showed creativity. The ones I really enjoyed were the clay pot rice and the silver perch. The silver perch was cooked in banana leaf and paired with a light Â kaffir leaf broth. The broth was really fantastic and I drank every drop of that soup. The clay pot chicken rice is right up my alley as it is very similar to the clay pot rice I grew up eating. This version takes it up to another level. The rice had a nice mixture of crispy bits with normal rice and the chicken was extremely tender and moist. The meal ends with two desserts. One was a clam leaf snow and the other was a play on kaya toast. The story behind the clam leaf made me enjoy the snow dish more than I normally would. Sorbet type desserts really aren't my favorite. The kaya toast however was really fantastic. At first glance the use of caviar in a dessert was odd. However, the salty caviar paired with sweetness of the ice cream and the crunch of the bread was a pairing that really worked. This will be the dish I will likely remember the most from my meal here.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: So I made sure that I have contained and condensed my rage before I started drafting this review so I could stay as neutral as I possibly can. Price: $140 fixed per person Which is steep for Singapore but I was ok with it as it has one Michelin star. Location: inside of a mediocre mall. HmmDecor: minimalistic. Some old school pillow at entrance with Chinese writing on it. Waiter attire: all black, a bit sluggish as the shirt was a bit wrinkled. (for those knows me, I have a thing with wrinkled shirt... Big nono)Food: overall was on the sweet side. I guess that's Singaporean food? Well, that could be subjective so I am not going to comment too much.Menu: they actually made a mistake on menu given out. There were two versions of menu which they acknowledged after we found out. No apologies or anything... and two different menus remains with the us on the table...Okay...At beginning, they asked if we have any allergies or any preferences on food. We said we don't eat lamb. After reading into menu, we also mentioned some of us don't eat Durian. Then comes the part annoys us. " You must try it(Durian). It's like going to Europe and you gotta try goat cheese." We told them that we have tried Durian before and some of us cannot stand the taste or smell of it so we request that they substitute it with something else or just don't serve it. THE WAITER REFUSED and insist that we must try it. Are you kidding me?When Durian dessert came, I mean I enjoy Durian myself and I can tell ya, it was a FULL ON Durian dessert from smell to taste. Moreover, the manager even came afterwards and was disappointed that not all of us ate the Durian. Talk about pushy and annoyance!!!We were quite annoyed that throughout the 15 course of meal as they wouldn't change our utensils! We would put our fork and knife inside the plate when we were done with each course then they will take utensils out and put on the white linen cloth so everyone gets dirty linen cloth. Seriously? Wow. After several course, you get how dirty it gets... Ugh I'm also use to having everyones course arrive all together . Nope, they serve one at a time ... After all 6 served then we gotta wait for them to explain the dish.. OK, you lose momentum and just not professional. When I'm traveling, I don't mind spend extra on food to have new experience but darn it, it sure wasnt a pleasant one especially I spent extra already. In this capital of food heaven, I don't see why anyone would want to spend their money here.The one absolute highlight of the dish was the quail leg: wow, that was nicely done in perfection. That's why I'm giving them 2 stars instead of 1Ugh, I am still annoyed by the restaurant.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: This is Michelin one star restaurant. If you want to experience Singapore flavor and sophisticated meals at the same time. I would recommend this restaurant!I like the chef who respects the local material, texture, quality, natural ingredients, beautiful presentation, and nice service! I know they do have those. I have a great experience here!! I will definitely come back!!! Can't wait!!

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: At Labyrinth, food takes centre stage. Indeed, the restaurant's dim lighting, minimalist decor and strategically placed spotlights were designed for diners to focus on its star dishes.Labyrinth's $178 tasting menu may seem steep considering the petite portions but with 16 courses, you do fill up nicely at the end of the meal. Although the dishes pay homage to Singapore's culinary heritage, expect creative tweaking here and there, this is a Michelin starred restaurant after all. Through picture cards placed on the table, Chef Han recounted interesting anecdotes, shared his culinary journey and personal memories. These wonderful notes allowed diners to follow each course with greater cognizance and to fully appreciate the inspirations behind the creative process. In addition, Labyrinth's efforts to work with local farms and suppliers is commendable, its tasting menu is a great platform to showcase quality local produce, artisanal goods including rare and exotic ingredients. I was very impressed with the creativity and ingenuity displayed throughout the meal. For example, we started off with "Nasi Lemak" Cheong Fun, a clever fusion of two iconic local dishes. Then there was a savoury LaLa Clam Tart with XO sambal and herbs, so pretty it could pass off as dessert. Labyrinth's Soy Bean Curd was notable for its unorthodox incorporation of yogurt (from goat's milk), sago pearls, caramelized sugar and bird's nest. These inclusions did not mar the dish. On the contrary, it enhanced the delicate flavour of the freshly made bean curd. On one or two occasions however, I did feel certain ingredients did not quite work together but on the whole there was brilliance in execution and presentation.Other exceptional dishes include :Labyrinth's Rojak, a charming assortment of flowers, herbs, sprouts, fruit and ground peanuts, was refreshing and extremely delish. Fried potato leaves and jackfruit sorbet gave this dish an unique appeal. "Ang Moh" Chicken Rice was presented unusually as a dumpling over a pool of white roux sauce. Within the bundle were tender morsels of braised chicken with chilli sauce, bringing forth the chicken rice flavours we know so well. This was another remarkable transformation of a local favourite. Local Wild Caught Crab was incredibly fresh and succulent. Served chilled, they paired perfectly with lightly fried egg white strips, a touch of Shaoxing wine and Labyrinth's signature chilli ice cream. An unconventional take on Singapore's beloved chilli crab dish.Uncle William's Quail was super tasty. The grilled quail legs and breast were well marinated with an in-house satay sauce with prominent accents of lemongrass. The accompanying satay gravy with ground peanuts was delicious, as were the innovative addition of soft chewy muah chee (sticky rice) cubes. Cristal de Chine Caviar had multiple layers of flavours and textures which came together in a phenomenal way. A scrumptious round of kaya ice cream with hints of gula jawa was sandwiched between 2 pieces of white toast. The latter having been caramelised, offering up a glazed sugary crust. This ice cream sandwich, which rested on a light bed of cereal powder, was garnished with a drizzle of egg yolk cured in light soy sauce. Last but not least there was the spoonful of caviar beautifully positioned atop the ice cream sandwich. What were normally breakfast items in Singapore metamorphosed into the most unexpectedly delightful dessert offering. Without a doubt, it was the fitting end to a rather surreal but positively unforgettable meal.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: The restaurant was located at the space formerly occupied by Space by TungLok. The place was decorated in all blacks. Besides offering lunch set and dinner sets, the restaurant also offered pre-theatre dinner set ($48++) on thursday to saturday at 6pm.TINGKATradish cake, rojak, nasi lemakThe radish cake was in a cylinder cone with a stick in the centre. Tasted not bad although felt it was a tab plain and wished one could taste shredded radish and dried shrimp in it. The crispy square puff was packed with rojak sauce in it. Interesting pack of flavours. The coconut flavoured chwee kueh was topped with sambal, and reminded one of nasi lemak.HIROSHIMA OYSTERlaksaThe noodle was created with coconut milk and a fat juicy hiroshima oyster was used to replace cockles which was usually found in laksa. The floss was spicy with flavours of laksa.DUCKbraised duck dumplingThe dumplings were served in a bamboo basket with soup in a glass bowl. The dumplings were covered in a transparent skin made of sweet potato. Somehow felt that the filling was over flavoured and covered the duck's flavour.TIGER PRAWN ($10 SUPPLEMENT) pen cai risottoThe fa cai had a light and crispy texture. The risotto was well flavoured with oyster sauce, shiitake mushrooms , beancurd skin, and dried shrimps .XIAO LONG BAO chendolA greenish xiao long bao served in a bamboo basket with gula melaka syrup in a small jar. The green skin was made to represent the green jelly strips usually found in chendol. The xiao long bao was packed with jelly cubes and red bean. Interesting pack of flavours when ate it in one mouthful.CIGARreese's peanut butter chocolateThe cigar was a chocolate bar with chocolate creme in it, dusted with cocoa powder, with the bottom part dusted with liquid nitrogen to make look like burn part. It was served in a glass ashtray with peanut crumbles as the burnt ashes. It was accompanied with a glass of earl grey tea with a ball of ice to look like a glass of Cognac. The rich chocolate stick was balanced by the light floral tea.PETIT FOURIt was Dehydrated Pandan with Kaya Butter macaron. It was light and not too sweet.I washed down the meal with a glass of Lychee Martinis ($12++)Vodka, Lychee Liqueur, Lychee Extract which came with 2 pieces of canned lychee and tasted quite sweet.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Labyrinth provides what you would expect of a single Michelin star restaurant. A pleasant mix of dishes - some will blow you away (the starter snacks, chilli crab ice cream and short rib were phenomenal) with their flavour and imagination. Others are just delicious (the uni, dumpling and snow.) Coming out at $230sgd for the uni, two cocktails and a third of a bottle of wine, which seemed fairly reasonable. I am glad I went - but also not desperate to return.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Day 51Dear stomach,It's been nearly 0.13972603 calendar years since I entered the Labyrinth and I am still utterly lost in the maze of top-notch ingredients and visionary dishes that overwhelmed me.Don't even get me started on the flash cards that accompany each culinary masterpiece; the vivid descriptions of the chef's childhood memories of each individual dish brought tears to my fragile eyes, only making my desire to consume the food ever so powerful.I NEVER KNEW HOW MUCH I LOVE FLASH CARDS.F L A S H C A R D SHELL YEAH !!!Pls disregard; I think I may have gotten a little out of control for a second there.Until we meet again stomach... godspeed.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: 2017 Michelin Stars: 1Staff and service was fine, food was above average. I'd give them 3.5 stars if I could, but will err on the side of generosity in this case. The place is hard to find; once you're in the area the center doesn't seem to list it in obvious places so good luck. From memory, it's on the second floor, near some escalators that are by an entrance that is away from the center 'stage' (?).

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: 6 COURSES DISCOVERY MENU AMUSE BOUCHEWe started with the Street Snacks of Radish Cake, Dehydrated Pandan with Kaya Butter, Rojak and very smooth Nasi Lemak that was served in the Rantang or metal food carrier.I really like the smooth Nasi Lemak that was served like Chwee Kueh with sambal and anchovies as toppings. The savoury radish cake had a crispy edge and was very fragrant, it looked just like a toasty marshmallow. The next Amuse Bouche that we had was the most beautiful keropok / prawn crackers that was injected with squid ink. This keropok was topped with mayo chili and beautiful orange fish roe and edible flower petal. BAK CHOR MEEBak Chor Mee is a popular local dishes and I usually love the distinct flavour of the chili and sourness that comes from vinegar. The Neo-Sin's version was noodle created from the squid skin served together with anchovies in the shape of minced meat and Hokkaido Scallop that looks like a fish cake. It was a miniature version of Bak Chor Mee that you could find in the local street market. You need to mix everything together to get the best flavour. This cute looking Bak Chor Mee was served on a small bowl with rooster on it, a popular bowl that brought out nostalgic feelings of eating street food during my childhood period.HAINANESE CURRY RICEThe miniature forest with bird ness and quail egg looked very magical when the staff served it in front of me. The green moss looked very delicate and who could guess that it was made from coriander. The white clay that covered the potato was imported from Spain, the 'black rock' minced chicken was very delicious and everything was put on the bed of quinoa curry. Again, it's very important to mix in all the elements to gain the true flavour. This was simply my favourite dish of the night, in terms of look as well as the strong spicy flavour that it gave. SINGAPORE CHILI CRABThis was the dish that took my breath away when I saw it on Instagram, so I was very excited about it. The chili ice cream was delicious, even when eaten by itself! It was moreover really delicious when mixed together with the soft shell crab. Presentation of each dish really mattered and it showed from the choice of plates that the restaurant used. This dish was presented on a light blue plate that resembled the sea, covered with mantou sand, some caviar, seaweed and foamy crab bisque.SATAY BEEFHubby was really concerned about the size of the beef when he saw the '80g' next to the menu but he was surprised that the beef was quite big. The Wagyu Ribeye was cooked medium rare, served with gnocchi (onion), satay espuma and rice cakes. The rice cakes in this case was peanut mocha which was skilfully wrapped in banana leaves. The beef was perfectly cooked and with the exact amount of layered fat to make it so enjoyable.XO FISHThe fish of the day was red garoupa with a hidden lobster claw served in the Teochew broth. This dish really reminded me of seafood gumbo although not as thick and heavy. The broth was quite light, filled with seafood flavour and mushroom. I found it best when I mixed the broth with the cooked tomato that was provided so it gave the tangy fresh flavour onto the mix.NEW ITEM: MINI APPLE TOFFEEChef Han came out from his kitchen and said hi to us. Not only that, he also brought out a surprising new item that will only be released in early April. It deceivingly looked like a mini apple toffee.PINAPPLE SORBETOur palate cleanser was a refreshing house-made pinapple sorbet and I joked to the staff that one spoon wasn't enough to clean our palate (hahaha). CHENDOL Xiao Long Bao (XLB)I want more of the Chendol XLB, it was a good start to dessert and the staff was so nice that she helped me take a pour shot by pouring the gula melaka slowly on top of the XLB. For a small item, it was quite rich since it has all the elements of chendol such as red bean, shaved ice and jellies.REESE'S CHOCOLATEThe staff playfully asked whether we smoke or drink before he carried out two ashtray filled with a cigar on each. On the other hand, he gave us a glass of Cognac. It was a peanut butter covered with dark chocolate and the Cognac was the refreshing Earl Grey tea.Now the question on people's mind will usually be 'is it worth the money that I paid for'. For me, it was really worth it especially when you consider the creativity, mixture of ingredients, presentation and passion that went into each dish.I had a very enjoyable night at Restaurant Labyrinth and so excited that they will add some new menu items soon. I went to the kitchen to thank Chef Han for his delicious food and to tell him that he needs to do a pop up dining in Perth... or I should just visit Singapore again.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Let me start by saying the food we had was great - very innovative take on Singapore Street Food. There was only one "Amuse Bouche" item (a puff filled with fermented shrimp) which I wasn't a big fan of. The rest was great - especially enjoyed a crab dish which included crab ice spicy cream. There is a Prix Fixe Menu so no choices other than they will upsell you on Wagyu Beef instead of the regular beef and a better shrimp for one of the seafood dishes... I found the upsale thing a bit awkward as they actually come to your table with a slab of Wagyu and some big shrimp and try to convince you to pay the extra amount to improve your dinner... strange approach for a Michelin Starred Fixed Price Menu.The issue I had with the restaurant was mainly the service. We waited a bit before finally asking if we could order a cocktail - our waiter seemed confused about our order (a gin martini and an old fashioned...not very difficult). It was our last night in Singapore and we were looking to get the whole experience starting with drinks...getting some wine with dinner etc. Before our drinks came we were served the Amuse Bouche course...then quickly after that our first course came out....I then asked the waiter if our drinks would be coming out soon...since usually we would have preferred them BEFORE dinner...again the waiter looked confused then asked us again what drinks we had ordered, a little later he returned and said 5 more minutes. By the time we received our drinks the third course was arriving and of course we never got a chance to order wine...Our waiter was friendly but the elaborate explanations of the food was lost on his poor pronunciations. We didn't understand anything he was saying....which was unfortunate as the dishes were remarkably intricate. Â After dinner we were not offered coffee or tea...I guess for the money I would never return or recommend to anyone but it's a shame because the food was really interesting.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Very friendly staff and very informative about the dish that we were going to eat. It's a great fine dining restaurant to have an intimate date.The food that Chef Han prepared was very creative, well presented and delicious. As for the price, it can be a bit pricey but all the staff here will look after you.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: A good overall experience. I love how a lot of the dishes remind me of traditional Chinese home dishes put together unconventional ways.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: In full transparency, I have not been to this location, but I have had the pleasure of dining from a menu prepared by Chef Han at an offsite location. I was impressed by the simplicity of the dishes and the amazing flavors that were achieved by combining different ingredients together. I never imaged that a sweet oyster sauce could go so well with fillet steak. My mind was blown!Chef Han's attention to detail and knowledge of the ingredients he uses in his dishes is unmatched. The combination of flavors and tastes create a unique experience that is authentically Singaporean, rather than a so-called fusion of other cuisines. I'm am excited to follow Chef Han as he takes on his next challenge of sourcing his ingredients locally and re-creating an authentic Singaporean fine dining experience, like no other Singaporean chef has done in the past.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Not worth the money. The concept is not original and their bag of tricks does not make up for the lack of flavor and miniature portions.

address: 8 Raffles Ave #02-23, Esplanade Mall Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: Gastro place, the tasting menu was excellent. Â Service was superb as they adjusted for the no pork, no beef requirement for me. Â It's a different take to the excellent Singaporean street food. Presentation was excellent and some of the plates were very innovative and good. Worth an experience.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: A lot of business meetings happen here during lunch time. We got here at 11:30 to beat the crowd. This place fills up by 12:00p. Great for people watching and having conversation as there is adequate space between the tables and the surrounding area isn't too loud. We ordered the brussel sprouts and the Bufalo Margherita pizza to share between two people and it was enough food for us. The brussel sprouts were surprisingly good! A little sweet, sour, and salty all at once. A little twist on the typical bacon-brussel sprout combo you usually get at high end steak restaurants. The brussel sprouts here don't taste as bitter or have as much of brussel sprout taste as what you would get in California. The plate was a bit oily, but expected. I really liked the pizza crust. I'm a huge fan of bread and get pretty picky with crust. The crust was nice and crispy on the outside, yet soft on the inside. A little thin in the center, but I still really enjoyed the pizza. The tomato sauce wasn't sweet, which I liked. The cheese was nicely melted. I mostly enjoyed eating the crust and I usually avoid crust on pizza. Total bill was almost $45, which isn't too bad for the quality and location. Would definitely come back to try out some of the other pizzas!

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: Extra Virgin Pizza used to have a buzz to it. Pizza! What more could you ask for? The perfect bite should consist of the right amount of baked dough with just the right portions of sauce and cheese. Finally topped with extras to give it that extra umami, that extra umph! Sadly, these pizzas lack character. The crust was tough, almost comparable to leather. The base of the pizza was so thin it could barely hold itself together, the pizza literally fell apart. I know restaurants are suffering through Covid, but I hope Extra Virgin aren't too desperate to have to skimp on flour? All in all, the two pizzas I tried were an utter disappointment.However, this review isn't completely fair because I did get it delivered to my room while serving my SHN. Unfortunately I don't think I would ever recommend getting a pie from this spot unless dining in opens up again

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: Decent pizza, but no 'wow' factor for me. Having lived in Asia for a few years, I know that pizza is not one of its strengths which is what might give this place a above average rating.I ordered the spicy pepperoni. I couldn't taste any spice (asked for extra chili flakes) just extra saltiness. The pizza arrived looking promising, but the crust was pretty chewy and after a few slices both of us noted how much work is was to chew it down.We also started with a chicken casaer salad. Lettuce, a few croutons, shaved cheese and dressing. The chicken was something pulled out of the refrigerator and dropped on top. Disappointing. Best part about the salad were the croutons.We were lucky it was an usually cool evening for Singapore since there was no indoor seating. The outdoor seats provide for great people watching, but on any normal evening it would be too warm to sit there, especially while eating pizza.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: Dragged the whole family to have pizza, in honour of my hubby's BDay. The StarterCaesar Salad - really good sauce over fresh Vege and nicely grilled chickenThe PizzasPistachio Pesto - interesting pesto taste, not bad tasting but not likely to order again tho Â Spotted Pig - nice flavour and kids loved itSeafood - seafood is fresh and taste okPepperoni - I was slightly disappointed as the taste is not bad but I expected more from gourmet pizzas mahThe PastaMeatball - this was for my pasta fan in the form of my girl. I tried the sauce and it's tasty. My girl obviously loves it too as there was none for me. The ServiceWonderful service. It could be because we were there quite early and one of the staff even folded a tissue rose for my girl! Winner!!The Ambience - on the night we went, it was very balmy and the kids had a kick sitting on the high chairs!!Not exactly a place I'll return as the price for the food is not really worth it. It's more of a chic place to hang out with decent pizzas.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: I'm not saying that this is the best pizza in the world. Pizza is just one of the many international food options that Singapore doesn't exactly excel at (unfortunately). But it is quite likely the best pizza on this little island. The ingredients taste reasonably fresh, the crust is just right in terms of crispiness and chewiness, and the toppings are fairly interesting but effective combinations. I like the al fresco seating (some may hate this as it's the only option but I'm totally down with the heat over here) and the buckets of Peroni certainly come in handy as does the Kirin on tap.Also, I've been here several times (it's downstairs from my office) and can only describe the service as hit & miss. But the largely Filipino staff serve more hits than misses in my experience, they are normally very nice and, if anything, a tad over-eager. Not sure where all the service-related complaints from my fellow diners are coming from but, by Singapore standards, this really isn't so bad.Best pizzas are the spotted pig, the pistachio and the spicy pepperoni, in my humble opinion. And if you have a health-conscious fellow diner, the cauliflower romesco is surprisingly decent. And this comes form someone who loathes cauliflower.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: There's been a lot of things said about the service here, and I have to agree that it is pretty astounding that they're still in business. However, the delicious pizzas they keep churning out makes it okay (for me at least), to turn a blind eye to the sub-par and not-too warm service. After all, I'm here for the food. And if you don't like to dine here, there's always the takeaway option (within the CBD area unfortunately). Dining here can be a sweaty affair as there are no indoor seats, so come at night if you want to avoid the heat. I find it okay as there are lotsa places you can smoke in secret. As the Pizzas are made to order only, waiting times can be a little long when they're packed, so expect some downtime after ordering. The variety on offer is really great and you can taste the freshness of the ingredients. The crust is just right and not too skinny or flaky. Price wise, it's really affordable for the quality of the pizza you get. So yes, I'd come back for more or just order takeaway.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: Really, really good pizza - the best I have had in Singapore and this New York pizza snob was impressed. We ordered take away (they had a 3 for $50 special) and got the Spotted Pig, the Spicy Pepperoni and a Four Cheese. Also got an order of the Oven-roasted Brussels Sprouts. What a meal! The dough was like home and the sauce, cheese and Â toppings were really tasty. Absolutely worth a visit. I would even eat the crust if I found it in the cushions of the couch the next morning :). Â Anxious to try it in the restaurant. Highly recommended.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: Being a New Yorker, pizza is a major food group for me and this place did not disappoint. We had the margherita and spotted pig, both were delicious. The crust was that perfect chewiness and toppings were also, pretty good. Â I'm still daydreaming about that NY slice but I'm really happy to have this option in Singapore and I will definitely be back. PS..outdoor seating only and happy hour everyday.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: Ya know, this place could be a 5-star if it tried... the pizza is pretty good, not NY good, but pretty damn good for Singapore with a thin (but not too thin) wood fired base, a variety of toppings and not ridiculous pricing... however the service stinks! Went on Friday lunchtime, joined the queues (rookie error going at 12.30 on a Friday) and was seated after about 15 minutes (so not too bad). However getting menus was something we had to ask for, and after placing our order, it took over 15 minutes for 2 glasses of house white wine to arrive - and this after asking 4 different staff members (including the manager) if we could be served! I don't understand how hard it is to pour 2 glasses of wine? Especially by this stage the place was not jam packed full either... Staff looked stressed and unprepared (once again, not sure why, it wasn't overly busy at this stage) and once our glasses were empty, there was no offer to get us another? I really don't understand this, such a simple easy upsell opportunity and one that many mid-tier restaurants seem to miss... I noted that 4 other diners also had some sort of follow up or complaint they had to do with staff members so I don't believe I'm a solo case. The pizza itself was good (we had the meat one) and we also had a caprese salad which was decent, with both the mozarella and the tomatoes packing some flavour. Frustratingly, I would eat there again as the finished product is good, but however I know now to order my drink before I'm even seated!

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: Popped in for the happy hour (2 for 1 Kirin pints) and stayed for TWO pizzas because they were so yummy. Service was great and atmosphere was fun. Will definitely be back.

address: 8 Marina View #01-04 Asia Square Tower One Singapore 018960 Singapore
comment: For a full review, please visit: urbanjourney.com/food-anâ¦When judging a pizza you have to start with the basics: Pizza Margherita ($16). Â This pizza passed our test with flying colors, so, since then we have also tried our luck with several other versions that we would highly recommend, including the Mushroom Bianco ($22), Spicy Pepperoni ($24), and Meatball ($24). Â If you're in the mood for something other than pizza, the veal and ricotta meatballs are also great.Picture this: the cheese is hot enough where it's not running off the slice but has the perfect texture, so when you bite it, it follows and does not create a mess. Â The tomato sauce is not only that perfect blend of salty and sweet, but there's enough to make for proportionate tasting between the 3 key ingredients. Â Plus, the dough cooks beautifully and at the right temperature in their woodstone ovens, making the perfect base and backbone of the pie. In our mind, a city can't be "cosmopolitan" or "cool" if it can't get a pizza right. Â But with the addition of Extra Virgin, that's one more stamp of approval for Singapore.

address: 16 Raffles Quay #B1-17/18 Hong Leong Building Singapore 048581 Singapore
comment: Finally! Â A Halal Certified Japanese eatery in town, that has won my taste buds! Â I read about Fu-Men from several blogs in town, and finally managed to go to DOWNTOWN aka Financial Business District on a Saturday. Â TAKE NOTE, Fu-Men CLOSES ON SUNDAYS!They are located in a tiny spot aka in "The Basement" of Hong Leong Building. Â I say they can seat about 35 people ish at one seating, though it can be a little cramped during PEAK HOURS especially for Lunch. Â Hence plan accordingly.So I take the opportunity to have my EARLY Lunch on Saturday January 26th 2019. Â Time was about 11:40hrs ish. Â Once arrived, the staff will give you the Menu. Â I sat, read the Menu which Fu-Men featured the Hakata Style Udon, but they also offer Donburi Bowls as well. Â From their Menu some of the dishes comes in sets and can be made COLD OR HOT. Â There are some appetizers if you want to order those too.Once I had made my payment for my meal, the staff gave me an Electronic Token, and the wait begins. Â It takes like about 10 minutes for my order to be ready. Â Maybe it will take LONGER for Udon orders. From the conversation I shared with the staff, I opt for the Stamina Donburi Bowl (SG$16.00). Â This dish comes with Rice, Beef, Beef Tendon, Spicy Minced Chicken and an Onsen Egg. Â Though stated that the Minced Chicken is Spicy, personally it was NOT Spicy for me. Â Thankfully they also offer several condiments, at the CONDIMENTS Counter if you wish to add the condiments.I also opt for the Appetizers. Â This was the Spicy Karaage aka Spicy Chicken (SG$2.00). Â It comes in 3 bite size pieces with a little mayo at its side. Â My oh My, those Spicy Karaage is lip smacking good! Â I wish I could have ordered more! Â Maybe next time.With GST 7%, my Lunch was (SG$19.25). Â Complimentary Tea is also provided that comes either Hot or Cold - for this Lunch I opt for COLD. Â In conclusion, what I had and the service I received throughout my Lunch was indeed good. Â THANK GOD, Fu-Men is located NOT so closed to where I live, ELSE I will be in deep deep trouble. Â I will return to Fu-Men in a heartbeat! Â The next time I will try the Udon, or some other items which they offer in their Menu.Fu-Men is about 8 to 10 minutes walk from Raffles Place MRT Station (EW14/NS26) at EXIT I.It is opened during the following hours :* Â Monday - Friday : 10:00 - 22:00* Â Saturday : 10:00 - 14:30* Â Sunday : CLOSEDWhile I was about to finish my Lunch, many more Patrons, dine in. Â Left Fu-Men at about 12:25hrs ish with a satisfied-filled happy belly tummy indeed! Â Oishii! Â Arigatou gozaimashita! Â I shall see you soon Fu-Men... Â Thank you...Fu Men16 Raffles Quay#B1-17/18 Hong Leong Building,Singapore 048581Tel : 6224 1134

Semi-upscale Singaporean food. As the name suggests, the satay here is really good - juicy tender meat - you can't go wrong with any selection - chicken, pork, beef, shrimpBesides the satay we also tried the Mee Siam, which was a tad bit spicy, and the Barramundi, which was well cooked/seasoned though perhaps Good desserts and cocktail selection as well. Â A good place to bring out of town guests for local food in a nicer setting

Not authentic PERANAKAN food  ! So noisy with loud music and dark .... The worst are the TOILETS which are quite far away and NOT CLEAN ! PUBLIC TOILET ! The service is SO SO , so many empty tables and we are tucked in small corner for two :/:SATAYS are too sweet ! BEEF RENDANG Â is under average . DO NOT RECOMMEND this place !

Cheers to April as April is always Fabulous with food. I have heard of Violet Oon's Peranakan Food and always wanted to try thus wish was granted. However instead of going to the one located in Bukit Timah, we went to their latest restaurant located in Clarke Quay.I was not surprise of its interior as it was kind of along the line where a Bar's ambiance will be liked. However it still have a good feel of Peranakan Style (old school) amongst those modern furnishing, decking out in dark woods and authentic Peranakan tiles. Overall the place reminds me of their rich culture but with a revamp into today's settings.If you are hankering for Violet Oon's Peranankan Cuisine like me, fret not. Even though this is a bar and grill, they do incorporate many popular dishes like Ayam Buah Keluah, Kueh Pie Tee, Ngoh Hiang etc.Suitable for vegetarian, these Fried Bean Curds were served with julienned cucumber and fresh beansprouts. Bean Curds were sliced and topped with very yummy Violet's Signature sweet and tangy peanut sauce. A perfect go to start your meal if you are looking for some appetizers.Tau Hu Goreng - $9One of the best Ngoh Hiang i ever had for it was not oily and these Ngoh Hiang tastes refreshing with the crispy deep fried bean curd skin cradling ingredients like prawn, crab and minced chicken with water chestnut seasoning as well as five spice powder. Dipped this fried Ngoh Hiang into the given sweet sauce or Sambal Belachan. It also goes well with the seasoned sides - Achar.Ngoh Hiang - $15When it comes to Nonya Food, this is the classic. Spicy and tangy chicken stew with a few Buah Keluak nuts infused with fresh root spices of Lengkuas and Tumeric. I like that the Chicken meat was tender with generous serving of Buah Keluak however it still lacked the good taste that i find on the meat. Could it be the strong tumeric soury taste had overtaken the authentic taste?Buah Keluak Ayam - $23With a variety of Satay to choose from, each type of meat comes Â in a plate of 3. We had the large chicken chunks marinated in spices, grilled and served with thick flavour pack spicy peanut toasted sauce topped with freshly grated pineapple, steam rice cake, cucumber and red onion. Recommended!Chicken Satay - $14You cant miss out this classic dish from the menu! I would say the all time favourite to order. This festive dish of braised mixed vegetables and bean curd skin in a rich prawn bisque is really awesome, love the part where the mushrooms were so juicy and plump. It may seems a bit oily but best of all its not cloying at all.Chap Chye - $15Choose between Nasi Lemak Rice and Jasmine Rice. The Nasi Lemak Rice is served elegantly in a small little white pot, packed with alluring fragrance of the coconut milk.Nasi Lemak Rice - $2Loving the sweet ending to our meal with a scoop of Gula Melaka and coconut ice cream drenched with Gula Melaka syrup. What makes the good experience will be the toasted cashew nuts toppings.VO's Ice Cream with Cashew Crunch - $10Overall, I find that it is a good place for gathering as well as chill out. The ambiance makes alot of difference and you will never feel as if like you are visiting the usual traditional Peranakan Place.

Went for afternoon tea after spending the day at the museum. Great atmosphere, service, and food. The local version Peranakan afternoon tea is great. Very nice savory and sweet foods make for an authentic taste experience. Highly recommend if you're looking for a more interesting afternoon tea.
A very fancy Nyonya Type of restaurant. Food here is ok. A very good place to bring your guests here.
Wonderful satay and fried rice. Â Wow. Â Amazing food and excellent service in a really cool environment! Â  Great job guys!

Good clean place to meet up with 'food nervous' expat friends. Â Plenty of staff ensures service, service, service. Â The food is well plated with many delicious options - it's a safe place to explore seasonings and spice. Â Very handsome decor. Â Do it.

This was one of our favorite meals in Singapore. The chicken satay and sauce were great-sweet heat. We also had the beef dish and mixed vegetables in coconut broth. The side order of jasmine rice was just enough. The setting in Clarke Quay is great too-we did riverboat cruise after this fine meal, so the location worked out well too.

Some items were good, others were meh. Recommended: Tumeric Sotong, Beef Satay, Beef Rendang. Avoid: Mee Siam - they use pasta instead of bee hoon - what?. Meh: Chap Chye - looks and tastes home cooked.

This is a great option to bring out of town guests and visitors who want local flavors in a beautifully designed setting. The service was excellent and the food a nice balance between being refined and authentic.

address: 2 Bayfront Avenue #01-86, Marina Bay Sands Singapore 018972 Singapore
comment: I happened upon this restaurant while walking around MBS and loved it so much I came back the next day for lunch!I'm normally a 100% ootoro girl but the chuutoro here was AMAZING. The fish took me to heaven and back--perfection. Other than that, the rest of the nigiri was fresh and had great texture.The next day for lunch I had the A4 wagyu gyudon. I normally only go for Japanese A5 wagyu (Australian wagyu is a waste of time) but I understand how A5 would have been too much for this dish. The fattiness paired with the seasonings would have made this dish too overwhelming so A4 was wisely chosen instead.Tip: be sure to make a reservation, it gets crowded at dinner time!10/10 will be here again next time I'm in Singapore!

address: 2 Bayfront Avenue #01-86, Marina Bay Sands Singapore 018972 Singapore
comment: Food: Â Nice food quality in comparison to other places. Prices are okay. Portions for some things are smaller than expected, also some slices of fish are a little thick.Service: Â quite good and accommodating Bottom line: Â I would eat here again probably. Location: Nice views of the bay and ArtScience Museum. Â The restaurant is located inside the Marina Bag Shoppes by the museum.

address: 2 Bayfront Avenue #01-86, Marina Bay Sands Singapore 018972 Singapore
comment: Fusion Japanese food in Singapore! I was looking for something like Nobu Matsuhisa here and I found it. It's still not as good as the one in LA but it will do to satisfy my New Style Sashimi craving with their Special Carpaccio (I recommend white fish) and yellow tail with jalapeÃ±o. They've got a variety of rolls also, and obviously portions are not as big as in the states so be mindful of that. I would come back to satisfy my cravings. 3.5 stars is about right but rounding up to 4

address: 2 Bayfront Avenue #01-86, Marina Bay Sands Singapore 018972 Singapore
comment: service was friendly but disappointing--due to a lack of knowledge regarding the sake & food menus. the sake selection offered various bottle-sizes (300ml, 500ml, 750ml) and offering sake by the glass, which is a pleasant surprise to individual drinkers or those who don't feel the impulse to consume an entire bottle. the sashimi 16-pc. sampler wasn't too fresh, with recently-thawed tuna and toro that had been lightly seared around the edges.would order again: truffle edamame (how can you really go wrong with that) and truffle ankake (who am i kidding, i love truffles).

address: 2 Bayfront Avenue #01-86, Marina Bay Sands Singapore 018972 Singapore
comment: LOVE this restaurant. My family and I visited Sen of Japan recently and were blown away by the level of service and the delicious food they had to offer! They were very accommodating for our larger group. The meal was delightful in every way and the view was captivating at the base of Marina Bay Sands. We will be back!

address: 2 Bayfront Avenue #01-86, Marina Bay Sands Singapore 018972 Singapore
comment: The sushi was fresh and delicious. Â The miso black cod was perfectly prepared. Â Unfortunately our experience was marred by soggy chicken karagge - deep fried breaded marinated chicken. Â It arrived soggy and tasted as if it had been fried in rancid oil. Â Perhaps it was reheated. Â (We had excellent chicken karagge at Ginzu Lion in Suntec City a few days later.) In addition the salad dressing on the salad at Sen tasted as if it had turned. Â So while the higher profile dishes on the menu were fresh and prepared well, more standard fare was poor. Â Perhaps the way to avoid disappointment is to only order more expensive dishes as that is what the kitchen pays attention to. Â  Service was excellent. Unlimited refills on the ice green tea was a nice touch.

address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #03-145/146 Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Reminds me of the good old Ponderosa. They have a good selection of chicken in their menus. I love the chargrilled chicken and their black pepper chicken. Their salad bar has quite a reasonable spread. Free flow of softdrinks, coffee and tea. Price is reasonable. The Just Buffet is a little expensive to me at $19.90. A black pepper chicken priced at $22.90 includes the salad bar is a steal. Get there early or try to call to see if they take reservations. During dinner hours the queue could be long.

In a street where new food establishments seem to pop up every week it is nice to find a place that does not follow the trend of being hip for the sake being hip and not being a Korean BBQ restaurant. Â Don't get me wrong - I like Korean BBQ. Â I just don't need 20 of them on my doorstep. I digress. Â Marukyu is an upmarket Japanese restaurant. Prices are at the very top end for the area but, Â thankfully, so is the raw materials and food preparation as well. Â I had the sushi bent box (very reasonable price) and everything, Â from the grilled cod, Â via the sashimi to the sushi rice tasted great and was perfectly cooked. (The sashimi wasn't cooked - you get my point. I look forward to come back and try the fuller menu in the near future. Â I hope I'll be able to keep the 5 star rating - I love japanese food.

This spot was a great find on my walk home one evening. I had gone the wrong direction and ended up on a different street than my usual route and noticed all the taps lined up - more than I've seen at any other spot in SG.The interior is cozy and inviting, brick all around with an open kitchen in the middle. I can't remember the exact number of beers they had on tap but between their own brews and guest taps, I'd say well over 20. I got a taster (flight of 4) and they were all great. The hazy IPA was actually hazy unlike many of the "New England style" IPAs I've had in Singapore that we're still pretty clear all the way through. I'd definitely come back again to try the rest

I've been known to rant copiously about craft beer, especially when I see it being treated roughly, indifferently, or just improperly. Â It's a visceral reaction, it upsets me and sits in my craw, an insoluble caustic precipitate slowly eating away at my very core. Â  Conversely, when I see time, energy, and money being poured into an enterprise built around highlighting their most prized product, I weep, especially when the product happens to be proudly, independently crafted beer. Heart of Darkness (HoD)has not been around a long time, but the depth of flavor and the balance in all their beers belies a wealth of experience extending far beyond the founding of the craft brewery in Saigon, Vietnam. Â I've been recommending people visit HoD when in Saigon for as long as I can remember and now there's one right in my own backyard! Â Life just very very much better for anybody who enjoys a flavorful pint. Â I'm not knocking national or commercial lagers, but if you're counting calories like me, then you might consider giving beers that are brewed independently and with quality ingredients to underscore the highlights of each beer style's characteristic traits a go to make those calories count!If you know Tras Street, then you'll know that it's converted shophouses that now house bars, restaurants, karaoke bars, coffee joints, and speakeasies. While HoD Singapore is not a speakeasy, you need to pay attention of you might just miss out on a good time. Â The set up is a taproom and an open kitchen. Thirty taps serve 25 HoD beers and 5 guest taps that will likely be representing local craft breweries, so right off the bat, HoD Singapore is a good "high density" beer location to be visiting, Â especially if you're not in Singapore for long. Â The partner at HoD Singapore, also has an active interest in craft brewing in Singapore and the likes of That Singapore Beer Project and Daryl's Urban Ales are likely to be regular taps at HoD! Â The space is cozy, and has a pleasantly edgy vibe. Â I like it here already, and am thankful to be alive in Singapore at this very moment when craft beer is exploding in the hands of professionals who care about the product enough to want you to care too and enjoy a quality product the way it was created to rock your world!
This place is super chill, the beer is good, and the staff are genuinely friendly (lots of places here they are just sort of 'polite' which ain't the same thing). Â Cool 'hood. Highly recommend.

Best place I found for beer hands down! The IPA selection was AMAZING! Nice atmosphere, well done. Make SURE you make it to this palce if you like beer. I wish I could get Heart of Darkness in the US.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Closed'])]
comment: This place is actually called Yan Kee Noodle house, not Yankee. Â Mee sua dry noodles, and apparently the best in town. Â Don't be fooled by the imposter across the street- I'm told this is the original and the best. Â And open 24 hours! Â I can't think of a better $4 at 4AM, post drink meal.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Closed'])]
comment: I've always loved the dry mee sua at BK Eating House. Recently, around Sep 2018, I heard the news that the original mee sua owners were chased out by their landlords and opened a new stall directly opposite BK, calling it Yankee Noodle House. Visited it the first time today and am pleased to share that there is air con! Hurray! The interior is so much cleaning then the previous area at BK. The plus point is that the price remains the same at $4 per bowl. I went after the office lunch hour and was enjoying my noodles in peace, save for 1 little table with overly loud UOB bankers. The place is relatively clean too!Will come back again soon!p.s. Heard that the original stall is still at BK eating house with different people wearing the same uniforms and cooking the same mee sua/mee pok. Which is better? I think this is, this is the original!

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-379, Suntec City Mall Downtown Core 038983 Singapore
comment: Play areas fit for 3 & under, Lego blocks tables galore, large fully stocked art center, dress up area, play area for older kids, a tweens area with games + a healthy selection food area. During the holidays, Cool De Sac had fun hands on interactive activities like tea party, craft time, dress up etc.There's enough here to entertain your little one for hours without getting bored. Money very well spent!!

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-379, Suntec City Mall Downtown Core 038983 Singapore
comment: Easy to find, one level up from uniqlo and H&M in Suntec. Lots of kids, packed with parents and everyone was so busy. It's great entertainment for the kids. So much variety - slides, digital interactive play area for young and computer games for the older, bridge, foam (could have done with a few more joining blocks but I was impressed they had it), ball pit, stage for dress ups (unfortunately kids couldn't get dressed up and roam around in the outfit - only for photo purposes). They had a tots area for under 3's and arts/ craft area and food. Very reasonably priced 22.80 unlimited play for. Friday. Only thing is you need to trot outside for the toilets and when your in a dash with the lil one you have no time to put everyone's shoes on and run along. For men the bathrooms are closer but women's are a further trek and seemed longer with a toddler who's busting to go. With excess use some things could do with a touch up. The gym/ slide area was a bit smelly around the bottom areas.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-379, Suntec City Mall Downtown Core 038983 Singapore
comment: Indoor play area for kids. Â I would say good for kids up to 10 years or any kid (or adult) that needs a respite from the heat! Â  They take your kids temp at the door which is apparently normal here in Singapore. Great for getting some of that physical energy out. Â Glad we stopped by, even as a tourist.

address: 3 Temasek Boulevard #02-379, Suntec City Mall Downtown Core 038983 Singapore
comment: Located in Suntec City mall on the 2nd floor. This is a decent indoor park. it has a few slides, ball pit, tree house & bridge, foam block station, lego station, pretend play station, an art station, play areas for toddlers, tweens, and a cafe for parents/ guardians to stay in while kids roam or play around. I Recommend keeping a closer eye on your younger kids as the older kids tend to get rowdy if they're excited and may run over the little ones. There is a diaper changing area but i didn't see any toilets for the kids or adults to use in the premises. They accept card and cash. they sanitize hands, check mouth and hands prior to entering. Bring socks as it's needed while inside. It's a good space to let the kids run off some of their energy, my kids enjoyed then park.

rest_name: Bee Cheng Hiang - New Bridge Road
comment: First of all... I booked my hotel down the street from this place. So it was super convenient for me to buy this whenever I wanted during my stay In Singapore. They open superrrr early given I left the hoten around 730-8am every morning and they were already open and making fresh jerky every day. After going around trying different Jerky's offered in SIngapore...this by far has to be the best. And during my layover in Shanghai... I actually saw Â they had a stand there!!! PLEASEEEEEEE OPEN ONE IN LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA!!!! I totally need one of these near me so I can snack happily hahahaha.The texture wasn't super soft and not super hard. Very fresh and they make their jerky's daily. OHHHH how I wish meat was accepted to bring through customs to the US!!!! Since I was just around the corner... I had bought some and snacked on it during my stay. This location is pretty open spaced but super clean. I like how you can even sample the jerky's too before you decide if you want to buy it or not given they have sooo many different flavors as well. I never saw a line here even during the weekends. People are totally missing out if they aren't buying their jerky's here. Highly recommended to tourists too if you ever decide to head to Singapore. They also accept Visa (as well as most stores/restaurants throughout Singapore).

rest_name: Bee Cheng Hiang - New Bridge Road
comment: I guess final day in Singapore would not be complete without these foods... soooo yummy

rest_name: Bee Cheng Hiang - New Bridge Road
comment: Irresistible, mouth-watering BBQ meat-jerky! I like the Chilli Pork - the spice kicks in at the end. The vacuum packed Mini-EZ makes a great choice for gift-giving or just to munch'em in the office whenever there is a crave for sweet and savory.The best part-- - no added preservatives- no added MSG- no added artificial flavoring- 100% natural ingredients

rest_name: Bee Cheng Hiang - New Bridge Road
comment: The temptation is always too much, I can't walk past here without buying something. This outlet is good as they grill on site instead of just being a retail outlet. Although it can get expensive real quick, a few slices of grilled smokey spicy beef or pork is an awesome snack and goes even better with beers - definitely great drinking food!The ladies working the counter are pretty friendly and are happy to cut you up slices to try and once you have tried some, there is no way you can walk away without buying something! You have got to be a vegan to resist this kind of food ...

rest_name: Bee Cheng Hiang - New Bridge Road
comment: Tons of locations around the country. I love Bee Cheng Hiang over the rest because:- There're hardly any lines; there're so many stalls everywhere- They Vacuum pack these delicious BBQ pork into boxes and i can bring them back to the US- They have bacon and chili varieties that are AWESOMEI dare you to walk by a Bee Cheng Hiang BBQing Fresh BBQ meat and NOT walk in for a quick snack. I.Dare.You

rest_name: Bee Cheng Hiang - New Bridge Road
comment: This is simply the best jerky I have ever consumed. Â They have several flavors, and meat types, I really loved their pork. Â My only regret, is not purchasing more of their vacuum sealed jerky to take home. Â There is nothing in the US that I have had, that even compares.

rest_name: Bee Cheng Hiang - New Bridge Road
comment: These guys are pretty consistent, no matter which store you go to. I only discovered jerky in the last few years. Previously, I couldn't stand the smell. Once I got past that, I found out that it's seriously tasty! I've tried various pork and beef, but find that I only really like the chicken one. Nom nom nom. Always have a few slices each time I visit Singapore (in fact, even if I'm just passing through Changi). It's worth the calories!!

What an amazing hidden Italian gem restaurant in Boat Clarke. Upon our arrival on a cool evening around 6:00PM, we were greeted by the friendly staff to show us to our river view table. Bruschetta al Pomodoro - simple and delicious.Pasta - clams with pasta you can't go wrong with seafood in white wine. I couldn't get enough Pizza - the pizza amazing, the sauce is fresh along with the prosciutto which equal to epic pizza. Tip: You need to make reservation to seat near the River view tables.
I wasn't expecting much with the risotto but it had amazing truffle flavor; really nice change in the middle of all the Asian fare available here. Â Great views too.

rest_name: Koji Sushi Bar - Raffles Place Branch
comment: I love this place! I was so glad when they opened up a location even closer to my office. Yes, it's on the pricey side, but the quality is there and it's worth the upcharge.

rest_name: Koji Sushi Bar - Raffles Place Branch
comment: There's really hardly any sushi around this area other than kinki which is more expensive and noisy but comes with a great view. I've had the takeaway here a few times. Take note they charge 1 dollar more for the brown rice option. I finally went in to have a sit down one day as I was craving uni. I ordered set a at $9 and sec c at $20. After I finished my small salad (bleah) and was halfway through my miso soup (mediocre) the waiter came back to me to say that uni was out. Imagine my disappointment. They told me they would sub scallop. The waiter was kinda just told by the chef to tell me. Chef made no eye contact. Manager was busy chatting away her own stuff at the counter quite loudly.If you compare my photo of the 2 sets. It really looks like I paid 11 dollars more for a hotate sushi which is overpriced. In the end the sushi quality was not bad and the size of the slice was good. But I think the service is the opposite of warm. Â Considering the place was nearly empty as I was having a late lunch (2pm) they could have example offered me a free dessert or something for the disappointment. Instead the asked if I wanted to upgrade my salad to panna cota for 3 dollars which I declined. Still OK for takeaway but I would only come in if I have a strong craving for sushi specifically and I check that they have what I want upfront. Â For takeaway 4 star, for dine in which was this latest visit was 3 star.

Good thing I gave it another shot. Â Why "another shot"? Â Well, I ordered a meal box via uber eats, ginger roasted chicken breast + other stuff. My order arrived and the chicken was a bit raw.I immediately messaged them privately via their fb page. The owner/chef replied and told me to come by their branch which I did a few days after.The owner remembered me and to my surprise he offered a discount. Â Everything went well - the food, service and all.So it will now be my after-workout- go-to-place from now on. Life is about giving chances anyway :)

It has been a long time since I truly felt touched by honestly good food. Â The moment I bite into the Kale and Mushroom, the cacophony of flavours simply exploded in my mouth without warning. Sweet, spicy, tangy......how can this humble looking sandwich taste so fabulous? I could not suppress my excitement and wanted to find out what magic has gone into this sandwich. "It's Chilli flakes that we've infused into the olive oil and that tang comes from the clots of lemon milk juice cream you see on top of the mushrooms." answered the owner Traveen in a slow-paced Norwegian accent. Chilli flakes and lemon milk juice? WOW. This brilliant inspiration can only be found here at Smor, Singapore's first Scandinavian Deli that is opened by food enthusiast twin brothers Traveen and Tarun Gulrajani. They were so captivated by the concept of Smorrebrod (which means "butter bread") during their 3-month tour of 12 Scandinavian cities that they decided to bring it to Singapore, elevating to an artisan level with quality ingredients all sources from Scandinavia.  It is not only the quality ingredients that make this worth. Like the Kale and Mushroom, the Crunchy Bacon is piled onto buttery and crisp toasted brioche bread that doesn't turn claggy with the moisture of tomatoes. Topped with side eggs, wilted baby spinach and shavings of emmental cheese, this warm open-faced sandwich is a great breakfast choice that tickles one's fancy. Â These sandwiches worked amazingly better than most cold pleasure-less wraps as they are prepared fresh upon order. The warm versions easily gain the upper hands as our palates acclimatize to the heat but the cold sandwiches are seriously not bad either. Â Instead of mundane ingredients like cream cheese and capers, the Smoked Salmon has a lovely acidic-sweet kick coming from the horseradish and dill-infused sweet mustard dressing which I mistaken to be honey at first. Some might find the Norwegian hand-peeled shrimps to be tad salty but if you factor in the tangy lemon mayonnaise and the sprinkles of chives, it's a simple, refreshing yet addictive combo. Â These voluminous seafood filling are stacked onto gluten-free light rye bread is resilient enough to avoid saturation from the extra moisture, yet still soft enough that it doesn't wear out the muscles as you chow into it. Â This is probably also the only place in Singapore where you can discover a fair range of Scandinavian chocolate snacks, savoury produce like caviar or coffee. I bought the Jaffa Nougatine bar ($2.50), some really good milk wafers at only $2.50 and the Shuffle Toffee Biscuits, the sinful combination of snickers, Mars and Toackers that are worth the calories. Â I have posted the Shuffle Toffee on my instagram hereWas it by chance that we managed to pick all four choices that were delicious? I seriously doubt so. Yes, the price of $6.90 for one sandwich, $12.90 for two and $17.90 for the Viking meal of three might seemed a little pricey or not satisfyingly sufficient for a meal. But trust me, a regular meal of two sandwiches are more than enough to fill you up. Moreover, if it's such a wholesome meal prepared with healthy ingredients, passion and sincerity, why not? Â I seldom say that I will return to try the place but this I shall unabashedly say that a return is a must.

4.5!Love this healthy and authentic Scandinavian eatery in Raffles Place! Wish I had tried this place sooner when I worked at the area. Â It takes a bit long for the order to come out, but it serves one of the freshest and healthiest dishes in Sing. I tried the smoked salmon sandwich and immediately regretted that I only ordered one, and the thick and hearty avocado soup was one of the best I've tried. Â They have combo lunches such as meatballs and chicken that come with pasta, broccoli, and roasted cauliflower, and salads that are simple yet unique in taste. D takes away dinners for me randomly as I crave this place on a time to time basis. The owner is usually always on site and he's been helpful in choosing the meals I want. highly recommended!

I. Love. This. Place. *ahem*  Sincere healthy food Located in at the bottom of the one raffles You do what is blatantly good When we want something more than just waffles Your chicken breast is skinless Your beetroot yam combi fulfilling Your service is wonderfully full of classiness Which is why i love the food that im eating
The food looks incredibly bÃ¸ring, but actually it doesn't taste that bad, and it's healthy and cheap. SmÃ¸r can give you tremÃ¸rs and help with amÃ¸r.
A very great food that is something simple but perfect. Â More people should really get to try this place.

The ONLY authentic Danish/Scandinavian place in Singapore.Must try for all you foodie Singaporeans, super fresh and the owner Traven treats you like family.Beef smorrebord is the best, tried them all. But if you want authentic Scandinavian try the herring.His soups are awesome also, favorite is the pumpkin spice.
They serve good and healthy food. The portion is good. Excellent service from the chef.But the place is a little bit small, just good for a small group of people.

always been a big supporter of wolf. Â  would drive distant to get my buger fix. Â  today was just a big disappointment. Â got a soggy burger unlike wolf's standard. Â  whoever cooked the burger needs to be retrained. Â  not letting the meat rest could be the ussue here. Â 9/4Well i previously gave a 1 star due to an absolutely soggy french dip burger but got a message/email from the owner himself inviting to make good and make good they did!!! Kudos to a biz/owner that can be bothered with customer feedback. Â Really do appreciate the boss taking the initiative to engage the customer and for that not only he won back a loyal customer and i am sure i shall be spreading the Wolf Gospel so to speak - thank you.Sep 29th '18Checked in again for the usual Double and Shroom with Sweet potatoe fries. Â  Glad to report all good.

Impossible truffle burger ($17.90) - 3.75 starsThis was the first impossible burger I had and a great place to start! Excellent texture and flavouring - it was very tasty. They replicated the meat flavour well and I appreciated the beautiful lettuce it came with. It was topped with mushrooms and cheese. I docked 0.25 stars because it was too salty, and the last star for the bread, which tasted like a nicely toasted but regular hamburger bun, i.e. too soft and unsubstantial. I'm a huge bread person and the only burgers I've ever approved of have been gourmet ones with Real bread for buns. Solid, though I hardly crave burgers so I'm not sure I'd be back unless they could make it less salty and get a real loaf of bread.

After being on vacation and eating tons of chicken and seafood for 10 days, we were craving burgers. I found this place on yelp. It was a little difficult to find as it is in a food court (Suntec's Pasarbella) and was not listed by itself in the mall directory.We ordered 2 waygu beef burgers and the trio of fries. The burgers were good but nothing outstanding. It did seem to fulfill my craving for a burger though. The trio of fries included sweet potato fries, standard fries and fortune fries. Fortune fries are hard to explain but they are sort of airy fries that have a little bit of sweetness to them.Overall, I think I have really high standards for a burgers but this place did the trick. Service was quick and easy.

I blindly came here, didn't read any reviews, and wasn't expecting much except to just quell my appetite. Looks like I chose right. I ordered the Chicken Curry burger with truffle fries. The chicken breast was so crispy and juicy and the curry complimented, not overpowered the taste. The turkey bacon was perfect too. You could've fooled me because unlike turkey bacon I had back in the US, this almost tastes like the real deal. Truffle fries were good too and I'm glad they didn't just pour the truffle sauce onto the fries. I'm glad they took their time to prepare my burger. Definitely worth another visit if I'm in the area. Not bad for "mall food court" food.

Located at the Pasarbella enclave at Suntac city producing marvelously crafted burgers. Â The mushroom Â burger's patty is medium rare cooked, very delicious, coated with melted cheers with sliced sautÃ©ed mushroom piled on to and sandwiched with beautifully puffy and light bun. Â Over all the combination of smells, tastes and textures are so well put together that the burger rank up with the best I've had. Â The buttermilk chicken burger is equally well crafted with a crispy from the outside succulent from the inside and very tasty.This is my new go-to burger place!

What a fun burger place at Suntec's Pasarbella!I came in wanting to try their signature Wolf Burger, but the staff was very good in convincing me to their their Alpha burger, which is their take on a double cheeseburger. Apparently they use a completely different beef for it, which could be why it's higher priced.I wish I could've had my burger done medium, but I went for well-done just for pregnancy precautions (I know... I know...)The burger itself was still very good; juicy and filling (after all, I was eating 2 patties; one for me, one for baby!) I'm pretty sure it'd be better if you order it medium!Unfortunately the sweet potato fries were a miss. They tasted good, but they were either overcooked or not fresh, as there was no crispness in the fry. Maybe it's best to just stick to their regular fries, more turnover = fresher?
The taste is just average. Â No wow factors. Â Service was quick and price reasonable for this level of taste. Perhaps a bit more sauce would help.

Great burgers!!! This place totally surprised me; going in I didn't think it woild be that good.
