My favorite in past memory was from Totto Ramen, which managed to create an incredibly comforting flavor that was also rich and complex. The line was about 40 mins long on a Wednesday evening around peak dinner time (7:30pm), but since I didn't know when I would be back in the area, I decided to brave the wait. I liked that the bowl was customizable on several variables: the saltiness, strength of broth and oil, chewiness of the noodles, and toppings. I ordered the Tori King Ramen non-clear soup and stuck to the normal/standard for everything, which runs for S$11.90++. Though soft-boiled egg isn't included in a standard order, they do have FREE UNLIMITED hard-boiled eggs and bean sprouts. A soft-boiled egg is a must have though, and it really should've been included. You could also grind your own sesame seeds to add into the soup, which was a nice touch.The normal texture noodle was already quite chewy and I liked that they used the wavy style of ramen. However, the broth tasted just like CHICKEN SKIN FAT. One redeeming factor is that they claim the soup has lots of collagen in it, but it still felt like it was clogging my arteries. Rather than the chicken soup for the soul type of flavor I was looking for, this had the very raw, chicken-fat-under-the-skin type of flavor, which is actually what I can't stand. Maybe I'd prefer having no chicken oil at all, but the regular tori broth just wasn't for me. I also ordered a wasabi ginger ale, which was intriguing, but the wasabi was hardly noticeable and not worth the purchase.

I haven't had the best experiences with chicken ramen in general. Usually, it's too mild, sometimes even close to tasting like nothing. And then here comes Tori King - the chicken ramen game changer.Just like any other Keisuke, you would order it based on a sheet, choosing which one you'd like, texture of noodle, amount of oil, what kind of garnishes you'd like, and if you want any extra toppings, like getting an ajitama egg or the special (all the works). It also has free flow hardboiled eggs and beansprouts.I chose the Tori King - the classic chicken ramen which a rich broth, because you know I'm all about creamy broths. One of the first things that you would notice is that every single bowl comes with a giant chicken leg that is so well cooked that you could still taste the crispy skin on the leg. The ajitama that I ordered with my ramen came perfectly cooked, almost as if the hallmark of the perfect bowl of chicken ramen.While this was a great bowl of ramen, I still generally prefer the pork based broths. If you've been burned before by another chicken ramen (looking at you marutama), and have given up all hope on chicken broth ramens, I'd definitely suggest Tori King, to maybe help raise some hopes for chicken broth kind.

I started this review in 2013, but as we count down the end to 2014 I'm committed to clearing all my unfinished half-draft-reviews.Ramen Keisuke Tori King is the chicken version of Ramen Keisuke Tonkotsu King. Wait, you guessed that? It's not even that obvious!Anyway the soup here is (almost) the shizz. While I prefer the porkier flavour of the porcine sister outlet, the chicken thing here is, in local terms, "damn solid la". Coupled with the variety of 'styles', green, black, and... well there's no blue but the green and black are both delicious. I really don't think you can go wrong here, except if you underestimate the queue during lunch time (and indeed, even on weekends sometimes). If you like Tonkotsu King, you'll like Tori King. If you don't like Tonkotsu King... then I don't really know what to say to you anyway.

Busy place which looked promising but the food was average. The usual free flow of eggs and vegetables were available. Even though I don't fancy chicken drumsticks very much, almost all the options included one so I decided to try. This is my second time having chicken stock for ramen and I can now say with certainty that I prefer the good old pork stock. I thought that it was my personal preference but my friend also felt that the food was not fantastic. I had the cheap thrill of diy grinding of black sesame which felt quite therapeutic to me. Haha.

This is a review of lunch with friends at Ramen Keisuke Tori King at "100 AM at 100 Tras Street". Â It is on the third floor of the mall.One quick anecdote:It is easy (at least for me) to get Ramen Keisuke Tori King (Tras Street) and Ramen Keisuke Tonkotsu King (Traas Link) confused. Â Well, my friends and I ended up queuing up at each one. Â We then got it sorted out.This is a busy shop. Â There will usually be a line but it seems to move quickly. Â Actually, everything about this place moves quickly.The staff is effective and efficient. Â However, do not expect them to fawn all over you. Â They are going to quickly take your order (which you check off on sheets) and then almost as quickly bring you your hot fresh bowl of yummy ramen. Â I think they also expect you to oblige everyone and quickly devour your tasty lunch or dinner.This is the order sheet from Tonkotsu King but the sheets for the two restaurants are almost identical. Â If I am not mistaken Tonkotsu King specializes in pork while Tori King specializes in chicken.Along with choosing your basic ramen type, you get to select the strength of the taste of the soup, how much oily you would like it, and noodle texture.tinyurl.com/k7e7k8kThe chicken ramen here is very good. Â You bash up your sesame seeds and tuck in. Â The chicken is tender. Â The noodles (for me) were just right. Â The soup was flavourful. Â The flavoured egg was bang on.Disclaimer - I fully admit that I know very little about ramen. Â I do not know a good ramen from a bad ramen. Â I do not know what makes a ramen more or less authentic. Â I just know whether I like it. Â I really enjoyed this ramen.tinyurl.com/l36kmbdReceipt (Lunch for 3): $50.25tinyurl.com/nyln8xkOverall - If you do not mind queuing for a bit and having a relatively rushed dining experience, I think this is a very good place to grab a lunch or dinner. Â It is not the kind of place to go and have a leisurely meal while hanging out and chatting. Â I think the food is very good. Â It is freshly prepared. Â It hits the spot. Â Just make sure that if you are meeting friends, you are all meeting at the right Ramen Keisuke.
Tasted most of their ramen stores. But I love this ramen store. I tried their original ramen. The noodles, chicken and soup... was flavourful and tasty. I would recommend anyone to go try this ramen.

If I had a sister, I would dress her in a sexy outfit, tousle her hair, and send her on a quest to capture the heart of the Tori and Tonkatsu King, Chef Keisuke Takeda (assuming he's not already taken). Â Then I would make a point to eat at their house every damn day of the week!I was skeptical about the ramen "king", having slurped down my share of quality bowls, but holy shitake, this guy makes EXCEPTIONAL ramen. Â Ramen Keisuke Tori King has a straightforward menu with 3 types of ramen: plain, black spicy and green. Â You can work the figurative customization knobs on strength and richness of broth and degree of noodle hardness. Â When there is a line outside, the waitstaff provides pens and order sheets so you can figure out what you want in advance. Â That way, once you sit down, it only takes 5 minutes before you get a steaming bowl of ramen plunked down in front of you...followed shortly by a glass of water and a big tub of seasoned bean sprouts.I was first struck by the unexpected full chicken drum and thigh, which turned out to be delightfully tender and tasty with truly delicious and flavorful skin. Â My first spoonful of broth struck me blind, deaf and dumb to everything else going on in the restaurant. Â The only part of my body I was conscious of was my tastebuds, and they were exclaiming, "WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOWEE!!!!!!!!! Â YOWZA!!!" Â The broth captures to an exponential degree the pure essence of chicken, reduced down to the potency where every spoonful feels like it must contain the entire flavor and essence of a whole chicken. Â It is a remarkable taste! Â Although I ordered normal richness, the broth was extremely oily, but I loved every spoonful, and my noodles, which I ordered hard, were perfect. Â As a certified egg-ophile, I was happy to discover that the restaurant also offers unlimited hard boiled eggs to dunk in your broth. Â Although not as delicious as the seasoned eggs, the hard boiled eggs are still delicious and I halved a couple into my soup, spooning broth into the yolks to convey the flavor.PARTING THOUGHT: Must go to Tonkatsu King ASAP!!!

This is now on my must-eat ramen list - yes, it is chicken, I know, and I've had some not-so-stellar chicken ramen in my time, but this is SUCH GOOD CHICKEN. As you queue, you get a great view of guy preparing this amazing chicken, and as you read this, you'll know not to focus on the guy, but on the amazing chicken. Yes, the amazing chicken (you get, it don't you?) gets arranged on a tray, and then gets torched, for some amazing skin char, and that's how it becomes this amazing chicken.As all this happens, you'll want to drool openly, but of course, refrain from such uncouth behaviour. You want to remain polite, and most importantly, keeping the drool off your shirt - the very same one you'll need to be wearing as you walk back to the office.Okay, you've been to the porky cousin, so you know what the system is like. Cool tea out front to appease you while you wait, little slips of paper that show you the three options (normal, black spicy - kinda like Cantonese chili oil, and green spicy - yes, wasabi), and those spices go on top of your chicken.First time means "try the crazy option", so I picked black spicy, while my dining companion (was sounds so proper) picked the green. Wah lau. DELICIOUS.Tick the option that gives you all the toppings, and you'll eat, and be satisfied. I could talk more about the ramen-eating experience, but you'll want to come here yourself and ignore everything else I said after the words "SUCH GOOD CHICKEN".Last words? Just be patient. Good food is on the way. Or go at 1.30 to avoid the lunch crowd.

Decided to check this place out since we happened to be in the area just before they opened at 11.30am. However we both found it to be way too salty and greasy, even though we'd ordered it with less oil and less salt. Neither of us even touched the soul as it's rather gelat. My dining companion felt nauseated by the experience unfortunately. Can't quite understand the extremely long queue that was present when we exited.

Heard a lot of good things about this venue so we checked it out. It was early for dinner so the place was empty which is nice b/c usually there's a long line (or as Singaporeans call it, a long queue, is it?).The ramen is tasty, the noodles are some of the best I've ever had in a ramen and the chicken thigh that comes with the ramen is AMAZING. The tender meat just falls off the bone and is so delicious. Never had anything like it in a ramen.The broth was really thick and not that great... it was pretty heavy. I had the regular ramen, not the spicy one.The other cool thing about this place is the big jar of pickled sprouts to top your ramen and the eggs on every table.Worth checking out but it's a tad pricey for ramen. I think we paid close to $40 for 2 - beware the GST ++

once in the building, the quickest way to get to their unit is via the lift.well posted signs, for now, means you will not get lost.once you have located the unit, a snaking, in my case lunch cum new opening, queue beckons.once in the queue, a constant smattering of japanese reassures you that you have joined the right queue!their staff efficiently hands out their menu, order chit and pen whilst you wait in line.an open kitchen with full glass enables you to appreciate the amount of work they put into your little bowl of ramen.the order chit is easy to follow, step by step.step 1:choose ramen broth and ingredients.broth - original(chicken base), green spicy(wasabi) or black spicy(peppery)ingredients - seaweed, flavoured egg or all toppings(go for this!)step 2:choose strength of soup, amount of chicken oil and noodle texture.step 3:specify any ingredients you dont want.they will then take your chit just before they show you to your seat.service was excellent throughout!everything was presented to you before you ask for it(including the check).from ice water to the black and white sesame seeds in a mini mortar and pestle. help yourself to the free flow of boiled eggs, spicy pickled bean sprouts and bonito flakes.a special spicy sauce is also recommended as a condiment to your chicken.before i could finish peeling the egg, dish out the sprouts and grind the sesame seeds.....my ramen order was presented!i ordered the green spicy tori king ramen with all toppings.you get seaweed, black fungus, finely chopped spring onions, deep fried onions, tamago, pork and a whole drumstick with a wasabi sauce that added a good kick.everything was cooked and served as per my order chit.the broth was full of collagen goodness, a rich murky consistency.the noodles had a stronger yellow hue than what i'm used to.the chicken, which i reckon is the star of the show, disappointed.they simmered, broiled then torched it.but somehow the chicken does not taste market fresh!i love drumsticks but not this particular rendition of it.even the special spicy sauce could not lift it from epicurean doldrums.the pork in contrast was good.it had a nice bite to it.the tamago was as perfect as it could be.in conclusion, if the star of the show doesnt show up, it can only be but an average performance.

After my previous visit to Ramen Keisuke Tonkotsu King Four Seasons , I found myself craving for their ramen again. This time round I went to the one situated at 100AM, which specialised in their chicken broth ramen. The Green Tea Cola tasted a bit like Sprite. It's refreshing to drink this especially after finishing the ramen.The Tori King Ramen with All Toppings is their signature ramen that comes with a chicken thigh, 2 half-boiled egg, a big piece of chashu and a big piece of seaweed. The chicken is tender, the egg tasted invigorating and the chashu was chewy. The greatest credit goes to the soup. It is flavourful, not too salty and accompanies well with the nice-cooked ramen (I didn't finish the soup as per what I did at Ramen Keisuke Tonkotsu King Four Seasons though).The Black Spicy Tori King Ramen with All Toppings is the black pepper variant of the original ramen. It is nearly the same as the Tori King Ramen except with a little spice. If you do want your ramen to be slightly spicy, this should definitely be ordered.Don't forget to have your ramen with the marinated beansprouts!Definitely will come back here again if I'm craving for ramen. If you are around the Tanjong Pagar area, this is one place to visit (the other being Ramen Keisuke Tonkotsu King, under the same company)

Great Ramen! I've been there twice, food is great, will go back again! The service is fast and both times I've been seated right away. They have a lot of sauce options and toppings to add in to the Ramen and the broth is very rich!

My favorite ramen place!!! They have free bean sprouts and hard boiled eggs on the table along with other nice condiments. They have a small form for you to fill out where you can specify things like spiciness and noodle texture. Very efficient service and always tasty!

It's just... I just... I can't... I mean...Alright, so it seems I'm at a loss for words when it comes to the deliciousness of Tori King. I thought I'd met my match at Tonkatsu King, but then they go and whip out a chicken version and my words escape me. The noodles, the tender, tender chicken, the rich green spicy broth, the "make your own ramen" slips... it's just, I just, I can't, I mean... no words. In summary, it's worth the wait. Heck, it might even be worth the commute from Sydney.

The chicken was the highlight, although it was kind of cold despite sitting in warmish soup. The broth was good and not as salty as I expected, having read the yelp reviews complaining about the saltiness, although that might have been because I asked for less chicken oil. The pork was a little bit too hard and dry.It's a little odd that they have you sit across from people that you don't know in the middle table. My girlfriend liked the hard-boiled eggs.I want to go back and try the green tea soda and wasabi ramen. It seemed too complicated of a thing to order on a first trip though. I also like to order a margherita pizza the first time I go to a pizzeria, because it is the purest measure of their skill and a good indication of the quality of their ingredients because it can be easily compared to all the others. For the same reason, I had to go with the basic ramen, and it was great. I also want to try their sister restuarant specializing in gyoza.

On my first visit to this Ramen shop, I was shocked at the Long Queue that it had and I had to wait for about 45minutes to get a seat, and the Long Wait was Worth it.The noodles here are cooked perfectly and still has that springy texture to it. The soup base is not too overpowering. The meat is very tender and juicy. Customers get to choose the Level of spiciness of the soup base. But do beware that the spiciness may blow your head out for those who cant really take spicy food.It is a very good ramen stall and I have been to the shop a few times since my first visit last year. It is really worth the wait and the price is reasonable for the quality of food here.
Generally do not like chicken ramen, but this one was especially good. They provide unlimited (and free) bean sprouts and hard boil eggs although you have to pay for the half boiled seasoned egg.

Tucked away on the third floor of a mall, I walked right by it at lunch without a second glance. Having read the reviews, I sought it out for dinner and was not disappointed. Dining solo, there was no wait, and my ramen was served in a matter of minutes. Fast, cheap, excellent service and delicious food. I can definitely see myself becoming a regular when I'm in town.

Had super high expectations due to all the great yelp reviews. Soup was a little too salty for my liking but loved how it had a great chicken flavor. Guess we arrived at 9 when they wanted to start packing up so was rushed through the whole meal. We didn't even get the bean sprouts! They started packing up our table as soon as they plunked down the noodles. Would recommend to get there earlier otherwise you feel unwelcome
Chicken broth was very rich, a little too much for my personal preference. Chicken thigh was quite tasty though the recommended spicy sauce was not really spicy.

Ok I can't really Â decide if I like the chicken ramen or pork ramen. The chicken broth had so much favor and is slightly sweeter than the pork broth. I do like the black & spicy with everything the most and not super crazy about the wasbi favor. The broth is rich and thick and the noodle are cooked to your prefection. Love it.
Had the Ramen with seaweed and oolong ice tea. The ramen was delicious, the staff was friendly, an the place has a nice atmosphere.

Supertree by Indochine offers a "timeless classic" with a beautiful panoramic view of Gardens By The Bay that is perfect for intimate dinners as well as large groups. There is also an exclusive Rooftop Bar with a S$20 entry fee for those only interested in libations with an exceptional view. The menu is inspired by traditional Asian Fusion cuisine with a modern flare making it a great atmosphere for any occasion. Â We ordered the followings: PLATTERSIt featured crispy chicken rice cake rolls, poached prawn rolls, grilled sea squid, scallop rolls and Kurobuta Lychee beignets accompanied by two types of dipping sauces were all excellent! STEAMED SEAFOOD CURRY A medley of seafood cooked in a coconut curry sauce wrapped in a banana leaf and steamed. The dish was rich and creamy full of wonderful curry flavors. SEARED SMOKED DUCKTender duck fillets were lightly seared and dressed with black truffle mushroom sauce. VIETNAMESE LUC LACBeef sautÃ©ed in spices, herbs and melted butter served on a hot plate with a sweet-sour dip. This entree leaned more on the sweet side which I'm not too fond of. We also ordered a Singapore Sling and Jade Martini cocktails. Both were perfect with our meal! Everything was delightful and the 360Â° view was beyond amazing.

Entry fee comes with a beer $20 or soft drink $12. Â TDLR: not worth it, just pay for the sky bridge instead. Â Maybe it's a Singaporean thing but service has been largely horrendous with rude servers at like +50% of the places I've been to. Â I'm asian and eat at asian places all the time and I don't expect awesome service but this is like even below my low expectations.

Drink is not cheap in Singapore, I think S$20 is reasonable with outrageous 360Â° view from top of Super Tree! We ordered appetizers... to be honest, I did not expect that "fusion" would be tasty. But this place is out of my expectation. We tried little bit of everything, they are all good. Of course, this is a tourist spot. It is a great place to hang out at the dusk time to see Singapore. Highly recommend this place if you visit Singapore!

Mixed review here.Expensive but the view is absolutely worth it. Â Absolutely beautiful. Â We opted for the drink ticket package and I'd absolutely do it again. Â When in Rome, right? Â I'll absolutely pay a premium to sip a wine on top of a SUPER TREE!!!Just know what you're getting here. Â I didn't try the food but I did see some dishes that came out looking delish.

Experience was worth it but service is terrible and they know they have you so prices are extremely high! But where else are you going to get a view of Marina Bay Sands from the top of the trees???? Food was delicious and well presented. The drinks were also good, when we could find a server to order one...... worth the experience for the view, but I wouldn't seek out this restaurant for any other reason. One and done!

My boyfriend and I decided to give this a try since we got to the night show relatively early and we were quite hungry. It cost about $20 SGD per person for entrance fee, which includes one free drink which is reasonable. Pros: Really a spectacular view. My boyfriend and I was here when there was still some sunlight and stayed until the sun went down. I really enjoyed the view and it felt somewhat "romantic". A great place to take amazing photography. Cons: You don't get to see the night show from here, so don't come up here expecting to see the night show. The food is very very overpriced for mediocre food, but it is what it is since it's a tourist area. Yes there's an open bar, but seats can be limited. It's not a huge area so expect to not have a place to sit, which is a bummer. Definitely give it a try if you want to experience the view, but not somewhere I'll come back for a small snack or meal. Way too expensive.

OMG!!! This place is just so gorgeous!!! It should be a must-go place when you visit Singapore. I traveled Singapore with my sister over the summer for three days and my favorite moment was at the top of this restaurant tree.Technically, I paid $12 (Singaporean) to buy a cup of orange juice and the scenery!!! I went around 7pmish and stayed maybe for about an hour looking at the sunset! When the sun is out, you can see the sea and land of Singapore and when the sun goes down, you can see the lights of the city! Honestly, at first I thought $12 for a cup of orange juice was so expensive but I decided to give it a try since I was "traveling". But really!!! You can experience the beauty of Singapore with this view!I loved Singapore because of this place and would 10/10 recommend!!!!

I was led here by a group of my work colleagues whose ideas for dining in Singapore were quite different from my own. Â We were here to see the daily light show in the gardens and then decided to stay to have drinks at the rooftop bar to take in the view. Â We each paid $18 and took the elevator up to the top. Â The entry fee comes with a ticket for a drink. Â We easily found a spot to settle in and ordered drinks. Â We also asked for water but despite a few requests where we were told it wasn't available and they would then speak with their manager, it never arrived. Â However, the cocktails, wine and food we ordered, did arrive with no issues. Â We decided to stay for dinner and ordered the appetizer sampler platter to share. Â Despite being so dark that I could not see what I was eating. Â The chicken wing, spring roll and whatever else I was eating were pretty decent, but typical bar food. Â It was nothing special and most certainly NOT on my list of foods to try in Singapore. The white wine I had was equivalent to a house wine, and nothing special.The views from the bar were okay but after sunset all we saw were lights. Â I'm sure it would have been much better at dusk when we would have had a better view of the Singapore skyline. Â This is your standard tourist trap. Â Everyone around us looked like tourists or folks on a business dinner. Â The food is pedestrian and way overpriced. Â You're paying for the view. Â Service was okay, not great. Â My recommendation is to stay for a drink or two to take in the view but head elsewhere to dine.

The food is surprisingly good. At first sight you wouldn't think so. There's a fee to enter but your first drink is free (however limited to a small menu).I had the seafood coconut curry with sticky rice and Â  Â  some type of green tea cheesecake with chocolate ice cream. Both were very good and I would recommend. Lastly, there is the view of course ;-)...A must do if in Singapore!

Let's face it, You're coming here for the view, right? Well you've come to the right spot. If you're expecting your taste buds to be titillated, then you'll likely be disappointed. Don't get me wrong the food is satisfactory. Just not mind blowing. But the view is gorgeous. 360 beauty, no matter where you sit. And kind and respectful service (duh, you're in Singapore). In my opinion, it's worth the once in a lifetime experience. As long as you're approaching it that way. If you're wondering what I ordered, it was the rice paper wrapped ground chicken. Tasty enough. I'd order it again if I was ever in the area and just had no other option

Ironically, although I'm not the first to review this restaurant on Yelp! I'm actually the person that entered the business into the system. Frankly, I did so with the intent of providing a fairly negative review -- but I see some diligent Yelpers beat me to it. Either way, here it goes:The food is actually relatively good. Not great -- just good. It's seemingly a sort of fusion Malay/Straits cuisine mixed with Vietnamese, Thai and Indonesian influence. The view is also quite nice, as it is in the top of one of the Supertree structures at Singapore's new Gardens by the Bay (worth a visit). Likewise, the bar one floor up provides a good vista.That's the good news. Here is the rest of the story:1. The prices are outrageous. Our bill for three dishes and soup (excluding drinks and no alcohol) came to over S$125. This is particularly egregious in a food paradise of a city where you can get better at hawker centers for $2-$5 per plate easily. Even fairly upscale restaurants in the malls won't run nearly that much. So these prices are for food that was probably in the bottom 25% for taste on our trip to Singapore -- a city with which I am a fairly regular visitor.2. The "admission" to get to the restaurant is S$10/person. Keep in mind that this isn't deducted from the price of the meal if you eat at the restaurant. Since this is an attraction (the Supertree-top view) I could see charging admission if people wanted to just go up and hang out; but really if we are eating there and paying beyond-top-dollar in their restaurant, it should be applied toward that. I've eaten at a few "tower" restaurants around the world in buildings/structures that required entrance fee and in every case they apply the "ticket" cost to the bill if you actually patronize their restaurant.What does come with that S$10 ticket? A voucher for soda. Not alcohol, but soda. I had eaten there, despite hesitation from my wife, because Gardens by the Bay is essentially a botanical theme park, and I had expected to be a little overcharged due to the captive audience effect common to these types of facilities. But it was too much gouging, and we left feeling distinctly fleeced.Gardens by the Bay is a fantastic attraction, and obviously a lot of loving care went into its creation. I therefore understand why they might rent the restaurant space in the Supertree to Indochine to make up some of the cost and help pay its way. However, given the restaurant's extortionate pricing and admission, I think the Garden should consider if it's worth having otherwise happy guests leave with this sour taste in their mouths.Honestly, the value makes it definitely one-star, but in fairness I gave it a "2" for the "3" level of the food.

We are visiting from California so our friends took us to this once because he thought it will be a wonderful experience. Â  The view is nice but good is below average. I would say it's the worst food for whole lot of money. We ordered a bottle of cheap wine for 105 dollars. Â It needed to breathe a little but Â our waiter started to pour into our glasses right away while my husband was trying to tell him to wait. Â My husband and friend ordered lemongrass sea bass and I ordered tiger prawn and pomelo salad while other friend ordered Vietnamese style beef. Â I almost fell out of my chair when I saw my salad. It said tiger prawn but it was more like kitten shrimp. I m not joking about the size of three shrimp that as in the salad. Â When I questioned the size after I saw someone next to me ordering different tiger prawn dish which was decent size, they said because mine was salad. Â Sure, since I must look stupid that I should accept that answer. The dressing on the salad did not go well with pomelo since it was Vietnamese fish sauce dressing. Â With most being the pomelo, and the small portion I still couldn't finish it because it was so salty and overwhelming smell of fish sauce. When it was time for our check, they informed us we need to spend 70 more dollars since it's required to spend at least 80 per person. Â Since we know the quality of the food and the taste, our guys decided in couple of cognacs which was 28 dollars each. It must have been a joke because the serving size was a barely a sip. Â  I understand that they must have to pay high rent to charge so much but the serving sizes there was a joke as well as the waiters and rest of the working staff. Â They were not trained to recommend or tell us about the spending until we got the check, they didn't know who ordered what so they try to give me my husbands dish, Â they were not informed about the wine to let it breathe, trying to explain why my tiger prawn was so small compare to other people's tiger prawns dish by telling me because mine was a salad. Â The service staff isn't well trained for the place where they charge so much money for not so edible good. Do not waste money for it really isn't worth it even for the view.

We didn't eat there and maybe that's where the negative reviews stem from but for $18 to get a drink and a heat respite with a view, I'm sold. You pay $18 for a drink in many places in Singapore so the view to me was a nice bonus. Staff was nice and you can go to an open air area on top and just soak in the views as well. It's a great place to plan to hit after walking around the gardens working up a sweat. I was very glad we stumbled upon it as it never came up in my pre research.

Getting a meal in the restaurant requires previous reservation. However you can get to the top bar without one by paying 40 Singapore Dollars for 2 drinks. It was expensive but the views from the top were worth the price in our opinion. You can stay on the roof as long as you want with just these two drinks and this place is not as crowded as Skypark Observation Deck.However it is better to watch free Light and Sound Show from the ground level.

I conclude this place is fantabulous for viewing our beautiful bright lights, just skip the complimentary drinks.one probably has to appreciate that in this market of rising alcohol prices (thank god I'm basically abstinent), you get one drink (from a short list) with your $18 entrance ticket - but the white wine was incredibly dry (almost akin to the feeling you get after using a tongue scraper) , and a whiskey cola heavy on the latter.I can't comment on their larger a-la-carte drinks menu, because you know I nursed the heck out of my eight-dollar glass of coke (and it was rather flat! at that price I want darn humongstrous bubbles!) - but I was there for date night and the view, so it worked out all good.

Indoor restaurant was booked so we went up the roof top bar instead. We only ordered appetizers and it took 45min-1 hour and we didn't even get any discount for it. Husband wasn't a fan of the one with lychee either. Rooftop access fee only came with one drink. Food and addition drinks are separate fee. This place is only good for its location and sight.

View is nice, food is not good.service staff needs training. If service is improved, it will be better overall experience- Â serving staff were unaware of name of food being served, didn't speak good English and couldn't understand us. Toilet is awful. Entrance of stairs down to the toilet was place where they cleared dirty dishes.Skip the restaurant and head straight to the rooftop bar for view and drinks.

We skipped the restaurant and visited the roof top bar. Â Entrance was $18 per person but your first drink is complimentary so essentially pays you back.The setting is wonderful with the lights of the super trees around you and the view of the city... Â Although there are many amazing roof top bars in Singapore, walking through the Gardens on the Bay (at night) to get to Indochine is a unique and magical experience that I highly recommend.

Supertree by Indochine is in the Gardens by the bay, Â food and atmosphere are great. Â Eating dinner there and having a drink at the top of the tree provides an excellent view of the gardens, Â Marina bay Sands, the cloud and rainforest domes, the bay ect... Kudos to my buddy Michael Ma for a very cool Â  Original restaurant.

We visited Supertree by Indochine to celebrate our anniversary. We had been told it was worth the expense. We wanted to take on nice views of Singapore and basically indulge ourselves, so we were willing to spend more than usual.The restaurant has a nice environment, but the view from inside is rather mediocre. To begin with, there's too much light inside, so most of what we could see through the glass was a reflection of what was happening behind us. The menu is extensive and consists of modern Western and Southeast Asian dishes. The food is, in fact, good (not impressive) and (mostly) worth the price. We had a tasty dinner prepared with quality ingredients and good flavours. So far, so good. The problem comes with the drinks or, to be more specific, with certain drinks. We found that beer and wine are exceedingly overpriced. I'm talking SGD $15++ for a miserable half pint (yes, half) of Tiger, and red wine for no less than SGD $105++ a bottle. On the other hand, single malts or good vodkas cost around SGD $18 a shot, which is, in fact, cheaper than many other places I've visited in Singapore. So, the key is to read the drinks menu and choose carefully.The rooftop bar is where the good view is. It has a very relaxed vibe, a mostly tourist-looking crowd, and chill-out music that is easy to ignore. The food menu for the bar seems like Â overpriced bar food, so it should be avoided. We stayed there for a few drinks and enjoyed ourselves. I'm giving it three stars because of that, maybe my good mood clouds my judgement.My recommendation for the best experience would be to visit the rooftop bar just before sunset and enjoy the views while having drinks, then maybe have dinner at the restaurant, and leave rather early to enjoy and take a few pictures of Gardens By the Bay at night, which is the real treat.

The rooftop bar is worth a visit. You could probably skip the restaurant...The restaurant review: The food is actually not bad. I really like this dish that has lychee with pork loin - a very interesting (in a good way) combination. With that said, the price here is still unjustifiable.The bar review: We didn't have to pay an entrance fee (maybe because we were dining at the restaurant). I believe if you pay you will get a wrist bracelet that gives you a complimentary drink. We ended up ordering a glass of wine ($19) and a cocktail ($20+). I like the chill vibe of this rooftop bar. It is like a casual/unfancy version of Lantern at the Fullerton Bay Hotel. I like that it is uncovered and that I could smell the freshness from the gardens and the sea breeze.Overall yes it is overpriced but if you're looking for a chilled and relaxing bar with a view then I think it's the place :)

It's difficult for a place like this with such an incredible concept and view to warrant a 1 star review, but life is full of surprises. To say the service was terrible would be an understatement of monumental proportions. Come for the view, but expect nothing else as you surely won't receive it.

When in Singapore, there is no way of not visiting Gardens by the Bay. However, for those who have too little time to look at the botanical gardens or who would rather invest the admission money in a drink, the Super Trees will be the place to be, as they are the highlight of the gardens. The plants-covered steel frames are between 25 and 50 meters high. They are used for the breeding of rare plants and at night lit by solar power. Rain is collected in their funnels for the irrigation of the plants. Some of the trees serve as cooling towers for the cooling systems of the garden's domes. Two of the towers are connected with a bridge at a staggering height.In one of the trees you will find the Indochine, a restaurant with a cocktail lounge on the roof terrace, from where you can enjoy a spectacular view onto the city.

What a complete waist of money. $10/$18 just to go up, including a drink. But when we got to the top, the roof bar was closed and they wouldn't let us sit at a table in the restaurant even though there was plenty of space. When we said we were ordering food and asked again about a table they asked- well, what are you ordering? Â Since we weren't ordering 'a full meal' they still refused us a table. We attempted to order for quite a while and were attentively ignored! When finally ordering the drinks included in the ticket, the list was limited and they refused to accommodate any requests, even though all the ingredients were on the included list and wouldn't apply the cost of the $18 ticket to a cocktail. When we finally got our orders, the drink was watered down and the food made both of us sick!

Overpriced, overpriced, overpriced.You pay a fee to get in (this fee includes an alcoholic or non-alcoholic drink, with the alcoholic drink being more highly priced, of course), and the view from the very top is pretty nice. For the price, however, the food is just so-so. We ordered the fried rice, the tiger prawns, and the crispy lychee with pork loin and bacon. The lychee with pork loin and bacon was delicious, and one of the best things I've ever had; the other two dishes were all right, but nothing special.If you really want to, you can pay the $10 fee to go up and get your complimentary soda, but I think your money will be better spent by going to the Skypark at Marina Bay Sands.

The lychee pork was quite good! I liked the oysters!However the fish wasn't very good.Dessert was worse than what u get from 7/11.Furnishing very old and bad taste. Table wasn't even stable.Too expensive, minimum 80 per person.

ew. We walked up to the hostess at the base and she was popping her zit. Quite possibly the worst way to greet customers. We paid our few and went up. The service was terrible. They looked like they had had a bad day and were very depressing to have around. It took a long time for a man to take our order and then even longer for someone to Give us our food. The food was actually not good. Â I don't recommend it at all. Don't waste your money.

Gardens by the Bay are magnificent, but there's no reason to drink or eat at Supertree by IndoChine. Their service is some of the worst ever - awful, rude, bored staff who ignored everybody on a Saturday evening and seemed to have no care for their jobs or guests. No one ever came to our table for anything. We had to walk five feet to the bar/service terminal to 1. ask to order, 2. ask for our drinks, 3. ask for tap water (which they didn't want to serve us without paying for it), and 4. ask to pay our bill. Just terrible. Food was decent but costly ($90 for four plates, understandable considering the locale) but drinks were weak and offered almost no choices: one basic rail/cheap alcohol with one mixer for $18 (gin & tonic, whiskey & coke, etc.) The bar is completely outdoors so if it's too hot or too cold you're fully exposed with no wind barrier, no fans, no ac, no shade. Even the view is better from the OCDC Sky Bridge below. Skip this unnecessary and poorly run bar in the sky, especially considering the worst service we've seen anywhere in Asia in 25 years. September 25th, 2016.

A kind friend took us to the Super Tree by Indochine. I believe that one goes to this restaurant simply for the view and the setting; the food is good, but nothing amazing. Upon entering the entire wait staff greets you as you walk in from the elevator. The decor reminds me a bit of a Vegas casino...flashy. It's an odd system, they have you select and order from an iPad, Â but then you still have to call your server over to confirm the order. Then upon the server placing the order, the iPad is taken away and paper menus were brought out later when we asked about dessert. The food comes with a hefty price tag and the taste does not merit that price tag in my opinion. We split a starter platter for appetisers. I had the portobello mushroom for dinner (it was ok). My husband had the lamb which he really enjoyed. We had the coffee creme brÃ»lÃ©e for dessert. It was actually really good. We enjoyed going up to the rooftop bar (which was closed due to weather) to take pictures and our daughters also enjoyed going down for the fantastic light show. I am very grateful we had the opportunity to try SuperTree, but once was just fine.
Upmarket place, very stylish and posh.I had the steak and fries and it was beyond excellent.If you are in the market for European food and don't mind the high prices, it's a good bet.

The restaurant was located at the far end of the hotel. Usually it did not offer set lunch on weekends, but from 10 to 17 Sep 2016 the restaurant was having La Semaine Francaise (The French Week) promotion for lunch. It was a 3 course lunch set which costs $40++ and was served with a glass of Rive Gauche Merlot or Colombard Chardonnay. I selected the Rive Gauche Merlot which tasted quite smooth down the throat. The meal started with the bread basket and some butter. The butter was in a coin shape with the fullerton logo in the center. The butter was not too salty and quite well with the soft chewy slice of bread. There was also a baguette in the bread basket which I felt was a tab too crusty and hard for me. I was served the charcuterie with the bread basket. There was 3 kinds of cuts and pates in the charcuterie plate.Frisee SaladLardon, Poached Eggs, Cheese Shavings, Raspberry VinaigretteThe cheese shavings tasted a tab strong at the beginning but it was soon balanced off the sour raspberry.Signature Duck ConfitLentils Gremolade, Potatoes RatteThe lentils balanced the slightly salty duck confit. Interestingly the dish was served with raw spinach, tossed with fried sweet onions.Creme BruleeVanilla Bourbon Creme Brulee, Blueberries CompoteThe creme brulee was not too sweet, and it was balanced by the sour tasting compote.I ended the meal with Petit Fours which consisted of praline chocolates, macarons, and kueh lapis, accompanied with a cup of English Breakfast Tea.The serving looked small but were quite filling. Service was great with staffs checking on me often, although I wished for a refill of ice water. The restaurant was quite busy as it was packed with customers having the Sunday Brunch Buffet. There was live singing too. Nice place with a great view.

The guests seemed startled that a local Singaporean on her own could afford to dine here! It took me a while to realise that I was the only Asian (Indian) in the room. If you are a local, single female, dining alone and want what you pay for, go somewhere else.

I love the Fullerton Bay Hotel for its amazing Marina Bay waterfront view and their high tea at The Landing Point remains my go-to for decadent bites. Well i've now found another reason to love them better with the newly refurbished French restaurant La Brasserie. Enjoy your customized Gin & Tonic ($19) as you enjoy the sunset from the opulent surrounding. I don't drink enough G&T but this was pretty refreshing.The French brasserie classics and dishes here have the hallmark of 'cuisine du soleil'. This 'cuisine of the sun' is the representative food of the South of France, a region that is said to be blessed with the sun for 330 days of the year. It is a cuisine characterized by Mediterranean flavours and a lighter touch.Start with a hearty Traditional Onion Soup ($19) which is a caramelized sweet onion soup made with beef stock. The beef bones are first boiled with trimmings without fat for at least 4 hours, and then combined with caramelized white onions for another 3 hours. The hard work culminates into a sweet hearty broth. It's topped with a day-old sourdough with gruyere cheese that has been gratinated under the salamander. Eat it quick before the bread turns soggy!We tasted the Mediterranean influence in the Aubergine Caviar Tartine ($19). The Mediterranean black eggplant is whole baked until completely charred, then served with a sweet Roma tomato confit, buffalo mozzarella and extremely crunchy olive oil pan-seared PoilÃ¢ne bread. The crunch could be heard from miles away. The signature Lobster and Scallop Carpaccio ($33) has been on the menu since the restaurant opened in 2010. The slippery slivers of hand-dived Hokkaido scallop and sweet 'live' Boston lobster are dressed with black truffle oil and lime juice. Hot Smoked Balik Salmon ($21) is one of my favorite starters here. The NZ king salmon is cured with salt and smoked over Japanese binchotan charcoal for a flavorful smokiness! The torched exterior parted to reveal a delicate pink center which is so good on its own. Enhance the flavors with the red onion compote and creme fraÃ®che. SuprÃªme de Canard Confit ($39) with Beluga Lentils and crisp salad is a signature at La Brasserie. I remember not being too wowed by it the last time I had it but the dish seemed to be have improved. The cured duck leg had enough flavor from the salt and fat while retaining a nice meaty texture. Grilled CÃ´te de Boeuf ($99 for two persons). The gorgeous slab of rib-eye is first grilled in a Josper over binchotan and black cherry wood and then basted with a thyme butter! The juicy buttery meat is good on its own and there's no need for the wide variety of mustard, salts, and sauces.Add on sides of potato gratin ($9) or sautÃ©ed peas ($9) with lardon to go with the meat. I hate peas but these were so poppingly delightful. I would certainly order the Lobster a L'Americaine ($68) every time i dine here. You can smell the umami fragrance of that Roma tomato, fresh basil, and lobster base sauce. The angel hair pasta is tossed in with the sauce and the thin noodles absorbed all that lovely flavors. I can finish a pot of this i swear.New additions to the refreshed menu are the selection of gluten and dairy-free buckwheat Galettes ($23/ $28 with a cider). I found the La Complete Galette with Paris ham, Gruyere cheese, and organic egg quite pedestrian. The Louis Ralson Original Crisp cider ($17) cider fared better on its own. Definitely have the Profiteroles ($13) piped with creme patisserie and topped with Chantilly cream and warm chocolate sauce. The double Tahitian vanilla ice cream is out of this world and contrasts with the eggy custard in the airy puffs. It's made even better with the rich 55% Valrhona chocolate sauce which has a nice acidity to it.Also make room for the Tarte Tatin ($32 for two to four persons) which features soft caramelized Granny Smith apples baked in caramel and topped on a mille feuille base. Each guest is served a scoop of ice cream after the pie is sliced table side! I have so much love for the dishes here at La Brasserie. Plus Fullerton Bay Hotel is such a gorgeous place to hang out at. If I were working in the area, I'll definitely go for the set lunches which start from $38. Also, it's possible to take away some of those lovely Western and Asian sweets at the brand new Fullerton Boutique located at the restaurant entrance leading from the hotel. P.s. The Fullerton Kueh Lapis is quite sedap.

Just an overall wonderful place to have nice quiet dinner celebration. Â Food were all served with efficiency and looks wonderful not mentioning tasty. Â Host martin was also great. Â Came out all the way the concierge to make sure I get my complimentary parking. Â This place sure beats the super hyped celebrity restaurants in town for price and value.

This place is amazing! Located along the scenic river, the restaurant has a super-high ceiling, giving one a feeling of comfort and spaciousness, which is perfect for a celebratory dinner. The place is really elegant and the ambience is very good. Even if you only go for drinks, from the moment you arrive, the service is first class. I would add that all the waiters were very friendly, courteous and efficient at all times. We could not fault anything. There are also pretty good selection of alcohols. If you decide to only get some drinks after a rough day at work, sit outdoor - very windy and relaxing. There is smoking area as well.What more - well there are the views across Marina Bay which themselves are stunning. What a magnificent experience! I'll be back to try the food.

This is not a big restaurant and there's no direct view of Marina Bay which I was originally looking for. However these are more than made up for by its great service, food and ambience. It has high ceilings and muted lighting as befits a haute cuisine restaurant. The duck confit was likely one of the most flavourful I've taste and the lamb rack was tasty too. However the steaks with frites was somewhat overcooked and hard; however once we fed back to the maÃ®tre d' / sommelier (an Indian gentleman) he promptly replaced it. Â I would like to commend him for his great service and attentiveness throughout. The complimentary "slice" of birthday cake for my wife was surprisingly large and 2 trays of macaroni/kueh lapis/chocolates were provided gratis too. The whole experience was topped up by a photo card of my family with the birthday cake. The final bill was not too cheap but still very reasonable for the fine dining experience (we were stuffed!) which included a glass of Chilean wine. I highly recommend this place for someone looking for good food, service and refined ambience.

TLDR: Good food and variety for a great price. Your meal includes unlimited salad bar which is full of different pastas and greens. The main course can be had for 20-30 dollars. I got the Hamburg steak which was delectably tender and juicy. Also the salad bar has unlimited egg and at the end fruit and coffee jelly (get it with the milk cream) for a perfect end to the meal.

Great value for money especially the free flow salad buffet. I've had Keisuke ramen so expected this to also be of high standards. The hamburg was tender and tasty, price ranging from $20 to $29. I was a little torn between kurozo chicken and the tomato sukiyaki hamburg but chose the latter since I'm at a hamburg specialty restaurant after all. The salad were really fresh and the special salad dressings provided good kick. They also had some appetizers like sweet potato and black seaweed, daikon and beansprouts. Dessert was coffee jelly, watermelon and oranges. I'll be back again. While the patrons were mostly locals, food wise was pretty good. My daughter who studies in Tokyo, actually says the salad tastes like Japan!

Value for money: 5/5With the free flow salad bar and eggs selection (sunny side-up, omelette, scrambled eggs, boiled eggs, tamagoyaki), you'll definitely make the price tag of 20-30 bucks worthwhile! Taste-wise, the hamburg isn't the best out there but it's flavour and juiciness are above average. Personally, I will give the Shiokoji chicken a miss though unless you ran out of option to choose from!Note: The queues may get rather long during dinner so better to go early

Saw this online and was curious to try. Went there on a Tuesday night (Wednesday being a public holiday) at 615pm and there were loads of people outside the restaurant. Was a wee bit put off by the fact that we would need to wait for dinner when we are that early... but as it turns out, the only seat complete parties, so we were good. Menu is simple enough - meat with cheese, meat without cheese, kids menu. 5 different gravy to choose from - though it was flavourful enough without the gravy. Set comes with one deep fried breaded prawn (yummy), rice and soup. You also have the option to add on extra meat and prawn (can't remember the price). We all ordered meat with cheese and all of us were happy with it. The set also comes with unlimited salad and unlimited eggs. UNLIMITED EGGS!!!! Sunny side up, soft boil, hard boil, omelette, scrambled - you name it and they cook it for you. Salad bar is kept nicely chilled - fresh and colourful. There were also 2-3 different types of cold noodles at the salad bar. For dessert (also at salad bar) you gave oranges, watermelon and coffee jelly with cream (I usually take espresso/ Americano and still felt that the coffee jelly was bitter!). A few things to note (I) CASH ONLY - we ordered the set plus a coke each and we paid $29 each. (ii) make sure all your group/party is present or you won't get seated (iii) they allow you to charge your phone at the table, and you can ask for a cable (in exchange with your IC) too (iv) they do give you a bib but since it not exactly sizzling, you don't really need it. (V) soft boiled eggs may be slightly too raw... Generally an overall good experience ... and a very very full experience :)

Was really lucky to get a seat for lunch on the Eve New Year without having to wait!The menu is pretty limited (choice between the Hamburg steak with or without cheese), but their salad bar is extremely extensive, and definitely worth the money. Salad bar also includes an egg station (being the crazy egg person I am, I had 3 eggs, and would like to recommend the omelette). Price point is pretty affordable for the area it's in (about $20.80 for the hamburg steak AND free flow of the salad bar). Just be warned of the queue! :)

The salad choices are really the star at this place. A variety of veggies and cold pastas and sauces. Definitely bang for the buck for what you get. Some of my friends don't even bother to finish the burger. Definite recommend if you are willing to wait. Weekday nights is not a bad queue.

Definitely have to queue up eariler as it would be a very long waiting time if you went there at a later time. Only two sets to choose from in the menu. Free flow of salad and eggs. Different types of eggs you can request from them. Everyone have to order one of the set. Cannot share your food too. Can also refill your ice and warm water. Overall, it will be filling. The food there are not bad too. Oh and the location is nearby the MRT. Quite convenience.

The salad bar is free flow and is very good. The egg station is excellent! Prepared to queue though. Only 2 items on menu, Hamburg with cheese or without cheese. The hamburg was a bit light but filling. For $18+ it is definitely worth it. Go early to avoid the crowd. Cash only.
Ate here once and it was really nice and worth the price! If you dont want to queue you better came faster before dinner time loo

Good food but the variety's a bit exaggerated by most people. There's basically only one thing you can order off the menu, it's just with cheese or without (aside from the secret Ebi Set that's not on the menu). There's 3 or 4 kinds of salads and the rest of the salad bar are full of veggies so you can DIY if you're feeling particularly hipster. Also there's a egg counter that cook eggs in whatever style you can think of that's basically the highlight of the restaurant.Great atmosphere too, like the dark wood decor, sizzling hot plates everywhere, dramatic mist coming from the salad bar, chef playing with his eggs at the eggs counter and random deafening screaming like "ZIYANG!! æ¥å¸®ææ¶ TABLE!!". 5/5 would come back.
Despite our worries, we were seated without a wait. Food and service were fantastic -- a new favourite spot!!

Since yelp doesn't really have much of a presence in Singapore, I resorted to reading blogs and was enlightened on the breakfast delicacy that is Shui kueh. What is it? Shui is the Chinese word for water and these rice cakes are steamed in little tin cups and individually scooped out by hand as you put your order in. They're slippery, moist, soft and topped with diced preserved radish and you can also add chili oil on top. I'm not usually the one for spiciness, but I tolerated that one and in fact, it MADE the dish for me. I could taste dried shrimp in the topping too, which reminded me of bagoong! Haha. The lines for Jian Bo is a testament their popularity and they're really the best in the island. Â S$2.50 for 5 pieces is not a bad price for a snack. I can't imagine that Singaporeans really have this for breakfast since it's a very indulgent treat. Despite that, I loved it so much because the texture reminded me of Filipino "Kutsinta" and it you've had this dessert, well, the shui keuh is the savory version of it. 5 deliciously cheap stars!

I had a long layover in Singapore so I stepped out of the airport to try some local food and went to the Tiong Bahru food market. This was such a good choice and there was so much good food around.If you are like me and want to try a whole bunch of different food this place is a must. I read about this online on multiple sites as one of the most recommended places to eat and boy it was worth it. My first time having Shui Kueh and it was fantastic. Soft, but juicy and moist delicious rice cakes served with diced preserved radish and some hot sauce. I cannot stop thinking about when I can have this again as I live 15 hr flight away from Singapore.

The best hawker stall food in my entire trip is here at Jian Bo Shui Kueh. It's located to the left corner immediately as you enter the 2nd floor of Tiong Bahru. You can't miss it since there always seems to be a line there.The shui kueh doesn't look like much at first. It's just steamed rice cake topped with a pile of radish with seasoning. However, the topping is amazingly delicious. In fact, it was one of the only food I finished on the entire trip and went back for another order.Plenty of people also stop by to get it to go. I was tempted to take a 3rd order with me but had to refrain. If I'm ever in Singapore again, I would definitely be back to eat this.

Yeap this shui kueh is nice. Probably one of the best shui kueh, translate as Water Cakes, you can find in Singapore.The shui kueh is steamed rice flour and steamed in a small cup. The texture of the steamed rice cake is smooth and light. Topped over it is Chye Poh condiments, and this is the best part of the dish. This shop's chye poh differ from the rest in that you can taste the dried shrimp in it. The others does not add this stuff. That the main difference here.However, this condiment is too oily. You can see the excessive oil dripping down the shui kush and the pool of oil when you are done with it. Otherwise the review would been 5 stars.

I already had so much food but I couldn't leave Tiong Bahru without having tasted some shui kueh, which apparently here, is the best you can get in Singapore. And who told me that wasn't wrong: this has been by far, the best shui kueh ("water cake") I ever tried here in town. The history of Jian Bo Shui Kueh located in Tiong Bahru hawker centre apparently goes as far back as 1960. The shui kueh is topped with "chye pooh" (preserved radish) that is sweet and nutty at the same time. The cake results to be soft and smooth, and is well complemented with the chilli that doesn't overpower the whole taste, working very well with the salty and browned chye poh. A unique delicacy!

Jian Bo Shui Kueh was recommended by Lonely Planet guidebook.Located on the 2nd floor of the Tiong Bahru Market and Food Center.Excellent cheer kueh - steamed rice cake with diced preserved Radish.Try both sauce, one spicier than the other that the Hawker serves with the rice cake.Good value. Â The stall is cultish for a good reason.

There is, in my mind, no better Chwee Kueh than Jian Bo's. Â  Chwee Kueh is a humble dish that given time and evolving tastes may fade from the Singaporean culinary scene and from the face of the earth. Â Panic set in yet? Â If you are the foodie that you say you are, your pulse should be racing and the vein in your temple pulsing right about now. Â  Â Well, ok, I may be overstating the case somewhat, and if the lines in front of Jian Bo are any indication, then Chwee Kueh is safe for now.Chwee Kueh is cakes made from rice flour and then steamed to creamy semi-firmness. Â This simple cake is traditionally accompanied by two condiments, "chye poh" and a savory chili paste. Â "Chye poh" is a salty, buttery, umami-laden concoction that has wondrous and magical powers on the human palate. "Chye poh" which actually refers specifically to one of the main ingredients of this condiment, preserved diced Chinese radish. Â Although technically a condiment, the "chye poh" is in my humble opinion, the star. Â Chwee Kueh lives or dies on the quality of the "chye poh". Â Jian Bo's version is outstanding! Â The diced preserved radish is stir-fried with sesame seeds and I suspect in sesame oil. Â This elevates the two-dimensional saltiness of the pickled vegetable, giving it all kinds of interesting new flavor profiles with nutty, toasty and buttery notes. Â Absolute genius. Â I'm not the only one who thinks so, customers typically request extra servings of the condiment. The fine folks at Jian Bo are more than happy to accommodate cravings for their famous condiment. Â At $3 for a small container, you'd be hurting from the gouging if this wasn't just simply phenomenal! Â I usually just pony up because the "chye poh" will also elevate another quotidian standard, "chye poh neng" or "chye poh" omelette, although frittata is more technically appropriate. Â The "chili" or "hot sauce" is the spice that wakes up the palate. Â This is also good, but a certainly less famous member of the entourage, just like Johnny Drama, full of wannabe angst, with anger management issues. It's dried chilies stir-fried with dried shrimps...what's not to like?? Â The ratios of condiments with each cake are hotly debated and a matter of personal preference and orientation. Â At the end of the day, you find what you like, make your peace and keep your mouth shut about whether you think this is better than your cousin's mix. Â It's not as contentious as Jameson versus Bushmills, but it's pretty close.At the end of the day, it's all about visiting a Singapore landmark, Tiong Bahru Market and Food Centre, ordering up 10 of these lovely creamy rice cakes for less than $4 (at the time of this writing), and enjoying each cake doused with a heaping helping of the aforementioned "condiments" and letting the lied of legacy flavors play soothingly in your head. Â And may I make so bold as to suggest an intermission of a sip of local milk tea and then letting that music continue to play to an audience of one.Of course, there's also Hai San and Tiong Bahru Fried Kway Teow in the house, so remember to leave enough room for a whole orchestra of flavors to flood your head.
The best chye poh and the rice kueh is super soft and moist. Absolutely the best chwee kuey in Singapore

I hunted this place down due to the reviews. Â I didn't realize it was in a hawker market upstairs. Â What a neat place. Â All kinds of different food vendors. Â All the food is extremely cheap and so far delicious. Â This place is no exception. Â The main dish (shui kueh) is delicious and a must try!!!

Can't believe there are only two reviews for this wonderful little spot of Heaven! When I moved to Singapore from America when I was a kid, my parents used to bring me to Tiong Bahru Market every weekend to wean me off cereal and toast. We would troop down to the then single storey market and brave the long lines for this little piece of goodness.18 years on, I no longer live in Singapore. But every time I touch down on the sunny island, this would be the first place I would go. Jian Bo Chwee Kueh, you have my heart. Now, and forever.

This Shui Kueh is pretty good, and affordable too.The kueh in itself is pretty average; however, those vegetables that come with the kueh is unbelieavably tasty. It has this sweetness to it, a little bit of sourness and is crunchy. Worth a try.

The best there is, all other chwee kueh (little steamed cup-shaped rice cakes) hope to be it.Chwee kueh is cheap, comfort food for many. Served with finely diced cai pok (preserved radish) and satisfyingly spicy chilli, this was one of the only foods my grandmother would indulge in without any inhibition, and she was very picky about her food especially when cancer robbed her of her appetite.But when I bought her Jian bo chwee kueh and ate with her in front of the TV, it was one of our happier moments when I realised I finally found something delicious enough to make her feel like eating again.Jian bo chwee kueh stands out, not only because of its fast factory-precision serving line that Ford would be proud of, so long lines move quickly and everyone has a chance at getting their guilty pleasure for only $1.20 (4 pieces). The rice cakes are soft and moist, and the cai pok is fragrant, fried with sesame and dried shrimps. It has all the right bits for perfection.I never eat chwee kueh from any other stalls since I found Jian bo, because that would be like cheating, with an uglier person.
Amazing! Cant put into words. The flavors are rich and balanced. The best i have ever had.

As a commoner cheap food(though not a Michelin starred), Â this is definitely best in sg and probably in the world! w strong è¾ç±³ (fried dried shimplets)ï¼and not just cheap chaipo (pickled chopped radish èå) to make it saltyIt could easily go above 4.5star!Photos: ieatishootipost.sg/jian-â¦

At 4 for $1.40, it is slightly more expensive than the Bedok Chwee Kueh (4for$1) but we do not mind because the chye poh here is EXCELLENT. You can notice that extra nutty aroma and crunchy texture because it is stir fried with sesame seeds. As the owners continue to mill their own rice flour for the chwee Kuey, each petite rice cake is soft to each bite.The best chwee kueh tasted so far

I followed the Yelp recommendations to this little hole-in-the-wall. I'm a white boy from Sydney so the food court felt quite exotic to me. I ate eight of these little fellas, with some of the chilli paste. Delicious and worth the very little money I paid for them, but they are an appetiser, not a full meal. The lady who served me was delightful and I ordered a lemon and plum juice from next door. Definitely a million times better than anything on the tourist strip outside.

Love the vibe, down home beer bar with constantly changing taps. The guys working were very knowledgeable and recommended great beer. The passion from the staff was there and the vide was perfect for an afternoon pint after walking in the humidity. Come to Freehouse for some good conversations and drinks!

Friend grumbled at 3pm on a Thursday, "it's my birthday".Me, "HAPPY BIRTHDAY!!!!!!"Friend, "Shut up. I'm old"Me, "Beers after work?"That's how we ended up drinking beer on a Tuesday at Freehouse. Well we walked in and asked for a table for 3, waiter shows us a table and then puts the food menu down and declares, "I'm not giving you the drink menu because half the beers are not available. We are preparing for a showcase tomorrow. You can go to the bar and check out what beers are left on tap". Right. I wanted to get up and leave because the value proposition before me sounded absurd. It's like queuing up for mee pok only to discover the uncle is already out of vinegar and pork but will still sell you a bowl of noodles to make money. Or Trump promising he'll be faithful to his current wife. Anyway birthday boy wins and I order an American pale ale... it was....sour. I kid you not. My ale was sour. It was so bizarre. Then my friend ordered a beer that he realized (about 5 minutes later) could come in a $25 combo with a hotdog. We called the waiter back and he said no, we wouldn't be able to change our beer order into the combo. More bizarro. We called another waiter and he got the first waiter to speak to the manager and voila, we got our hotdog. I can tell you the beer in the beer combo tasted good and the hotdog was decent. Would we come back to Freehouse again? No. How long will it last at Amoy? I give it a year tops.

Great atmosphere to meet and have a few beers and an excellent selection. Went early on a Saturday evening and wasn't too busy yet. Prices aren't cheap, but the beer is quality - even had some shorts beers all the way from Michigan. Staff seemed attentive, will return for more beer.

I can't get enough of this place! With a number of craft beer bars opening up this year it is hard to be impressive, but Freehouse does a great job. It's on the second floor, so you'll have to look for it, but the sign outside is easy to spot. And then you just need to follow the "stairway to beer heaven." The beer selection is hard to beat, with 15 (or so) well curated taps. You can buy a paddle or a half pint if you want to try a few. I love the food here. It is pretty indulgent and very satisfying. Try the chicken sandwich and the tempura bacon. I promise you will not regret it.

This location is inside Ion Orchard Mall, 4th floor. As a tourist it was easy to get to via the metro. I highly recommend ordering the chili crab and or black pepper crab with fried mantou to soak up the sauce. Pro tip: Save your receipt if it's over $50 Â as you can redeem it for one free drink and access to the 56th floor Ion Sky. Sip your free cocktail while enjoying the city skyline.

The tasting menus here are the way to go here to try a bit of everything. Â There are 3 tiers you can choose from with varying dishes and of course prices. Â We decided on B and were not disappointed. Â There was never too long of a wait between dishes and everything was nicely presented. Â Of course, the chili crab is the main attraction. Â You're provided with a bib and some gloves but be prepared to get messy. Â The gloves are actually more of a pain to use when trying to de-shell, you're better off using your hands! Â But all the work that goes into it is worth it in the end. Â What deliciousness! Â Also found the cheese baked king prawn and beancurd with fresh mushroom to be fantastic as well. Â Can't go wrong!

Chili crab - great tangy spicy sauce, first time, mud crab meat sturdy and meaty compared to Dungeness in San Francisco. Â Enjoyed a lot.Mirugai sashimi - perfectGood set menus for 2-12 people, good combos. Â Upscale super fast accurate friendly service upstairs in a mall of crazy rich Asian stores like frank mueller and Harry Winston.Everything was delicious and well priced.

Absolutely delicious spicy chili crab. The reason why I didn't give them 5 stars was due to not having the Alaskan crab. They have a good size selection of wines but very limited for wine by the glass. For appetizer the Jumbo chili crab bun is very delicious, in fact everything here is delicious.

We came at 1:57 pm and we were sat right away. They do close at 3:00 pm so they were trying to get our order ready ASAP. That was nice, we were hungry! We were lucky enough to get 50% off Alaskan crab and we had it done it two ways: with pepper and with chilli (tradicional Singapore style). I'd like to thank the waiter that took our order cause we didn't know how spicy the chilli sauce was going to be and he was gracious enough to bring me a little sample of it. And we loved it! We also had noodles with seafood and sodas. The crab took a little while to cook (as expected) we actually saw our 2.2 Kg crab before was cooked (sorry!). They do bring you water for your finger tips, wipes, and a few pair of gloves all together with the seafood scissors and tools to make sure you get the last piece out of your crab! It's not cheap but the price it's fair for the flavor, service and quality you get. I recommend!

This place is the Singapore signiture restaurant. They are famous with their Singapore Chilli Crab. It is a National dish. The taste is awasome and must try. Prepare to get messy eating with your finger. Super Yummyyyyyyyy.

Healthy bowls that don't burn a hole in your pocketWith a whole range of healthy bowls opening all over the island, it's surprising to find one that doesn't burn a hole in your pocket. Prices are pretty decent here, considering that it's located at Robinson road / Shenton Way. Located at OUE's swanky new lifestyle hub Downtown Gallery, Wafuken is a little outlet serving some really yummy healthy food. Ordering is simple enough, staring with your protein of choice, followed by side (carbs) with the choice of more sides ranging from Wafu Salad to Onsen Egg. Prices here start at $4 for a half portion of chicken (which is a lot by the way) to $30 for a full serving of Wagyu rump (200g). Carbs are averagely at $2 while add one range from $1 to $2.50.The chicken was sous-vide and was very tender and moist and I liked how it was not over complicated by seasonings, allowing the natural flavor of the chicken to shine. The dory was surprisingly good. A lot of times, places who use dory tend to serve it broiled (more like boiled), with the fish turning mushy and blend. Here however, the dory is lightly seasoned and pan seared very well, giving it a slight crust while remaining tender and juicy. The salmon too was cooked perfectly. The outside was firm while the inside remained moist and juicy. Perfectly cooked salmon! I've tried both the soba and the Furikake Japanese Rice and they both didn't disappoint but if you're going for the rice, than the onsen egg is A MUST!The yolk was thick and rich and really helped bond the rice and protein together, making it a smooth, rich combination that makes you crave for more! Paired with a crisp and Â refreshing wafu salad, it made this dish incredibly mouth watering and satisfying. Overall, the experience was fantastic and it's a great place to grab a healthy meal at decent prices, while chilling with friends.

One word to describe this place - B.R.A.V.O!!!! Â its a 5 stars on all fronts i.e. Service, Food, Ambience and yes even Value. Â Shame to Mingles in Korea which is a 2 Star We say the Stars should be switch!!

Came to this place for lunch with Nik T, and we weren't disappointed. Despite the low cost of the lunch per pax ($50+) , they managed to be very creative and come up with a good 5 courses that utilized many pairings that were delish.However, what captured my heart was the bread, with two types of butter. The bread, oh, I love me a good freshly baked bread. This place has a lot of potential, and all the seats are on a curve surrounding the kitchen so you get to watch the chefs at work.Not a super romantic place as everyone can hear what you're saying, but great for a fine dine meal if you're in the mood for one, but don't want a super stuffy place. Would return for lunch, but alas I don't work in the CBD!

french names always trip me up, so get your linguistic french bff to help, his is no exception.but i did make an exception for the trip down stanley street, on the behest of my yelp partner in crime, and am glad to report with no regrets.an intriguing layout encouraging open communications as well as offering a stimulating combo of visual and olfactory insights into the preparation and assembly of the fresh, seasonal produce that you can expect to partake.the cold draft from the a/c did initially dampen the mood a few degrees but once chef warms you up with his personable attention to details and starts you off with his piping hot, fresh from the oven bread, paired with two versions of his easy to spread homemade butter, you wouldn't mind as much and will be wolfing down as quickly as they show up. no shame in seconds, especially the smooth, creamy but light charcoal butter. the bread is to die for, i would so buy home some if not for them not having enough for the day's demand.service was probably in it's startup infancy.minor hiccups but quickly picked up and righted or explained by the eagled eye and keen hearing chef, himself.they are also tolerant and accomodating towards dietary restrictions or preferences, just specify and you will be heard.pacing was fine for our 5 course $55++ lunch.flavours, colour and textures were above and beyond reproach.accompanied with carefully curated, small batch, lesser known wines that chef proudly declares comparable to, if not better than, their more famous counterparts.Lerouy, said with a french accent, is a value lunch exception in the current deluge of pricey fine dining permutations.

Not sure what's the hate here.. This is the only Canton Paradise I go to. This location is located at The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sand. I have come here a few times and always enjoy their menu at teatime.SERVICE 5/5Service is always good here. Staffs were helpful and friendly every time. My last visit, Andrew was the one who showed us to our table and took our order. He was very polite, very attentive and checking on us throughout our visit. I thought I was having tea at the Ritz-Carlton.FOOD 5/5Baked Char Siew (bbq pork) - 5/5 Fillings inside were generous and savory. Very delicious! Definitely order these when one visits here. I packed some home for my mom and brother.Congee 5/5Light and tastyMini egg tarts 5/5Fresh with crispy crust.Rice Noodle Roll 5/5Opted the bbq pork fillings. The roll was thin and soft, how it should be. Most places failed this part and made the rolls too thick and tough. Fillings were good.Char Siu Sou (Roast Pork/Chinese BBQ Pastry Puffs) - 5/5Flaky crust with sweet fillings. Triangular in shape. One of the must order in all dim sum settings. But only if they are any good. Those served here at Canton Paradise are legit. AMBIANCE 5/5Preferred this location than all other Canton Paradise even though I receive 10% less in discount when currently there is a promotion for all Paradise Group membership. All other Canton Paradise outlets offer 40% off selected dim sum items during tea time from 3-5pm. The one at Marina Bay Sands only offer 30%.
