The bakery is good, though I chance upon quite a disappointing macha croissant today. Just order the original croissant will do. The kouign amann is also good, but a lil too sweet. Overall, I like this joint better than the one at City Hall as it is more quaint because it is located within the hip Tiong Bahru neighbourhood.

Described as the Tartine Bakery of Singapore, I went here a few times. Â I gotta say, I never liked the coffee but the sweet pastries were good (if you're into that kinda thing) but I did just enjoy the plain croissant. Â Enjoy the funky center hinge door when you go.

Recently tried their new savoury croissants.Speaking of the "Rolling Dumpling", I would not have guess that it was inspired from Xiao Long Bao if not for the menu description as it lacked the distinctive traits of this classic chinese dumpling such as the slurpy pork broth. Yes, there were pickled ginger and succulent minced meat but the black vinegar dressing could not lift up the dish.Nonetheless, the sparkling chemistry between the subtly spiced chorizos and the sweet caramelized onion jam in the "Flying Pig" left me clamouring for more. Its miso dressing did not overpower the dish and I wouldn't even mind if the sausage was spammed with even more of the tasty onion relish on top. As a person with a soft spot for fish, I thought I would love the "Jumping Fish" the most but it turned out otherwise. A bite into this voluptuous croissant revealed an oasis of minced spinach and salmon filling. The smoked salmon was not too salty but the filling, which reminded me of the classic Greek Pie Spanakopita, needed a shake of herbs to bring it to life. Another calorie-worthy croissant is the "Running Egg" that was garnished with non-heady Japanese spicy flakes. While ramen egg gurus might insist that the "molten" egg yolk could be more gooey, I thought the current consistency worked well with the bonito flakes and mayonnaise sauce, which contributed to the tasty umami flavours.Prepared fresh in batches and kept warm in hotboxes to retain the temperature, all the croissants, except for the Ramen egg, are baked together with the ingredients. This results in a croissant dough that are more moist and chewy while the external layer retains a delightful crunch.Each croissant is retailing at $4.50 each or you can select any two flavours to go with the tangy salad with yuzu dressing, dried cranberry and mixed seeds for $12. My suggestion is to enjoy these savoury croissants at the outlets where they are served piping hot and fresh from the oven. It's alright if your stomach acknowledged the aroma of caramelized butter by making some embarrassing growls in public.Mine did but so did everyone.
Amazing croissants and beverages. Croissants were the right amount of sweet and their flavoring pleasant and not overpowering. Similar could be said of the tea, coffee, and hot chocolate.

Ordered a chocolate and almond croissant as well as ice chocolate. The ice chocolate is very chocolate. Which is great. This is by far the best ice chocolates I've ever had, beside la galate de Paris. Which is just awesome to have something so close to perfection. They do use real melted chocolate instead of chocolate syrup. Which JC quite rare to find in just any cafe around Singapore. As for the croissant. It's buttery, melt in your mouth buttery. It came very close to what I have had by a professional pastry chef. All in all, because it's too damn close, but as I said... It's close but not quite... Therefore, it might be the best for Sunday times, but not really for me. I've had better... Sad enough I've had better.

After a disappointing chai, we stopped by Tbb thinking we could at least rely on an oldie. The crumble seemed to have dropped in standard. The filling of fruit was barely there and the layer of crumble was so hard.

There are many awesome bakeries and cafes in Tiong Bahru but none are as packed as this one. This is both the upside and downside of this local bakery - the constant line and flow of people means they are always putting out fresh goodies and pastries and even the displayed cakes aren't laying around for long. On the downside, it is rather difficult to find a place to sit especially on the weekends and lunch time. With that said, Tiong Bahru bakery is worth a visit as they have many original pastries, cakes and even savory treats, including one of my favorites the squid ink bun. When I lived in Tiong Bahru and even now, it is one of my favorite breakfast cafes.

The bakery in Tiong Bahru is almost always packed with people and I would say it is for a good reason. They have an excellent selection of different pastries to satisfy your sweet tooth. My clear favorite is their Almond Croissant. It is a bit different than most other croissants as it is bigger, heavier and has a slightly more dense feel to it. The generous filling of almond does however make it really nice. Most of the other pasties I have tried have also been very good as well as some of the savory croissants as well. They do also sell 'regular' bread but actually never tried any of it but it does look nice.They serve pretty good coffee as well (from 40 hands) and the teas are also nice. I also like that they manage to keep things moving smoothly despite the place being full and the service is with a smile.

Decided to check out the place with the hype among Singaporeans.I was pretty excited the moment I stepped into the little store.Got served by this awesome waiter who tries very hard to ensure customers don't wait for too long for their seats. *thumbs up!*Queued, and order a chocolate croissant, pandan croissant and kouign aman.The overwhelming buttery taste of the croissants were SO GOOD. I had this infusion of butter in my blood kinda feeling after my breakfast. (if you know what I mean). The chocolate croissant has a really thin layer of chocolate in appearance, but the taste of chocolate was really strong! pretty delighted with that!Pandan, to me it's a very localized flavour, and I like the idea of it! It gave croissant a different punch in fragrance, worth a try!Kouign Aman was my companion's favourite, as it's salted caramel flavoured! (bread infused with salted butter and caramelized sugar!) Overall taste of the breads were really good!Had a latte and received a fantastic latte art. The sight of it makes me love the cup of latte I was holding on to. Taste awesome!The bad side: over priced. Totally over priced.Even the coffee is over priced.My first bite into the cold breads in the morning was a huge disappointment. I was expecting the bread to be at least warm. All my 3 breads that I ordered were served cold. :(All in all, it was only A-OK for me. too much a hype.=/

The Pastry: I had the Kouign Aman. Think of a light croissant - crispy, buttery layers topped with salt and caramel. More tasty than their plain croissant and not too sweet, which I liked. They also provided an assortment of fruity jams at the side (self-service). I picked a dark, pump colored one which I suspected was a mixture of fig and blueberries.  The Sandwich: KH had "The Speciality Bun with Bacon" and not being a big fan of bacon, I only took a small bite out of it. It consisted of bacon as its name suggests, onions, rocket salad and sun-dried tomatoes. The bacon strip was neither deep fried nor salty but still tasted good. A much healthier way of consuming bacon has been invented (hurray!). The bun was really soft and not heated. Personally, I prefer my carbs hot and crusty but this was ok too. The Beverage:The coffee was divine (probably the best part of my meal). I had a simple latte. Later, I learnt that the coffee was provided by Forty Hands (also part of the Food Collective owned by Spa Esprit Group.) Fun Fact: This is the same group behind the concept of House @Dempsey and Skinny Pizza, both of which I enjoy. Definitely looking forward to checking out their other food joints that I haven't tried, like Open Door Policy Â and Forty Hands. Overall: 3.5/5 (but I can't seem to do a 0.5 on Yelp. oh wellz... 4 then :))Overall, I think it's a pretty decent place for an afternoon tea or a light snack if you are around the area (Tiong Bahru can be pretty far and there's not much to do around there except eat *again* at other places, which we almost did at Rachel's outrageous suggestion if our bellies weren't at the brink of exploding).Pictures of the cafe and its food can be found on my website, pandarcakes :)
Nice place to sit down for an expensive cup of joe or pastry and pretend like you're hipster yet chic. Minus one star for no wi-fi.

This place has managed to take all of my money since I've started working here, as it's a 2 minute walk from the office.This original location has been around for some time, and it's still as busy as ever. I am amazed at the amount of people who chill here around 10 AM on weekdays, both locals and expats. I almost want to yell, "Does anyone do any work around here?!"*There's a lot of baked goods to choose from, but I normally aim to satisfy my sweet tooth by ordering their chocolate croissants. Their plain croissants are also worth a try, as they're super soft, flaky, and buttery. There's also a savoury that I love, but it has a French name that I can't remember... all I know is that it smells like pizza and it's delicious!I'm not sure if they do this all the time, but the coffee that they offer is from Forty Hands (as they're related.) So if you're a fan of the brand, you can easily get your fix here.The only criticism I have is that the furniture is starting to show some wear and tear. If they could just repurpose the chairs and tables, perhaps it will give it a less tired look.*You know I would never do such a thing. I'm obviously just jealous!

Bewildering. I never imagined so many types of bread were possible, and is that black bread? Oh squid ink that's really clever. OMG tarts, and croissants, and savouries too, with coffee and tea, in a pleasant great smelling and great looking French bakery that's quickly gaining popularity judging from the waitlist of people trying to get in. This must be what heaven is like, and French heaven is just extra sexy.These were the first thoughts running through my head when I first saw Tiong Bahru Bakery in the first week of its opening. Tiong Bahru is really getting its hip on, there was no doubt.I had Kouign aman -- if a croissant and a salted butter sultana got together and had a baby, this would be it. It was buttery and only slightly sweet, and so fluffy, I could taste a hint of salt (and a bit of heaven), life was good there and then. To be kind to my waistline, I'm going to make it a point to try something new every week here, instead of doing it all at once, and because I just want an excuse to come back all the time.Coffee was nothing to write about, but hey, that's not what Gontran Cherrier is famous for.

Not only are their baguettes possibly the best that you can find in Singapore right now, but they've also brought the simple art of jambon beurre sandwiches to our island as well! One of my favourite staples whenever I'm in Paris, the ones at Tiong Bahru Bakery are the real deal and the two main sandwich ingredients, ham and butter, are of great quality. Talk about simple pleasures.This is definitely THE bakery of the moment, so it gets pretty crowded, even on weekdays. Worth a visit, and make sure you get one of their baguettes to enjoy back at home as well.
I travel a lot and am always on the search for the perfect Croissant. It is half a world away from where I live (US), but I found it in Singapore in this great Bakery. Who would have thought.

The cafe Latte was really really aromatic and rich in taste. The milk they used was really good that it didn't leave an aftertaste. The crossaint was by far the best i've tasted in the long while. Only gripe is that it isn't bigger. Otherwise, its rather creamy and fragrant. definitely a must try.
First breakfast in Singapore definitely a great place. You can tell the break is freshly made every morning.

The latest addition to the quaint Tiong Bahru area that has seen an explosion of indie coffee joints, Tiong Bahru Bakery is the result of a collaboration between French Baker and the Spa Esprit Group.Despite the rather quaint location, the bakery is frequented by many and its quite common for it to get packed during lunch. Serving up a range of pastries and desserts that are all freshly baked to perfection according to the chef's recipes, the number one selling item here is the plain croissant. While it sounds too basic to be a best seller, the flaky and crispy exterior has a soft airy interior that will blow your mind away. Othermust-tries include the Kouign Aman and chocolate brioche. Definitely a place to visit, but somehow I still prefer Maison Kayser.

Two words. Chocolate slipper. Two more words. Almond croissant. Honestly, this place is just across the street from my work and I find it hard to not want to devour everything. It's a Singapore institution and I can see why. Everything is freshly baked, the staff is super friendly, and they really know what they are doing! Big kudos to the team at TBB!

I have such a nostalgic attachment to Tiong Bahru Bakery - it was one of the first cafes I visited when I was rediscovering the new old Tiong Bahru and I dare anyone to resist their drool inducing displays!The coffee infographic menu is the eye-catching centre piece of the entire bakery and true enough, it was very well made (might have something to do with the guys from forty hands!) Unfortunately, the both Pandan Flan didn't impress - most of their baked goods are priced above $6 and I was just hoping for that little bit more. It's a beautiful space with such a vibrant atmosphere; I'd be happy to come back and give TBB another go! Apparently - the croissants are legendary!
Got a few desserts and breads, and have to say the breads are awesome, and some of the desserts look better than they taste (lemon tarte is tooooo sour and slippery too bitter).

Coffee is good. Especially when paired with their pastries and other goodies.I found my sweet tooth here. Do not go pass the Kouign Amann or the Almond croissant. Sandwiches are good but its their Danish that gets me coming back.

Like that ex you can never cut ties with, I have a love hate relationship with Tiong Bahru Bakery.Let's get this clear. Tiong Bahru Bakery is expensive. Whether you think it's worth it is of course, up to you, but I generally don't think it is.The sandwiches are good, but cost more than two plates of chicken rice at the market down the street... and isn't more filling. What's worth going for? The Kouign-amann. Buttery caramel-y goodness, this is absolutely delicious and the one thing I go back for again and again despite my verbal insistence that I actually boycott the place. After a few weeks of having it regularly though, I'm proud to say that I'm finally so-over it and managed to stay away for a good 3 months.That all came crashing to an end today after I popped in for a coffee. If you didn't know, TBB is owned by the same company that owns Forty Hands, meaning you know you're going to get a good cup of coffee here. It's a little pricey, for a 'small' cappuccino, meaning that coffee here is actually a touch more expensive that most places in the CBD. But it's good, robust coffee, and if you're already overpaying for bread and pastries, well you might as well overpay for drinks too right?Why is it still receiving 3 stars then? Why do I go back? Because it's across the street from my office, and it has the best coffee in the area. Because the quality of what it offers is undeniable, they do good shizz. But the prices. Oh the prices.

Will not say much about the food because the experience was a little distasteful. Right when we have finished our food, 4 big men, we were asked if we would like more food. When the reply was no, we were asked to leave (of course politely), but I still took offense.

I knew this was going to be a interesting meal when I saw the fun front door. The line was terribly long on the Saturday afternoon we first visited. Â I think everything is pretty tasty but the choice, while seemingly extensive, is kind of just variations on a theme. Â I would like more diversity in bread products than pastry and sandwiches. Â My iced latte was delicious. Â The guacamole sandwich was tasty but not filling. Â The pear tart should have had more pear. Â The food was only two thirds of the experience because the cafe was so lighthearted and bustling. Â We couldn't help but have fun.I've been back since and enjoy the food but I'm still looking for my favorite.

I'm typing this after being done with the salmon and cream cheese bun thing and the pear tart. Had a flat white as well. I must say, I had high expectations seeing as to how my friends have raved about this place. Verdict? NahhhhThe salmon wasn't fresh, very unlike the salmon baguette I had at Broers Cafe (and their specialty isn't sandwiches!). And they could've been a bit more generous with the cream cheese. The pear tart was okay (with the so-so hand action). Could've been sweeter, given how the girl asked me "would you like any sweets to go with your meal?". Coffee was okay too.I guess it could be because it's 6pm and the food isn't quite as fresh. I'll give it a second chance and be sure to be here much earlier in the day. So far, seems pretty overrated.

Croissant is nice and chewy and flaky on the outside. Delicious. Add some strawberry jam and a latte and it's a great way to start the day. Â The apple crumble has got to be one of the best things here. Heat that bad boy up and it tastes just like mom's apple pie! Love it. Big enough to share. Huge portion.Tried the Tuna Bread as well--- sadly it was disappointing and difficult to eat/cut. Â Not the most dainty if you ask me, plus you get kickin' breath after so don't order this if you're on a date.
Best bakery in Singapore! Croissants, bread, sandwiches, pastries and drinks: real quality! Plus I enjoy the local scene in Tiong Bahru. To return many times...

Three visits over three days - probably wont be a 4th if there are more than 2-3 tables in use....The service dropped drastically in proportion to the number of people they had to serve - asked for sandwich ro be toasred/ heated - came out "just warm" - 3 coffees ordered at same time ....but each came Â separately. ...5- 10 minutes apart - no warning, no explanation - not good enough.
Had the squid ink buns stuffed w ham+cheese and croissants (plain+almond paste) and everything tasted good although pricey. Extra star was for the fact that we could walk there from our apt.

The crowds here are insane. Despite heading over post lunch hour, we were still met with queues. And what's up with the separate lines for orders and drinks anyway? The order queue is so long, it will definitely intersect with the drinks queue at some point, creating a confusing mess. Found it very frustrating, and decided to do a takeaway of lemon zest tart and berry crumble. Both items were at $6 each, which was a little eh? as the tart is smaller than one's palm, and the crumble was easily twice the size of the tart. Tart was well.. not tart, which left me a little disappointed. It was actually rather sweet, given the candied lemon zest. Tart shell was firm to the bite, and made a mess when it shattered all over my desk. I quite liked the berry crumble - now that was tart and sweet all at once. The base was buttery, the crumbled top crunchy, and the whole item summery and yummy.

There is alot of hype surrounding Tiong Bahru Bakery, it's gotten alot of press ever since it opened so I wanted to see if it lived up to all the glowing reviews.Quite easy to miss if you walk a little too fast along Eng Hoon St, the bakery's got quite a welcoming interior as a long row of pastries greet you as you enter.I tried the supposedly "best croissant in Singapore" with a cup of flat white. There is free flow of butter and jam and water on a separate counter which I loved. The croissant was still delicately crispy on the outside and buttery on the inside, it was good yes! But then how much better can the plain dough of croissant get? Not to dismiss the skill behind baking a really quality croissant but surely there's more to this bakery than the croissants!So I had the salmon sandwich which came with a cardamom bread. All the sandwiches have been pre-made so you can't really choose whether you want salmon with the squid ink bread or chicken with the cardamom bread, which is quite a bummer because I wanted to try the squid ink bread with the salmon. I didn't really enjoy the cardamom bread because the cardamom seeds kept getting stuck in my teeth.It was very crowded for a weekday and the queue was busy throughout!Final verdict: I dough not know if it will continue to reinvent itself or get too complacent with its current success but for now I'll just come for takeaways because it gets way too crowded.

Their baguette's the best I've had so far in Singapore - easily a five star rating, but what brought it down is the below average crowd control (which can easily be explained by the craze caused by word-of-mouth and being in the Straits Times!). Taste-wise, the baguette's near-perfect, down to the hard, flaky brown skin, and the moist, chewy 'flesh' that has the texture and bite comparable to the boulangerie in Rue Caulaincourt in Paris (loved it!). Price-wise, at 65 cm (the benchmark), the one in Singapore comes up to S$2.80, while a Parisian counterpart would be â¬0.80 (about S$1.50). A little too overpriced (especially the croissants!), but lending the Gontran Cherrier baking touch comes with a price (I guess). Will definitely be back for the basic breads, but will give the sandwiches, savoury items and coffee a miss as there's no way I'm paying S$8.00 for a sandwich the size of my palm.

I must say that Tiong Bahru Bakery is quite a cheeky cafe, this. From the outside you may easily walk past, disregarding it as one of them shophouses, especially with the chinese teal stamp on the wall outside. Yet on the inside it was as though past met present - its choice of furniture created a feel of a 70s bakery, yet it also had all the luxuries of a present day air-conditioned cafe. If anything, it can get pretty congested when fully seated, and so rather noisy - but I guess that just adds to the buzz and bustle of it all.I asked the lady at the counter (as I always do) for their recommendation, and was a little surprised when she pointed me to their simplest of plain croissants. It did seem quite pricey ($2.50), but I thought that if she'd dare to point me to something as plain as that, there must be something to it, so on I went to get that, and just that. It was such a treat! You could help yourself to as much butter and jam as you wanted from the side, and trust me you'll want more than one little dish of it. The prune/plum jam was such a good balance of sweet and a little sour and a tinge of bitter, which made my croissant taste like a good after meal sweetener. Then if you'd add the butter you feel like it could well be a pre-meal bite. Such versatile tastes based on the freshest, crisp and perfectly baked croissants you'll find in this country! I found it to be $2.50 well spent.

I absolutely love the vibe of this cafe. Â Because I have celiac disease and cannot eat gluten I cannot speak to their food items (beautiful looking muffins, pies, tarts, etc.), but the coffee is fabulous. Â They always have a line, and the buzz of energy makes for a very pleasant environment. Â We always look forward to a stop here while we're doing our marketing!

Best bakery in Singapore! Â Having recently moved here from San Francisco, I've been trying to find a good bakery with good coffee and both savory and sweet options. Â Tiong Bahru Bakery is it!Everything I've tried there has not disappointed. Â Traditional baguette is amazing, Â Chocolate Almond croissant is good, and the specialty bun with ham sandwich is excellent!

Definitely one of the best croissants that I've eaten. Although the place was small and crowded, the servers were friendly and efficient. Â We waited less than 10 minutes to get a table for four. Â The latte was rich and flavorful. Â The brownie is good and so were the almond croissant and brioche. Took away a squid ink bread with salmon and ham but my sister said it was on the salty side. Â The cafe music is rather loud and I do recommend going to Raffles City outlet for a more luxurious and lazy way to spend a Sunday morning.

Come for the kouign amann and buzzy atmosphere. Spotted before: Zoe TayThe weekend that Tiong Bahru Bakery first opened, traffic snarled to a stop on Eng Hoon Street. Despite new outdoor seating, the best place to sit is indoors, close by the long display of breads and pastries, sandwiches, and baked desserts (in that order). If you're just ordering the fabulous 40 Hands coffee, skip the (usually long) queue and go straight to the counter, one for cash payments and the other for credit cards. Tiong Bahru neighbours swear by the kouign amann ($3.50), a salted caramel spiral-shaped 'croissant' which offers crisp layers and layers of buttery, sticky delight. There is no fruit filling (if you like those, Pullman Bakery does a decent version). There are three croissants - plain ($2.50), almond and chocolate. The texture of the plain croissant isn't the classic flaky sort; here it has many distinct layers - not a unanimous favourite. The almond paste version is much too sweet for me, while the chocolate has a really good quality to it. Baked desserts are rather pricey for the size, but seem to be popular. Try the palm-sized lemon tart ($6), which is sweet and zingy with a lovely short crust. Sandwiches are a good deal, with various ingredients such as bacon, avocado and tuna, each matched to a specific bread such as squid ink or sunflower seeds. (And makes for a cheaper lunch than at sister establishment 40 Hands on the other side of Tiong Bahru). From the recreated old skool look to the freshly baked and high quality goods, this place deserves all its kudos - but the slightly high price point keeps it from becoming a true daily hangout.
The coffee is good but not fantastic either. Â Pretty standard but over-priced. Pastry is nice yet not cheap as well. More for ambient if go there again.

the baguette is way too tough. i prefer maison kayser's baguette. the plain croissant was crispy on the outside, but a bit too doughy in the inside --- at least for my taste. they're closed on tuesdays by the way

Good coffee and AMAZING croissants! I've also had their lemon tarts and it was definitely tart enough! I'd totally go back for more of those mouth watering croissants! really cute place, great to chill and snack - they also have the coolest door ever.
Coffee is excellent and the pastry is divine. Â A little on the pricey side. Â but very cool and hip. Â A must-try if you're in the Tiong Bahru area.
the best Â FOR croissant !! it's real remind me home and italian bakery!! I know the place is French !! but the location and the aroma seems to be back when was child going to my bakery on my street

address: Blk 744, Bedok Reservoir Rd #01-3029 Singapore 470744 Singapore
comment: Great coffee, hipster vibes, expensive magazines on cute little coat hangers, great food. I recommend the sea salt ice cream on waffles and mac & cheese! Get it done.

address: Blk 744, Bedok Reservoir Rd #01-3029 Singapore 470744 Singapore
comment: Recently opened last quarter of 2014. Another option for those in the east. I detoured there for my "teatime" before doing my second errand earlier today. Situated on the quieter side of the stretch of neighborhood shops. I like that it occupies Â the 'L-shaped' corner, which gives it the advantage of views from one side facing the shops, and the other facing the open car park and the newly developed condominium. It has a modern industrial look. Naked bulbs with warm lighting hanging from the sides of the ceiling. These give it a cosy feeling. Petrol tanks are lined against some parts of wall and side panels. Wooden crates used as seats at one corner of the cafe. They have a small merchandise section. The young lady who took my order was friendly and helpful with my questions before I left. The one who served my order up seemed indifferent. It is not just the gasoline station theme that amused me, it seems that it is the whole concept for the cafe - an image of liquid drop (tear drop shaped) used as brand icon. Some interesting names as items offered on the menu: Full Tank, Fill Me Up and Refuel Pancakes. I had a cappuccino, which was quiet a strong brew for me. The Black & White Chocolate Tart... is something someone who badly needs to satisfy serious chocolate craving should have. Generous layer of dark chocolate ganache on top of a layer of white chocolate ganache on (chocolate cookie??) crumbs base. There is a choice of a scoop of chocolate or vanilla ice-cream. Mine will always be vanilla. I was pretty happy with the pitcher of ice cold lemon infused water provided. I will make mine latte for my next stop here :)

address: Blk 744, Bedok Reservoir Rd #01-3029 Singapore 470744 Singapore
comment: This cafe is seriously out of the way for me! But during one rare occasion I was visiting a friend in the east, we came to try it out. It was packed on a Sunday afternoon, with 2-3 groups waiting for a table in front of us. The crew looks flustered and not very good at handling customers' inquiries about waiting time etc. I guess they are still young and pretty new to this yet. My glass of iced mocha latte was so-so. Too heavy on the choc flavour, can't really taste the coffee.They have a pretty comprehensive menu ie breakfast set, sweet + savoury pancakes, burgers and the list goes on....I ordered the Porky Egg waffle. The pulled pork was well marinated, scrambled egg was well-executed.

address: Blk 744, Bedok Reservoir Rd #01-3029 Singapore 470744 Singapore
comment: Nice deco and food choices is quite limited. Free wifi. I recommend the pulled pork burger. Coffee is normal I prefer Starbucks in my opinion. Choose your seat carefully as the air con is full blast. Super cold in some areas.

address: Blk 744, Bedok Reservoir Rd #01-3029 Singapore 470744 Singapore
comment: Went for a weekday brunch & the place is packed, we were on a waiting list. Which translates into popular is good. Portion, atmosphere & taste is worth the money. Ordered 2 mains & a milkshake costing us $30+ as a 2 pax. When you are in the neighbourhood, visit them.. plus free wifi.

address: Blk 744, Bedok Reservoir Rd #01-3029 Singapore 470744 Singapore
comment: The honey lychee "v power" drink is great. The smoked salmon waffle needs more... More salmon. 3 small pieces totaling the area of a credit card. Hoped for more. But its a chill spot for a drink. Just don't expect too much from the waffles.

address: Blk 412 Bedok North Ave 2 Singapore 460412 Singapore
comment: I was doing some research online on where to get good seafood / fish soup and got REALLY excited when I found one close to my home in Bedok! I HAD to put this on the YELP MAP!This fish soup is in the category where they put minced pork inside and the soup tastes like those charcoal fish steamboat places like Nam Hwa Chong, so if you're looking for one that has absolutely no meat except fish, this is not for you! This one is almost like eating steamboat fish soup for 1!Now back to the seafood soup! Prices aren't exactly that cheap but the ingredients they put in, does kind of offset the cost they sell at.I "dapao'd" (take away) the Premium seafood soup set which costs $10 bucks and included a good serving of Pomfret inside, 2 prawns and chuncks of minced pork. Another version also had crayfish!Prices seem to be from about $5 - 12bucks for coffeeshop fish soup, but for this quality plus its smack in the heartlands of Bedok, you can be sure that I'll be back!For those who already stay near by... YOU'RE WELCOME! REJOICE! For a GOOD fish soup place is finally close to home!!

A most excellent location with the water on one side and the WakePark on the other...Views of Wake Boarders and a wonderful cross-breeze accompanied by nice tunes!!! Wow :) The service is note-worthy and the food is exceptional! I say take a visit and and try it out for yourself!!! You will fall in love with this positive dining experience :) Big Thank You Props to Coastal Rhythms :)
Serves nice flavorful nasi with dish. Choice of meats and fish etc. A good variety of sets to choose from. Simply yummy. Â Authentic and one of the best nasi ambeng around.

Wow! Best service in Singapore! They are so happy here and the food is just lovely. Healthy and bright bold flavors! They also make a mean latte that we loved. The harvest bowl with rice balls was so good! We also loved the avocado toast, the drizzle of herb oil was so yummy.

*Coffee Snob Intro*When you're let go from a company the locations you frequent many many coffee shops.These wonderful roasteries provide the perfect balance of professional attitude, casual attire, and passionate delivery to aid you in your job search.I'm going to rate a bunch of coffee shops based on this metric and a few others and provide an overall rating for the experience.----------------------------------OVERALL: 4 starsAmbience: 3Coffee: 5Food: 5Meeting Place: 3Working Space: 3----------------------------------*Coffee Review*Forty Hands! It conjures up a multitude of anecdotes and amusing one liners "open sesame" and "making light work" amongst them; and so it is that 40 Hands comes to the East Coast.When I first came to SG just on 4 years ago now, one of the first real coffee shops that I visited was 40 Hands in Tiong Bahru. I made the mistake of going on a weekend to that particular location, and realised just how popular it was... actually that whole area is an amazing mÃ©lange of coffee/brunch/cocktail options.Since moving to the East Coast there were very few coffee options nearby my condo so it was a real pleasure to have 40 Hands move in for this java snob.I had a buddy over recently from Oz, and every morning we were looking for a cup of the dark stuff, and something to nibble on. 40 hands came to the rescue 3 days in a row with strong coffee and a delicious bacon 'n' egg brekkie roll which is an 'Strayan staple.I probably don't get here as often as I should, but it's definitely one of the first places to spring to mind for weekend coffee.

Probably my favourite go to Thai restaurant at the moment. Lots of variety of dishes. Each done excellently even for those without the thumbs up sign, it is unforgivably excellent!The kang kong, the wrapped pandan chicken, the tom yum soup and the mango salad all makes me drool at the thought of it. They just a taste a tad level higher than wherever place you've had. Prices are extremely reasonable too. Though there was a queue, we didn't wait long to be seated down. The staffs were really efficient. Parking is FREE on Sundays and public holidays. Don't let the distance hinder you.

This is a well known eating spot for employees here visiting from the US. Â It's not your average watered down Thai hawker stand place in SGP by any means. Â This place really has some amazing flavors that's so authentic while prices are the only thing that's inline with hawker stands. Â I tried so many of their plates and you really can't go wrong with any of them. Â My favorite would have to be the Pandan leaves Chicken--truly unique and flavorful. Â Four of us ate here for under $50SGP!
I found here and my friend said this one is really nice , so I went there , Singapore is super hot but the food is really nice there

Very popular on weekends, but the queue of 5 coupes ahead of us moved quickly and we got our table within 10 minutes, and we even got to place our order from the menu while waiting in queue, and almost the food came within 5 minutes - Super fast.Thai pineapple rice - very tasty. Just the right mix of pineapple, shrimps, raisins, egg and not Tio sweet, not too salty.Tom kha gai (chicken soup with coconut milk) - delicious. Nice tangy flavour. Coconut milk not too thick - just perfect.Papaya salad- normal. Not spicy enough for my taste.Minced chicken with basil leaves - spicy, tasty, but a bit too much salt for my liking. Goes well with the pineapple rice.Prawns with black bean sauce - preparation was yummy, but the prawns Themselves were not too fresh and succulent.Overall - quite satisfied, and will come again to try some of their other dishes.

I have been reading loads of good stuff on Nakorn Thai & though I live in the East, Â the thought of long queues put me off. But having acquired the love of Thai food (cooked by Thais) staying overseas, I was dying for an authentic Thai food in the East without having to travel to Thanying. I was about the visit Nakorn Thai when my hubby did some research & told me Nangfa is the original restaurant. So! At 5:45pm, there was already a long queue snaking at the restaurant. Though it was crowded at the old namesake, there was no queue. The choice is obvious. I decided to doggy-bag. There are some food that are just not good for doggy-bag. Eg. steamed fish.Ordered their signature olive fried rice, their pandan chicken and Thai mango. I waited half an hour & got bitten by mosquitoes (please bring your mosquito patch along or pre-order in advance). They only take cash. Ryan took the order. He was efficient & fast.And I told myself Â : " This better be good!" Enroute home, the aroma from the doggy bag nearly killed me.And a bite into each of the dishes, it was as good as its aroma. Not only was the food super authentic & yummy, it was super value. The prices competes with hawker centers! Would I come here again? Yes, with mosquito patch. Note : it's an eatery (aka non-airconditioned) and not a restaurant. Dress appropriately!
Great food! Â Tried the Pad Thai, Honey Chicken, Olive Fried Rice, and Mango Sticky Rice. Â All were very good.

One of the best Thai restaurants I have eaten at in Singapore. We had the pandan leave chicken, green curry chicken, prawn cake and kailan w/ mushroom. Â All were made to perfection, ingredients were fresh, seasoning/ flavouring spot-on and authentic. Â We also had the mango glutinous rice and red ruby. Â After finishing off every crumb from her plate my daughter declared the meal 'so satisfying'. Â We arrived at approximately 6pm and already there was a Â queue but it moves quickly. I highly recommend a casual family dinner here anytime.

Quality Food and very tasty soups. As we were there slightly past lunch hours there was no queue and service was fast. They are generous with Ingredients in the soup . A portion of soup can serve 1-2pax. Average per pax is about $20-25

address: 32 Simei Street 1 Level 1, Metta Building Singapore 529950 Singapore
comment: A friendly, clean, comfortable, and convenient place to get a bite during the day. Simple, fast breakfast items, like vegetarian Bee Hoon. Lunch specials vary on a five week rotation. Bakery, packaged items, and drinks are available. Good WiFi and newspapers in Chinese and English.

I mean for just $32+, you get a teppanyaki choice where food is cooked to order, a wide variety of tze char, and the good ice cream they provide! Sashimi is also available like any other international buffet chain but they have seasonal king crab legs which is really worth the price! Local flair of desserts such as Yam Paste are also available. Pretty neat choice for just $30+
My favourite Italian restaurant in Singapore.The antipasto and calamari must not be missed.

6 years have past since my last visit and I am happy to report that it was as good as I remembered. Â We usually go with a larger group and always order FAI TE. Â The quality and portions were excellent and the service great. Â  Â When you enter the restaurant your are transported to Italy. Â I miss seeing the owner sitting up on the top floor corner table overseeing everything, Â but his wife and son still run the restaurant to perfection. Â He left it in good hands.I introduced this restaurant to some locals 7 years ago and they now are frequent customers. Â I am from the US and just love that such great Italian food can be found in Singapore

Porta Porta is an Italian restaurant that sells traditional Italian food. Honestly, this restaurant is the best Italian restaurant in Singapore and needs to be more famous.Ambience: 5/5 The whole restaurant is very quiet and peaceful and the decor is nice. If you like quite restaurants, this is a good choiceService: 5/5 The waiters were very polite and will try their best to give you the best service.Food: 6/5 ABSOLUTELY SUPERB. First, the calamari with prawns. It was fried to perfection but it was not greasy at all! Although if you were expecting it to be crispy, u will be disappointed as they just lightly fry it in batter. But still delicious and soft. Next, the bruschetta. The bread was so crispy and nice and the tomatoes on top were packed with flavour. A must have for everybody even if you do not like tomatoes. Next, the gnocchi. It was so soft and had a lot of flavor. The tomato sauce was also very balanced in flavor. The gnocchi was handmade so they put a lot of effort and heart into making this. Next, the ravioli. Unfortunately, I do not have a picture of it cos I ate it so fast. :) the ravioli was cooked perfectly and the filling was just so amazing. Once again, the pasta was handmade so a lot of effort and heart was put into this. Next, the lasagna. Again, the pasta was handmade so you know it would be superb. The pasta was cooked beautifully, not too hard or soft. The filling was flavorful too. Finally, the roasted chicken with salad and potatoes. Unfortunately, this was a bit of a let down. The chicken was a tad bit overcooked and dry. However, the salad and potatoes were delicious.And now, dessert! We had the lemon sorbet and chocolate profiteroles. The lemon sorbet was sour and delicious and the chocolate profiteroles were chocolatey and sweet. The lemon sorbet is actually serve in a lemon which is very interesting. Overall, I highly recommend Porta Porta. Its food, service and ambience makes it one of the if not the best Italian restaurant in Singapore

It's tucked away in a row of shophouses along upper change road north and I wouldn't blame you if you happen to miss it while driving by.When you finally find your way there, the food makes the journey worth it - especially if you're not exactly an eastsider. My girlfriend lives just behind so, lucky me.On to the food, for appetisers, I had the serving of roasted peppers, mushrooms and eggplant which was really nice (given that I'm not the biggest fan of leafy greens and variants).For mains, I ordered the vongole, which was simply perfect. The pasta was ala dente, the cleams were fresh and the sauce didn't have that fishy essence that's reminiscent of lousy clams. Gotta have more of it.

I've come here before a few times and always found this place charming. After not coming here for a few years, I went back a couple of months ago and absolutely fell in love with it all over again. It's kinda outta the way (thank god I live at Loyang), but if you're driving, that's fine. There are quite a few new restaurants and stores nearby - so you can explore those stores after dinner.What I Love: The decor, ambiance, service and food is great. It's run by a lady whose husband is Italian - and the place has a very traditional look to it - pictures of family members, trinkets on the wall, it's a mish mash of stuff and it has a very homey feel to it. The food is pretty good! Their bread is freshly baked, and I've had their salad and Prawn Pasta, which is pretty yummyyy tooo. The menu does not give like huge options - but its pretty good. Must Try: Prawn Pasta. Have never tried anything like that before! Portions are huge.What I Don't Love: They don't open during lunch on weekends and they close at 9:30pm too. So, gotta savour your time there! Prices are high too.

This place has awesome ambience if the weather is good - ie not too humid and windy. Best time to come is around 6 where you still get an hour or so of sunset. Food we had were mostly good but not memorable. The Iberico pork chop was well marinated and grilled to perfection. The fatty parts do melt in the mouth. Serving is well for two if paired with some other food but on the fence if it's worth the price. Grilled veggie platter was alright. Can't really go wrong with grilled veggie. One winner was the grilled pork skewers. The minced pork was well marinated and when paired with their homemade spicy dip - I'd get more of these and replace the pork chop. Do note a few other things:1. Parking is expensive and limited - two hours was about 7++2. They'll take your card on tab or pay when food are delivered. 3. Try to book sunset hours so you don't get burn and can still see what you're eating - lights are a tad dim once the sun's out4. Kids friendly and water is free.

Friend booked the place couple weeks ago. U must request to be seated at the deck and dine around 6pm to see sunset! (Make sure you check weather; if it's raining, reschedule)So menu is new compared to friends' last visit a year ago.We ordered:1) Trio Meat Platter Â  Â  - never go wrong with this sweet potato fries Â  Â  - don't expect good Striploin  Â  Â  - Pork Ribs not so bad Â  Â  - Roasted Spatchcock is okay2) Baby squid on plancha is so-so3) Signature cocktail: Beautiful to sea.  Â  Â  Not a big fan of cocktail but just for pic purpose.Waitresses are attentive and they know which angle good for pics.Food: 3.5View: 4Service: 4

4-stars for the view, but seriously 2-stars for the food.This is an outdoor bar and restaurant located within the National Service Resort & Country Club (NSRCC) boat house grounds. It's an amazing place to hang out and kick back with a couple of drinks to enjoy the sea view, sea breeze and be generally far away from Singapore's crowded malls and city area.Unfortunately, the food is inconsistent and ordinary, there's nothing to shout about. The view and relaxed seaside atmosphere keeps me coming back.Getting here on public transport is challenging, so I'd recommend ride sharing or taxi.

This is a review of lunch with a colleague at Chit's Bar and Restaurant. Â The restaurant was selected by my colleague.This is a relatively waterside restaurant. Â It maintains a airy open feel. Â This is true for both Â the outdoor and indoor seating. Â It looked like the kind of place that would be wonderful for an evening of drinks. Â Ah, but this was just a lunch and since it was during the mid-day heat, we selected an indoor seat just under a fan.tinyurl.com/batouxvtinyurl.com/apfsu7kThe server was very friendly, professional, and efficient. Â The food came out relatively quick.The food ranged from good to very good.Chocolate Shake and Lime Juice - Both of these were pretty good. Â But neither of them were great. Â The shake was a bit dense and lacked a depth of chocolate flavour. Â The lime juice was not as refreshing as some. Â I doubt if it was fresh.tinyurl.com/bg4rho4tinyurl.com/bdueonkFish n Chips - When they arrived, I noticed they did not look like traditional fish n chips. Â The coating was more bread like. Â Something more like I would expect to see on a schnitzel. Â But, when I gave it a go, I was pleasantly surprised. Â  The fish was very good. Â The coating was crispy. Â The fish was tender, flaky and flavourful. Â It was served with some fresh greens and some fries. Â The fries were just ok and the portion was small. Â Since the portion for the fish was generous, I did not leave hungry.tinyurl.com/ae3yc5qSpaghetti Bolognese - My colleague had the spaghetti. Â It actually looked very good. Â He enjoyed it.tinyurl.com/aper8qpReceipt (Lunch for 2 - $60.62) - At just over $60 for two people, this is another spot that isn't exactly a budget lunch. Â But it is a nice spot to get a break from the office and see the ocean and some palm trees.tinyurl.com/amfyw4jOverall - I really enjoyed Chit's Bar and Restaurant . Â I think I would like it even more in the evening. Â The food was freshly prepared and quite good. Â The service was friendly. Â It has a bit of a feel of being on a beach-side holiday. I would have no issue with returning.

For a reason unknown, this restaurant reminds me of my childhood. Perhaps its the 80s - 90s like architecture, and the general distance from civilization that makes it feel less Â like Singapore with all its clutter.The best thing about this restaurant could also be the worse thing about it for some people. The airplanes are at an amazingly close distance, it is loud and big and just pure incredible. For me its a joy just to sit by the sea, enjoying the breeze and some seafood whilst watching airplanes take off one by one. Another plus point for me is that the live band generally play the oldies, 60s,70s, 80s, and some 90s. The food is not too bad, the prices are decently matched with its quality. Service is friendly and attentive. This is one of my favourite places in Singapore, a definite 5 stars.
Five star location, vibe and service. Three star food. Not anything awful, just not anything to write home about.

Chit's, you're killing me.Your location is perfect, your staff are attentive and friendly, your prices are affordable and reasonable. But the food, man. You've gotta fix the food.It's not that it's 100% bad all of the time. It's that you're inconsistent. I could visit on four consecutive weekends, have the same dish, and have four completely different experiences. And I have. Then, just when I'm ready to give it up and break it off for good, you serve a damn fine meal and you've got me coming back for another 3 disappointing months.I'm begging you, guys, fix it. I want to like you. I want to have no hesitation in coming back to Chit's because I love the location and the vibe so damn much. But I fear that the day is fast approaching when I'll finally hit my limit and never, ever come back - and that would be a crying shame.Oh, and watch out for the parking. It's a nightmare.
If you are looking for a place right by the sea, outdoor, quiet except for the planes flying above, with live music, serves draft beer, this is it.

address: Blk 539, Ste 01-619 Bedok North St 3 Singapore 460539 Singapore
comment: This hidden treasure is really a local gem in the heartlands! Good nasi padang is not something you easily find everywhere in Singapore. This would definitely be in my TOP 5 list of nasi padangs in Singapore! Who would've thought that it would be in some unknown coffee shop in Bedok!?I went there on Sunday morning about 1130am and the queue was snaking! People were dabaoing so many packets infront of me that it took me about 15mins worth of queuing up to get mine!They have the usual "must haves" like beef rendang, sambal goreng, sayur lodeh, siput sedut, kupang kupang.... and the list goes on!You might be thinking..... "eh what does this chinese boy know about good nasi padang?" Eh hallo! Check my profile... I'm a full on Peranakan boy who must kena my pedas (have it spicy) almost every meal! I would travel to hj maimunah just for my nasi padang fix and have worked at Kandahar street (near arab street) and have eaten at all the nasi padang stalls daily for 3 years - Â from Rumah Makan Minang to Sabar Menanti I & II and of course the famous Warung Nasi Pariaman. I swear this nasi padang review is legit!Of course you don't get the "atmosphere" at Warong Java since it is in a normal coffee shop in the heartlands of Bedok as compared to the ones at Arab Street, but if you're talking about strictly food...? THAT'S WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT!If you happen to live in the far east of the island Â and not willing to travel too far for Nasi Padang then this is the place!Just a tip: A good time to go is from 10am - 130pm where nothing is sold out yet and most of the dishes are up for grabs.

address: 311 New Upper Changi Road Bedok Mall #01-95 Bedok, Singapore Singapore
comment: The Bibimbap here is good! The menu is pretty simple - around 6 different variation of it e.g. Seafood, Pork... I had the Pork Bibimbap and my friend had the beef one. Our reviews were both positive. Although they could have added more dice pork in the dish, the different veges in the dish complemented well. I haven't had bibimbap at those Korean places in Telok Ayer. But the last time I had a good version of the dish was in States. Add a spicy military stew during the snowy winters and it makes for a perfect recipe for homesickness.I think this is a franchise too so you can get it at other places in Singapore. It's like Korean fast food - food served fast.Surprisingly relatively empty too on a Sunday afternoon.Would have tried the rice cakes and other appetizers too if I wasn't in a rush

address: 65 Ubi Rd 1 #01-92 Oxley Bizhub Singapore 408726 Singapore
comment: Such an interesting find within the industrial area around Ubi! A cool and chill place with a large outdoor seating, pleasant enough even to sit outside. Pretty extensive menu, not only tailored for the drinking crowd but also proper dining options from appetizers, sashimi, sushi, dons, ramen, sets to in-house made ice cream and cheesecake! We came for the grilled eel which is a Nagoya cuisine. Good value now with a 20% discount. Wish the unagi could be sliced thicker so we can more with each bite. They also have a free loyalty programme where you get points for dollar spent which you can exchange for vouchers. I will definitely be back. And my daughter also enjoyed the experience and will bring her boyfriend.

address: 65 Ubi Rd 1 #01-92 Oxley Bizhub Singapore 408726 Singapore
comment: I ordered the futago don (gyu don and salmon). I found a short hair in the rice bowl. They have enclosed kitchen concept, all chefs didn't wear cap. The beef was too dry and tough while the salmon wasn't the premium cut Shashimi but bits that left behind of the shashimi cutting. Disappointed and would not recommend this restaurant to anyone.

address: 65 Ubi Rd 1 #01-92 Oxley Bizhub Singapore 408726 Singapore
comment: Unagi and squid grilled to perfection. Friendly and accomodating service to boot. Will revisit over and over again.

address: 65 Ubi Rd 1 #01-92 Oxley Bizhub Singapore 408726 Singapore
comment: I came here specifically for the grilled eel since I saw so many reviews raving about it. Â It was pretty decent but it was not orgasmic by any mean.The outside was fairly crispy with a tender bite in the middle, so the texture aspect was good. Â However, I was hoping for a bit more pop on the flavor. Â To be transparent, I did opt for the salt version, but I don't think that really leads to missing flavor as I have had many flavorful grilled items with salt base at many other establishments.

address: 65 Ubi Rd 1 #01-92 Oxley Bizhub Singapore 408726 Singapore
comment: Believe or not. I had not tried eel before this and so when coming here I choose the eel with scallops combo for fear of not able to eat the eel. Big big mistake!!!The eel was the BEST of the 2 choices. Next time here I get the full eel set. The meat was tender with a nice crispy covering from the grilling. It was covered with a good tasty sweet sauce. They show you the 4 ways (3 maybe) of eating your eel on TV. But the best for me was eating it with the rice and not with the broth. Â Before I knew it I ran out of eel. The meal comes with soup and other stuff. Overall a very enjoyable meal.

address: Kaki Bukit 511 Market and Food Centre #01-19 Singapore Singapore
comment: Normally everybody thinks about Changi Village when they think about Malay nasi lemak. I don't understand howcome this has not been on yelp yet! I have certain items I have to select in order for me to call it a nasi lemak - ikan bilis (no peanuts), egg, chicken wing and a begedil (potato cutlet).All items were served nice and piping hot to me. The rice isn't the most fragrant I've tried but fragrant enough. Sambal is very tasty and have a good kick but found it a bit on the watery side. I would definitely return though instead of driving all the way to changi village, especially if I stay around bedok, I say why the hell not! ;)Enjoy this little Gem!

Alan and his sisters have been running this little eatery here in this sleepy corner of Opera Estate for the last 12 or 13 years. Economical and delicious, you'll find the food authentic and down to earth. They learnt the Peranakan recipes from their mother. Don't worry if you see no patrons eating here, this is mainly a front for their catering business which forms the bulk of their customers. Many Peranakans swear by the quality and authenticity of their food and will get them to cater for events and functions.We had beef rendang, ayam buah keluak, sayur lodeh, and ngoh hiang. They tasted more home cooked than the big Peranakan restaurants, just like how grandma would make it.Dress lightly, his naturally ventilated eatery can get stuffy on warm days.

address: Blk 412, Bedok North Avenue 2 #01-152 Singapore 460412 Singapore
comment: Visited jing long based on a recommendation that their seafood hor fun (rice sticks) is very good. We stopped by around 730pm without a reservation. Staff was very accommodating and set up a side table for the two of us. Extra star for that. Ordered 3 dishes for the 2 of us. I wanted a forth but staff said 3 is plenty. She's right. Seafood hor fun is good. Is it super good? Not quite. Got wok hei for sure but a tad salty for my taste. Vegetable is fresh but left as whole so a little more difficult to eat. There's fish, shrimp and squid. All tasted fresh. I would order this again and tell them to hold back some salt. Soft shell crabs was mediocre. Too salty again. Fried with a lot of batter because the crab was cut up into many small pieces. Cooked the Thai way with basil in the batter. Can give this a pass. Cai Po tofu is one of their specialty and it was too sweet. I think they used oyster sauce and used too much if it. The tofu itself was good. Not too excited about the Cai po. On my way out, I saw other patrons eating a tofu dish with white sauce (egg white) that looks more appealing. Their set menu looks good too. I would recommend the seafood hor fun and recommend that you try the set menu with a group. Adv Reservation recommended.

address: Blk 412, Bedok North Avenue 2 #01-152 Singapore 460412 Singapore
comment: Sunday night rolls around, and it's family dinner time. Time to pick dad's brain for something to try, for he is the resource for all things tzi char. Tere are probably a gazillions tzi char places in Singapore, of which he spends careful time pruning his select list of places we should try before they disappear from a host of reasons including skyrocketing rents, internal kitchen feuds between master and disciple, and the lack of a succeeding generation. Traditionalists island-wide are a dying breed.Anyhows, dad says Jing Long is a HDB void deck place lah, so we'd got the impression that impression that it was a shorts and t-shirt kinda place... Well sorta. We rock up and yes, it's under a HDB block, but it looks pretty good leh! Private rooms and all, so I dwelt super under-dressed when I thought I'd be coming to sweat it out. They were welcoming enough, so in we went.Orders went in, and food's out pretty quick - were we the last ones to order? The sea cucumber, snap peas and mushrooms were out first, and I don't normally even have sea cucumber, but these were braised beautifully, and had that spongey-ness while maintaining some bite. The signature pork ribs were a great recommendation too - with a pork belly-like mix of fat and char, and were super fine-diney in presentation; something that I felt was a little over the top.Tofu and some fried duck pancake too? House specialties, and were okay, but nothing special.At just over $100 total, I thought we ate rather well!

address: Blk 412, Bedok North Avenue 2 #01-152 Singapore 460412 Singapore
comment: Very very average food for such a high price. To be honest I have tried others like Ding Tai Feng and Crystal jade. All tasted better then this. Service is messy and almost non existent. Place is crowded and noisy at weekends. Not friendly for babies. For this price, I will rather go for paradise group restaurants in my opinion.

Wow guys, no ice water? I mean sure you're next to a reservoir so people can go help themselves, but still!It's a lovely chill location, great for late night drinks while chilling with friends. The sliders were aiight, though a bit heavy on the BBQ sauce.The pork knuckle was appropriately crisp but surprisingly bland, and the accompanying sauerkraut was just bad. The signature lobster bisque was... flavourful but I don't remember much lobster.I enjoyed the homemade iced lemon tea though!Overall it's one of those places that's really more about the location than anything else.I'd go back because my friend lives across the street and they open pretty late, but would I travel there just because I miss Wawawa? That's a definite nah-uh-uh.

Overpriced bland food. It's German food because they serve a couple sausages? Drinks way overpriced. Server had strong body Â odor. Warm water is $1, coldWater is $2.50. Nice location though, but it's tastier and cheaper to eat at the nearby Changi Village hawker stands.

A group of us had brunch here with a plan to have a relaxing meal then walk around the reservoir. After we ordered our meals and coffees, we were informed that the only water available was bottled mineral water. I can understand the restaurant wanting to discourage freeloaders from just sitting down and sipping tap water while enjoying the view. But it makes no sense forbidding legitimate diners from having water with their meals. As other reviewers have stated, the irony of this establishment next to a water reservoir cutting off tap water to their patrons is ..... beyond belief.Food came on instalments. Empty plates and cups were not cleared even when being served.Best part of this restaurant is its location and a reasonable selection of beers.
Very nice place.. Open in the evening.. Serve very good food. Such as the pizza... Yummy yummy...

Run of the mill bar/bistro not unlike the numerous ones that's been sprouting inside parks across the island.Came by in the afternoon, had some tea and some sandwiches. Tea is hot water in a cup with a sachet - $6. A plate of 2 slices of ham and cheese sandwiches with some greens and eggs - $13. Edible.Nothing to complain about but nothing to rave about either. Location is good, in a serene environment, if not interrupted by loud obnoxious music blaring from the speakers in the place. Staff kindly obliged to request of lowering the volume though.

Wawawa is a bistro located by the reservoir, with the intention of providing you with a cosy, chillax atmosphere by a body of water. However, I think the choice and selection of food and drinks is so-so only, nothing spectacular that you wouldn't find at any other bar. Also, you'd expect a bar in a place like Bedok Reservoir to have prices that would suit heartlanders, but you may actually be able to get cheaper beers by the pint in town.That being said, I think this is probably the only bar in the Bedok / Tampines area so if you want a social drinking spot this is the place to go.
It's a rip off $82 for 1 Pop con chicken , 1 fish and chip , spaghetti and 2 drinks .. Don't come not recommend

If you are a vegetarian/vegan, then don't bother coming here, especially for brunch. My vegan husband wanted to order a green salad and hash browns, but was told that he could not order them separately and thus had to order a burger set; however, he is vegan, so the burger went to waste in order for him to get what he wanted. Not sure why the menu changed, as you used to be able to order a basket of hash browns as a side. Not many other menu items for vegetarians, and pretty much none for vegans on the brunch menu, though there was no other menu offered on the Saturday morning of our visit. We went with a group of people, all of whom have kids, but were told that the "homemade" pancakes were out, but we could have the waffles. This was confusing, as the batter for both is pretty similar, and if you can make "homemade" waffles, then why not pancakes? I ordered the french toast, which was cold when it arrived (ice cold in some parts) and tasted like it had been defrosted. It certainly did not taste like it had ever been hot off the stove top.On the lunch/dinner menu, the options for vegetarians are pretty slim. We live in a condo on Bedok Reservoir Road, and every month or so we go to Wawawa to give it another go, but every time we leave disappointed, whether from the slow service, the music, the too-few menu choices, or the cold food (which could very well be the result of the slow service, who knows?) The only thing that I can recommend is the chocolate lava cake on the dessert menu, which I'm pretty sure is the only reason why I would return in the future...after eating dinner somewhere else.

Wawawa is a cozy bistro restaurant situated at Bedok Reservoir. Nearby, you can spot part of the dismantled Berlin Wall, which was donated by an avid art lover. The restaurant draws its theme from the German reunification, bearing a key message of unity and freedom. The food on its menu is reasonably priced, with large influence from the German tradition of cooking. I cannot exactly recommend you what to eat, because everything that I've tried from here tasted really great. If you are really troubled, friendly staff are willing to assist and give you their recommendations. The restaurant is pretty open, and has a really nice atmosphere in the evening. Not too noisy, not too crowded, just a little hideout from the usual urban noise.
Food is nothing special. Drinks are decently priced. Atmosphere is good. Would not recommend for dinner, but to hang out with a few drinks, why not.

rest_name: Qiang Lim Seafood Fish Head Curry
comment: I think this place deserves a 5 when I compare it to other similar eateries - zhichar stalls in coffee shop - in SG. Zhichar is a Hokkien Phrase literally meaning "cook & fry". Such stalls are aplenty in SG, offering up to 100 dishes or more. First visited this coffee shop with my family last year (May 2016) upon my brother's recommendation. Already loved it a lot then as all dishes we ordered that night were simply great.For this year's Chinese New Year Reunion Dinner, we were thinking hard where to eat and I suggested to my family to eat at Qiang Lim again. I'm glad we did! 6 super delicious dishes (please see collage) cost only $98! Very reasonable by SG's standards especially when all were so yummy.The service here is friendly and prompt which is great. The entire coffee shop is sheltered, so, no fear of getting drenched if it rains. Although there is no air-conditioning, but we didn't feel warm at all due to the well-placed multiple fans in the coffeeshop.Ample parking lots are available at this quiet Bedok South estate - a great yay for drivers! Nearest MRT stations are Tanah Merah and Bedok Stations. Just a 5 min cab ride / 15 min bus ride would get you here.Would definitely return for more.2/50 reviews for 2017 ^^
Affordable.. KBBQ at $14.90 (adult weekend lunch)Good enough meat selection & serviceTip: top up $3 to get a bowl of cheesy sauce

If you have been reading the reviews that I write, you would have realized by now that I am quite skeptical when it comes to Korean food. But once again, my beliefs have been turned around! I visited this outlet at Tampines 1 for the pretty well-known Korean barbeque buffet. I really liked the barbeque meat there! The marinated one is nice, so is the non-marinated one. There are several dipping sauces that you can choose from, and I think the meat goes best with the dark sauce with lemon in it (I don't know what exactly it is though... I just know it goes well with the meat!). But other than the barbeque meat, I think the rest aren't that fantastic. Like for instance the cooked food, the variety is quite limited and tastes very average. And although the barbeque is supposedly smoke-free, you'll still stink from the barbeque smell. Also, the floors are pretty oily and hence slippery. Honestly, I'm contemplating between a 3 or a 4-star rating, but in the end I decided on a 3, since I think there is a considerable room for improvement, like for instance making sure that the environment is more conducive and clean. Lastly, the weekend dinner is more expensive on weekends, so you may want to visit it on a weekday for better value.

Decent Korean BBQ. The range of meats was not exactly very big, Â Different cuts of pork, beef chicken, some were marinated in Bulgogi, some where without any marinate. All were pretty decent. Really liked the pork belly. You also have the lettuce to stuff your cooked meats into if you are into that. Grilling the garlic and onions in the fat that oozes out of the pork is also yummy. I am not that big a fan of Korean bbq in general, as the meats are usually marinated sweet, Hence I cannot really give this place a high rating, however there was a really really long que and everyone seemed to be having a good time, so my rating is a matter of personal preference.

address: 16 Jln Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488682 Singapore
comment: Momoya Japanese Restaurant is a fantastic place for authentic Japanese food. My recommendation is that there isn't a better place in Singapore for Japanese food, the dishes are delectable. Located in Bedok along an array of eateries Momoya Japanese Restaurant is one of the ones that stands out. It is in a tiny shop space but still comfortable. The design allows for a decent space, the tables aren't at an uncomfortably close distance to once another, neither are they far enough to be considered spacious. It generally is a comfortable place for a meal and service is decent too.The parking isn't too bad, you might have a little trouble finding one during peak hour though. They use an ERP system. There are also several dessert options you may choose from after a meal

address: 16 Jln Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488682 Singapore
comment: I've been here at least a couple of times and its been quite hit and miss for me. My first visit was considerably better than the second. I had the Ala Carte buffet and the food was pretty okay. As always, I had serving after serving of sashimi (since it was free flow). Some of the sushi and cooked food like the agedashi tofu and tempura were quite nice too.On my second visit, I was kinda disappointed that the service and food quality didnt quite match up to my previous visit. I had ordered a toasted onigiri and to my horror, they were using thai rice. Flavourless, bland and burnt. If that was anything to do by, the rest of my dinner was about just as disappointing except the sashimi.Its going to take a bit of convincing for me to go back.

address: 16 Jln Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488682 Singapore
comment: Here's where I'll get a great value of Japanese a la carte buffet because they have several items that wins me over and makes me crave for it once in a blue moon. Priced at an affordable rate given the wide spread of Japanese cuisine, there's sashimi, agemono, yakimono, donburis and noodles. What makes me walk there uncontrollably even when I try hard to resist is the mentaiko spaghetti. It has the salty flavours of both mentaiko and bacon, with a touch of cream to coat the spaghetti together with julienned onion. Also, the ume soda though of a separate charge is something I have to order. Head down on a weekday, lunch is certainly cheaper if you have the time. The spread is not any smaller than dinner and it is also cheaper on weekdays! You will really have to go on an empty stomach to order away!

address: 16 Jln Pari Burong Picardy Garden Singapore 488682 Singapore
comment: Momoya is the best place to go when you're craving Japanese food but have absolutely no idea what you want to eat. The range of dishes available is astounding, from usual dishes like Japanese curry rice to separate dishes like salmon belly to fusion foods like mentaiko spaghetti. For the buffet, you order off a menu and the dishes are served to you in adorably tiny portions so that you can eat as much as you like of your favourite sushi, sashimi or basically anything you'd like. Due to the style of preparation, the food is served hot and fresh unlike in most buffets where the food is left out. I liked the yakiniku in particular, and others are worth trying like the yuzu salmon although it did not really taste of yuzu.At $23++ for lunch, it is really quite good value for money, and I have not been disappointed by the service standard yet.

address: 311 New Upper Changi Rd #B2-10, Bedok Mall Singapore 460209 Singapore
comment: I'll admit it - I come to Canton Paradise @ Bedok Mall for one thing only, and that's for their super yummy HK style wanton noodles (soup version)!! I am such a big big fan of HK style wanton noodles that I can eat that every day whenever I was in Hong Kong in the past. #callmeawantonnoodleaddictidonotcarelolStarted coming to Canton Paradise about 2 years ago upon my hardcore foodie friend's suggestion. My 1st trip here with her was quite food-memorable - we had wanton noodles, a few plates of dim sum; our favourite being the mango prawn fritters which we ordered 2 plates in the same sitting. After that taste-buds-happy 1st trip to CP, I have been coming here about a few times a year to satisfy my cravings for wanton noodles. Thus, you can imagine how happy I was when my ex-colleagues suggested to visit Bedok Mall for our biennial get-together. I quickly seized upon the opportunity to suggest Canton Paradise as the meeting point.However, after reading another fellow yelper's tip of how great the congee is at CP (I have not tried their congee), I decided I will try congee instead of wanton noodles tonight. It was SO HARD to not order my usual wanton noodles, but, I managed to fight my impulse to order my favourite dish. I am so glad I did as the assorted congee (sliced fish, pork balls, beef slices) was really really good! It is quite hard to find good cantonese style congee in SG, so it is really awesome that I can find it here. Thanks L!The dim sum here is pretty awesome too. I will give them a 3.5-4 yelp stars. Wanton Noodles: 5 yelp stars. Service: 3 stars (they didn't clear our table after we have finished our main courses and we had to ask them to do it. Minus 1 star for this).My 4 ex-colleagues all tried the wanton noodles and loved it. Without a doubt, I would be ordering both congee and wanton noodles the next time I am here! So looking forward to it!

address: 311 New Upper Changi Rd #B2-10, Bedok Mall Singapore 460209 Singapore
comment: Great authentic Chinese food. Nice ambience. Pricy though. Needs a reservation on weekends. Lots of people. Wide selection of food to delight every palate.

address: 311 New Upper Changi Rd #B2-10, Bedok Mall Singapore 460209 Singapore
comment: Average fare but there are still some dishes you can choose to make a good meal. The porridge, yam dumplings and lotus rice Â are good. Their supposedly specialty, the black char siew, is below expectation. Often the meat is quite tough and a far cry from better ones such as Char.

Been to Mellben many times over the last 6 years (of living within 100m of it). Food has been consistently excellent. While I don't eat crab my wife tells me the Pepper Crab is to die for. Dried Chili Chicken is very good and Indonesian Curry Prawns just brilliant. Great value and friendly staff round it out.

It's my second time here and I've left happy both times. My friends and I ordered both the pepper crab and the chilli crab, along with a number of side dishes (Kai lan, sweet and sour pork, noodles, fried buns, and sweet spring rolls). The crab is very good, although I prefer the pepper crab since I don't take spice very well. The meat is generally nice and thick although there are a few points where you'll be clawing for what is fairly stringy meat. The portions are obviously more than enough. The side dishes were all average, save the noodles (thick with a brown gravy sauce and chicken - the name escapes me) which were excellent. Bring lots of tissues to clean up with afterwards since you'll want to dig in with your bare hands. Prices are reasonable. Go later in the evening when there is less traffic and you will get far faster service. All in all, a very nice meal about once a year.

This place is the worst crab bee hoon Â ever. The crab was not fresh and overdone. My suspicion was that they substituted the crab they showed us for pieces of crab they took out of the fridge somewhere and we did not get a complete crab. There was only one quarter of the body of the crab and two legs that we could count. The other dishes were equally uninspiring. Very disappointing as we expected so much better with the few reviews posted.

I've been here many times and have never been dissatisfied. The crabs are always fresh and there's a variety of flavors you can choose from. My favorites are the Black Pepper Crab and the Laksa Crab. The laksa crab comes with noodles in a clay pot and the Laksa broth is just awesome. Typical coffee shop setting, very casual and the service staff are polite and accommodating. Excellent location for family dinners .

You know the name - Mellben means crab, and boy, have they built up a reputation!The Ang Mo Kio branch now has a pretty standard hour-long wait, which could be worse if you don't get there before the line gets mad.But hey, there's this store in Pasir Ris... and it's got the same name... but why is there no queue? I was more than a little curious. So the Mellben name is splashed about on their menus and namecards, and the signature crab bee hoon is here as well. Dad was pretty convinced that we should eat, and Mum was pretty psyched about crab bee hoon too, so we put in that order, along with some homenade toufu, and a little veg to appease the little voice that called for a healthy, balanced meal.The claypot arrives, and that crab, oh that glorious crab is sitting on a pile of thick bee hoon. Oh man. We tuck in, and the soup is the first thing to hit me - this is my first Mellben experience; yes, I've never been to the one in Ang Mo Kio - and it's JUST SO TASTY. People tell you think of fishhead bee hoon, and how tasty that is, but this is a whole new level. CRAB. BEE. HOON. CRAB. guys, it's CRAB. And it's so good.The Crab is so sweet, and the soup is so crab-flavoured. It disappeared really quick, so we had to get an extra portion of soup and noodles. Because we were greedy.Have to squeeze in a little shout out to the handmade toufu - that sauce with chai por was tasty enough to make me stop eating the crab for a sec... but only a sec. Guys, we're here for CRAB.Trivia: a quick chat with one of the ladies there tells us that this is the odest Mellben operating, after the original one at Alexandra closed. Take that, Ang Mo Kio... Pasir Ris Drive 4's where it's at.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-66/67 Changi City Point Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: The bar was located next to Jolibee, just away from the main shopping block. It has both indoor air-con dining and outdoor alfresco dining. The outdoor area also has a small stage which is used for live music performances.Although it was a hot and humid day, it was quite cooling in the outdoor area with the many fans blowing above. Beware of the tall tables as they were not quite stable.
