Serving size is fine too - it's a good mixture of flavour and potency. Overall - good underlying espresso shots make for potent and well executed lattes, but skip the cappuccinos. Along with table manners, this is currently the best option for anyone in need of decent coffee in Changi Business Park.

address: 6 Changi Business Park Avenue 1 #01-30 UE BizHub East Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: And here I thought on this trip to Singapore I would have to search for a decent coffee place! No, right at my doorstep was Knead to Eat. The wonderful barista made me my favorite coffee, topped with a beautiful heart and a delicious breakfast sandwich. I'm a regular now!

address: 6 Changi Business Park Avenue 1 #01-30 UE BizHub East Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: Great coffee. Very friendly staff. Worth to find this little gem at expo.

The Thai food is good as for the rest is okay I reckon non-of you had ever sat at a place an said I will not give it a review on first glance after trying the food some of you will want to give it a positive review but it is up to you to prove me wrong

address: 58 New Upp Changi Rd Singapore 461058 Singapore
comment: Awesome and affordable Thai food. I prefer this stall as compared to the other Thai place Nakhon.Food to try chicken with basil, chicken salad and their Thai green curry.Their dessert rocks as well. Â I've tried their red ruby but I'm always asking for less coconut milk. I know... Should've gone all out with the calories.This place is affordable and I love their green chilli. It's sweet and only slightly sourish.

address: 58 New Upp Changi Rd Singapore 461058 Singapore
comment: Every now and then you come across a gem in a coffeeshop and Yummy Thai is one of them. My parents decided to bring me there for dinner and what a masterstroke it was. The food was excellent. We ordered a few things - green curry, bbq squid, phad thai and pork knuckle. The green curry was good. It had tender slices of chicken and flavourful curry gravy. The squid was fresh and grilled nicely, topped off with some really tasty black sauce. The pork knuckle was gorgeous. Crispy skin, tender meat and, best of all, they served the dishes with thei signature green chilli sauce on the side. It had that sour, spicy kick to it. Very very very nice!

address: 6 Changi Business Park Avenue 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: There are a multitude of places to choose from in this area. I was staying at the hotel nearby and thought i'd give it a try for dinner. I ordered the Gai Lan which was excellent. It has this beautiful garlic chili sauce that really makes it tasty. It was cooked perfectly. Probably one of the better ive ever had. My main dish was the boiled chicken wanton teow soup. It was beautiful as well. Not too salty, not fatty. Â Good portion of meat, veggies and noodles. It had a nice clean taste that I was in the mood for. Service was fast. Owner was very polite and hospitable. Â Im looking forward to coming back and trying their chicken rice everyone else was ordering. Can't go wrong here!

Called in the week before to make a reservation for 25-30 people and double confirmed this morning but unfortunately none of the staffs remembered. And the staffs that were on the phone requested me to speak in Chinese instead. So I had to divert my language section of the brain to converse with them in regards to the reservation (minus a star).Came here around 5.45pm. Parking was pretty hard to find as the parking space was pretty full by the time we reached there. Tried Nam Tok Neua (beef salad), BBQ chicken wings, deep fried kang kong, seafood stir-fried tang hoon (only prawns though), spicy seabass lemon soup (that tasted like tom yum), dill pattie omelette, something like satay (sorry - wasn't the person in-charged ordering), and mango sticky rice. For beverage, tried lemongrass. (Btw, the one ordered was a Thai friend)The food was served pretty fast. The meat dishes were tender and flavorful (juicy). Was not too spicy besides the fish after adding more of the lemon soup inside the fish shaped claypot style. All the dishes had unique flavors but among all the dishes I mentioned above, i like the chicken wings. It was not too oily either and it leaves a lingering after taste. Lemongrass drink was pretty decent. I felt like they put too much ice on the drink that I tasted the melted ice more than the drink itself.This place can also accommodate big groups. As my church friends and I came here around Chinese New Year period, we saw people ordering Lo Hei and mixing the ingredients together with their family members.Overall, was pretty impressed with the price too. Didn't spend more than $300 for 15 people and we also ordered two sets of the dishes. If you are around the area, do try this place out :)

Another nett priced Thai restaurant that serves great value for money food!!! I love their BBQ chicken wings.. Similar to the hawker centre ones but bigger :) the seafood pad Thai was good :) a lot of squids and small shrimps. I also tried their tom yum soup but I don't normally spicy food. But this tom yum soup was pretty decent. I liked their shrimp omelette however, it was quite oily.. Even more oily than the BBQ chicken wings. The pineapple fried rice served with Chinese dried sausage and cashew nuts was good! :) it had the wok Hei taste too! I really liked the mango sticky rice :) for $6 it's a little pricer than Jal Thai but still decent chunks of mango :) I love the lemongrass drink, it was a cooling relieve for my sore throat.

If you think that Thai cuisine is all about Tom Yam Soup, Phad Thai or Pineapple Rice, then it's time to make a trip to Spicy Thai Thai Cafe, a casual Thai style eatery in the Aljunied heartlands that serves North-Eastern Thai cuisine with some Teochew flair.The Claypot Lala Beehoon ($18) justified a visit on its own, with the succulent fresh clams, chillies and moist beehoon that soaked up the peppery broth. The addictive, vibrant flavors immediately sparked an enthusiastic response across the table that borders on mania. The Fried Lad Na, thai style deep fried hor fun, paled in comparison as the stock was slightly diluted and lacked much aromatic character. Nonetheless, the chef's deft hand in seafood is also evident in the Basil Mussels ($15), submerged in a funky, umami-laden broth enhanced with aromatic cilantro and Thai Chilli. More delicate tongues can rest eat with the BBQ Pork Collar, slices of beautifully burnished meat with a distinctive caramelized aroma. The Chicken Wings $6 for 4pcs were slicked in a delectably sticky and sweet coating but the meat was too dry. Some of the cuisine here reminded me of comfort home-cooked dishes that go superbly with a bowl of rice. The Dill Pat Omelette ($8) is a well executed puffy "chye poh neng" that comes without the radish but a special legume called cha om (or English Cattle) that is grown in Thailand. For a unique twist, try the Water Fry egg, a pool of tasty and tender scrambled eggs studded with occasion chopped chillis, spring onions and served with Thai Style Crispy Sun dried fish ($12), which disguised sneakily as the brown conch-like decoration at the corner. Other tasty gear on offer includes the fish cakes and prawn cakes ($2 each) Looking like the tempura vegetables, the Deep Fried Kangkong ($10) would probably be a great snack to go with beer or simply with the special thai sauce--a nutty, mildly spiced concoction with mixed with minced pork. These were not too greasy but I prefer still prefer stir-fry vegetables because the greens were zapped of its original taste after a dip in the high-temperature oil.The real treat here is THE FISH. To ensure that the spicy, complex lemon broth stays piping hot till you even finish your desserts, the owner goes the extra mile to serve the Thai Walking Cat Fish ($28) on charcoal , an authentic way of maintaining the heat and quality. With fresh meat of melting texture, this dish kills two birds with one stone as one can skip the Tom Yam Soup and slurp down the hellaciously hot soup to the very last drop. Something a little more extravagant would be the Red Emperor Fish Snapper (seasonal price) that is steamed and sprinkled with garlic, chilli's and slices of lime. This second fish of the night is as much an achievement as the previous catfish, or perhaps even better as the flavours are sharp and seasoning is bang on. Other desserts include Thai Red Ruby ($3.50) Lemon Grass Jelly with Aloe Vera Cubes and Calamansi ($2.50)The desserts were those usual suspects that one would rattle off from a typical Thai menu but they were above pedestrian quality. My favourite was the Tapioca in Coconut Milk ($3.50) . These starchy roots were as soft as sweet potatoes and the warm temperature of coconut milk heightened the natural sweetness--a welcome change from the usual cold, stodgy version. The Sticky Glutinous Rice with Mango ($6) took me by surprise too, with the rice yielded a perfect texture.Given such an extensive menu of more than 50 items, I am really impressed that the chef can manage to maintain such a stellar quality across most of the dishes here. Though I did not manage to try my favourite Tom Yum Soup or Papaya Salad this time round, I was very satisfied with the robustness of the herbs and spices here. With a constantly changing menu and very reasonable prices, this is definitely another great place for Thai food

The proprietor has switched to commercial fish paste--no longer the squishier housemade parang (wolf herring) fish paste of old. But the modern take is snappier, less fishy but also less sweet. The yam nuts have the legacy texture. The highlight of the meal for me were the steamed flower Lala (clams).A very strong example of Yong Tau Foo and other steamed items

Yong Tau Fu cravings? Try Stephen's Hakka Yong Tau Fu located in Katong. I have been eating Yong Tau Fu created by this family for almost 40 years. Stephen apprenticed with his father, and now his daughter is apprenticing with Stephen. Getting Yong Tau Fu here is a family tradition and on our Favorite Foods in Singapore List.What makes this place so very special? Let's begin with the most amazing red sauce and chili sauce. The red sauce is my favorite since childhood since I couldn't eat spices when I was younger. Now, they are both delicious to me. It is rare that I rave about a condiment, but these sauces are pretty special.Next, the fish paste is fine, firm and flavorful. It pairs well with the delicious variety of bases: bitter gourd, eggplant, medium firm tofu, fried tofu, red and green chillies. They also have little fish balls. They also have my favorite white is a fish paste roll wrapped in tofu skin. Yong Tau Fu is usually fried, then cooked longer in a robust broth. Sometimes, I enjoy eating the wrapped fish paste just after it is fried. I remember hanging around the wok when I was young and eating these as a snack or appetizer.After it simmers in broth, the Yong Tau Fu is pretty good, too. I love the flavor of the slightly wilted cilantro cooked by the steam from the broth. I love mixing the red sauce in the broth for a delicious red soup. Hmmm. I wish I could get me some right now.If you are lucky, they have fish roe. Wow! Roe is amazing with the red sauce. Okay, if you get my drift, I love the red sauce so much that I can almost eat it with anything. Other specialties at Goldhill Restaurant are the steamed Pomfret, and the small stir fried clams. These 2 dishes do not carry-out well. However, the Yong Tau Fu develops beautifully when you take it home to enjoy in your own home. A toast to Stephen and his family who brought be back down through memory lane from the first bite to the last sip of broth mingled with that red sauce.

Not my first time here but definitely my first time reviewing this place. It's so quaint, authentic and the food is great. I've always been here on the weekends only and each time the food quality is consistently good. A very nice experience if you've never had traditional Hakka food. There is a very limited menu but I've tried everything on it and it's all amazing food. Highly recommend trying at least once!

If you are health conscious and want good & fresh YTF, I highly recommend this eatery. The decor is nothing to shout at, but the YTF are all hand-Made.... Very fresh. No carbs are served here ......just very fresh YTF, steamed fish. To me, this YTF Â is SG's best

This quaint old place along Changi Road is a real throwback to the olden days and for the younger crowd, feels a bit like you've travelled up to Malaysia for a meal. It was pretty crowded when we were there for lunch on a weekday, so we sat outside along the five-foot way, and sipped our Water Chestnut drink cooled with ice from a little bucket, kopitiam style.The main draw here is the awesome Hakka Yong Tau Foo, but the place is also famous for its seafood - the Yu Sheng (raw fish) was great - and this is coming from someone who doesn't like sashimi - and the La La (shellfish) was quite good as well. The quintessentially Hakka dish of Abacus Beads, Yam and Tapioca topped with dried shrimp was very respectable.If you've never had the chance to try Hakka cuisine, this is a great way to get a taste of the culture, but be warned that parking along Changi Road is not the easiest, especially on weekends!

address: 511 Guillemard Rd #01-52 Grandlink Square Singapore 399849 Singapore
comment: Finally amazing Filipino lechon here in Singapore! Crispy and delicious! Served with traditional gravy. The rice was nice and soft too. Gotta have it with rice. The lechon sinigang was delicious and served in our own pot which is great! The owner is really nice and friendly. We went on a weeknight at 6 pm.

address: 50 East Coast Rd Ste 01-80 Singapore 428769 Singapore
comment: I have to admit that this post is slightly biased because the owners were so hospitable, but hopefully with the combined reviews from others, you'd believe my words.My first real foray into Filipino food and I'm hooked. Prices are reasonable and the food has been slightly tweaked to suit local tastes, such as use of pork slices instead of pig's ear. For the more conservative Chinese, there are many aspects of Filipino cuisine that bear similarities to Chinese cuisine. Mee dang Hoon for example was very much like fried beehoon and fried danghoon, and their fried roast pork was simply heavenly. It was the last dish and we were already full and bursting when it arrived, and yet we had to put it into our mouths. I don't know how to spell most of the food we had since someone else ordered and I simply remembered it by sound, but they were mostly recommendations from the owner anyway. The spring rolls were also incredibly crispy, filled with mince meat and seeming like a more crispy version of Ngoh Hiang. Sisig is also another must-try, a hotplate meat dish with egg and lime. It's a pity we never got to try the desserts as we were simply stuffed, but the little fussy 8 year old has already loudly proclaimed that he wants to go back next Sunday so I might have another shot at ordering those desserts. Until then, we would have to coax our helper into attempting to recreate as closely as possible some of these amazing dishes.

address: 50 East Coast Rd Ste 01-80 Singapore 428769 Singapore
comment: Located on the first floor of Roxy Square, Kusina de Pinoy is the best Filipino I've tried in Singapore. In my opinion, even better than Gerry's Grill in Orchard or any of the Philippine stalls in Lucky Plaza. Strong words, I know, but hear me out. I judge the quality of a Filipino restaurant based on two dishes: Pork Sinigang and Chicken Adobo. Pork Sinigang is a tamarind based soup filled with pork. For locals, think of it as the Filipino version of Bak Kut Teh. As opposed to the peppery taste we all know and love, Sinigang is most known for its distinct sour taste. Kusina de Pinoy's Sinigang is particularly sour, which makes it downright Amazing! Yes, the more sour it is, the better (my personal opinion). I find the Sinigang served at other Philippine establishments lacks this sour umph. Â The reasons for this are two-fold: (i) there is too much water in the dish and is thus diluted or (ii) the chef has scrimped on the sinigang mix. To top it off, the sinigang had a healthy serving of tomatoes, bok choy, onion, and daikon radish. My only wish was that there was a healthier serving of pork and/ or the the use of pork spare ribs! If you love Bak Kut Teh, you should definitely try this dish. Â The Adobo Rice was also good. It's a must try if you love garlic rice. Personally, I thought there was too much garlic rice. Crazy to say, when Filipinos, love rice! Overall, I'm huge fan of Kusina de Pinoy. As a Filipino myself, I can attest to its quality and authenticity. This is my go to Filipino restaurant not only in Katong, but in all of Singapore.

address: 50 East Coast Rd Ste 01-80 Singapore 428769 Singapore
comment: Lovely Filipino food! I had some new Filipino colleagues drag me here one weekend and boy did we have a good time! I had the chicken sisig which was truly delectable. The ambiance was loud and messy, but it was still very comfortable and homely. Being situated in the east you get a lot of east siders. I just love this restaurant and am a frequenter now. They might even be sick of my face! It is right next to my church so every Sunday they know to expect me. It is an open air, within the mall itself. The service was polite and well mannered. You could tell that they were well trained.The food - excellent!

address: 866A Tampines Street 83 #02-03, Tampines Central Community Complex Singapore 521866 Singapore
comment: 2ND VISIT HERE FOOD: EXCELLENTIts my second time back & i ordered takeaway this time and the food is still so good!! I ordered Roasted Chicken Rice (ç§é¸¡é¥­) for my grandmother & she loved it. She gave me a few pieces of chicken because she said there was so much of it HAHA & its still as tender as tge first time i went with MORE SKIN HAHA For myself, i tried their Roasted Pork Belly Noodles (ç§èé¢) & its was sooo delightful!! Despite taking away, after 10 min of walking home the pork belly was still so nice & crispy plus the proportion was bountiful (see pictures!!!). The gravy was delightful & even though the pork belly was soaked in sauce it was STILL CRISPY that is definitely some good pork belly slices + the noodles was cue & really delicious i finished every drop. DEFINITELY EATING THAT AGAIN!PRICE: CHEAP For $3.30 & the proportion + standard i got it was AMAZING even my grandmother was amazed so its a definitely MUST TRY. WAITING TIME: QUICK The waiting time was still about 1-2 minutes even though i ordered 2 portions!! Really fast & nice service by the staff! OVERALL: DELIGHTFUL A great 2nd try at this place & i will be coming back for more! Its a pity that the place is quite deserted because not many people come to community centres to eat but BOY was the food good. THUMBS UP!

address: 699 East Coast Road, Singapore Singapore 459061 Singapore
comment: Adriatic cuisine n00bs + good reviews on Yelp = must try!If you're currently sitting in the restaurant and never tried Adriatic cuisine before, then head over to the meats and grill section of your menu and choose from there. Note that the dishes are pretty heavy, so if you're not too hungry you'll be fine with just a main.For appetizers, we started with something familiar- a Caprese salad. This was amazingly good. The fresh mozzarella was delightful, and it went well with the briny kalamata olives, fresh tomatoes, and fresh basil.I ordered the pujena pljeskavica (don't ask me how to pronounce it) which is basically a spiced meat patty. This particular variation is the pimped out version of one of the other menu items (can't remember which one) as it's stuffed with cheese. YUMZ.I sampled the rosemary chicken, and I really liked it because the rosemary flavour was very strong. It also came with some good potato wedges.This place has been in Siglap for years, and the cosy decor really gives off a great neighbourhood vibe. We can't wait to return!

address: 699 East Coast Road, Singapore Singapore 459061 Singapore
comment: A friend introduced me here and it took me at least 4 months before trying it out for myself. She warned me that it will be more difficult to get here by bus/train and encouraged me to drive here instead. After deciding where to eat/snack and drink, and since I am driving, decided to suggest this place to my friends. When we came, I was surprised that it wasn't crowded as I had this sorta implanted logic "bars = packed on weekends" especially around 8. Was given the choice - outdoors/indoors or smoking/non-smoking. My friends and I were more mesmerized with the interior design so without much hesitations, we asked to be seated indoors. We were ushered to a small table with three chairs but one of my friends were eyeing on the couch for a larger crowd. We were also told to go up to the bar area to order our foods. Since my friends were taking awhile before making a firm decision, the server came to serve us instead.The first question she approached us "Are you guys above 18?" We literally laughed out loud especially when two of us ordered a Cider each and another friend ordered a 1/4 of red wine. But the server was smiley throughout the process of delivering our drinks and pizza. For the pizza, I ordered Pizza Bianca con Formaggi. It has two types of cheese -mozzarella and parmesan. It was a thin pizza and wasn't too thick on the flavor so it was a good choice especially with cider. Love the chewiness for the cheese itself and the crispiness of the pizza base.I ordered Kopparberg Strawberry & Lime Cider - 4.5% alcoholic content (the menu put it as 4.0%). I am always into fruity ciders or white wine and since I was driving, the cider sounds much better. It arrived with a cup of ice and bottle with left over cider on the side. It's more like drinking a soft drink rather than cider. I love it. I even tried the elderberry and lime one and I love both.Stayed there for about 2 hours but instead of people coming here, the customers left table by table and the three of us were the last one to leave. We managed to talk to one of the servers and she told us that she was about 18 years of age and was surprised when we told her that we are 7-9 years older than her. Anyways, she is a friendly waitress and even recommended the meat dishes on our next visit. Will definitely pop-by here soon. Parking wise, do Siglap center.

address: 699 East Coast Road, Singapore Singapore 459061 Singapore
comment: Recently I had some friends who moved to Singapore from Croatia and this was the 1st cafe that they told me I had to try. Their menu is pretty impressive and the food is just amazing. No spoilers here, but if you haven't try Adriatic cuisine, you have to give this place a go. p.s. I had the Chef make me something special from the kitchen too!

address: 699 East Coast Road, Singapore Singapore 459061 Singapore
comment: At Next Door Cafe & Taverna, it is made simple. As they like to say, its not about wine and food critics, it is for everyday people. Situated at Siglap they pride themselves as a warm and cosy corner, a fantastic place to simply relax and enjoy a meal with a couple of drinks.They offer offer Adritic cuisines such as authentic pizzas, homemade pastas, a wide range of appetizers, salads, pates and cheese, a selection of grilled meats, and fresh Mediterranean seasonal fish (thurs. - sun. only). The coffee is pretty good as well, and the beer definitely 2 thumbs up. Opening Hours: Mon - Sun 12-2pm, 6pm-midnight

address: 699 East Coast Road, Singapore Singapore 459061 Singapore
comment: A fantastic, casual spot in the East with an impressive list of beers and an Adriatic food menu, this is a favourite of mine for lazy Sundays in the neighbourhood. They offer pizzas and pastas, but the real highlight here is their extensive selection of meat dishes. Sausages, skewers, chicken... all of which is deliciously spiced. It may be a good idea to get the Mixed Grill to have a little taste of everything, but be forewarned, they say it's good for two but I felt we could have fed three or four with our feast!Good place to hang out, especially if you're in a slightly carnivorous mood.

address: 699 East Coast Road, Singapore Singapore 459061 Singapore
comment: Simple and good food served in a cozy and friendly atmosphere. Â Everyone was happy at my table, including my teenage children. Â The portions, presentation and freshness of the food show care for the customer. Â Nice selection of drinks in a local pub-like atmosphere. Â They could use one or two more employees as their staff are rushed off their feet.

It's official- I have a Maki-San addiction! (Or if I'm in denial... I am fully committed to Maki-San!)I have yet to visit the original outlet in Dhoby Ghaut, but their third outlet it Katong suits me just fine. They loosely refer to themselves as "the Subway of sushi", and it's a totally fitting description. Sushi snobs, this place isn't for you.The fun part about this place is you get to choose what goes in your roll! There are so many ingredients to choose from, some traditionally Japanese, others, truly local (bak kwa or smoked duck, anyone?) I have yet to try their salads, as I have way too much fun playing around with all the sushi combos I can make!If for some reason I go missing in Singapore, please visit Maki-San first. I'll most likely be chomping down on a tempura-filled mega-san roll.

Finally .... yes, I finally tried Maki San after (1) seeing other Yelper/s posts on Maki San (2) passing by the outlet at i12 many many times, but always promising myself I'll try it another time lol (3) receiving the mail-dropped flyer from maki-san informing us that they now deliver Island-wide. I'll make this short as many other reviewers have already reviewed it. I love it that I'm able to choose what goes into my sushi - it's really FUN!! The sushi came in a very nice lovely box that I was so tempted to bring it home with me #vanisahoarder I didn't bring it back after all. #butiwasverytemptedtoMy sushi was really yummy! The whole dining experience was ok. The design of the eatery was functional with some cute wacky wall posters depicting Crazy & funny Sushi art! I guess people are here for the food - nutritious, delicious sushi and not so much for the comfort. I will definitely be coming by to eat again, or I'll order and get them to deliver to me.

Maki-San has arrived in Katong. Yes! Â Customizable sushi at a colourful, fun loving store manned by friendly and smiling staff. Â By the way, since this is customizable sushi, if you order the wrong thing, you have no one to blame but yourself! :D Ordering is a little daunting at first, but once you get it, it's simple enough. Just pick up the red pen and paper (order menu) and tick away. If you need help, there is at least one staff manning the order booth -- don't be shy. Available Sizes: Little San or Mega San --- Choose the Mega-San, you'll thank me laterWrap: Traditional Nori (Seaweed); Crepe (Egg Wrap); --- I'm a traditionalist, Seaweed all the way. Essentials/toppings (3 choices for Little San and 5 for Megan San): Ebiko (Prawn Roe), Kani Stick (Crab Stick), Roasted Mushroom, Steamed Ebi (Prawn), Tamagoyaki (Japanese Omelette), Â Tempura Enoki Mushroom -- These ingredients are all great.Sprinkles: Tempura Crunch -- if you want your sushi crunchy and Japanese tasting, choose this!House Sauces: This is the most important selection of the lot. One false move, and you won't like what you've ordered. I've been to this store twice now and the Chilli Crab has never failed me. Kind of gives the sushi that oh so Beautiful Singapore taste. Specials: Salmon Sashimi -- This afterall is a pseudo Sushi restaurant, so Sashimi Salmon all the way. You can come to Maki-San over and over again and you will never tire of it because of the huge selection of ingredients. It is a Sushi Place, but when it is all said and done, you'll never feel like you ate sushi, but rather a food concoction of your own imagination. The store is cute, albeit on the small side. The packaging is jaw-droppingly beautiful -- as a business person, I wonder what the margins on this business are with this huge fixed cost. I almost feel bad, leaving the box after my meal. In all, just a truly wonderful concept. If I had any constructive criticism, it's that the meal is not very filling (even with the Mega-San). Â I guess that is a testament at how good this place is. Fortunately, its only SGD9.90 an order, so if your complaining like me, do your self a favor and just order another one. :-)

Thanks to Michelle! I have another Japanese cafe to go to. I only knew about this cafe when I saw the check ins and reviews from a few Yelpers in my list and that caught my attention. Finally, my first visit of that place came and I was looking so forward to trying the sushi. I was not disappointed at all! The quality of the seaweed and rice is very good, and the best thing? I get to choose my own ingredients! There are more than 30 ingredients for you to choose from, even the famous Chinese "Bwa Kwa" (BBQ pork) is available. I picked a few of my choices and then the nice staff cut the whole row of sushi into smaller ones. The sushi is then presented into a very pretty box which I kept it as a momento. Took my first bite of it and I was in heaven (literally of course), it's pretty good as its fresh and has good favour among the ingredients. Combining them together, I got myself a good sushi roll. I will definitely return for more. The cafe isn't big so don't be surprised if the place is filled during peak hours but trust me it's worth it especially if you are a Sushi lover. :)

I love love love makisan, and when they opened up closer to home - I loved it even more! It gives me the option of going healthy with brown rice and deciding what I want to put in my body for the day. Not to mention, BOOST is just beside this Makisan! So that's a healthy lunch for you. I would recommend the Tempura Enoki Mushrooms with Paprika Seasoning to anyone - it's so sinful, but oh so yummy!
Tastey...but TINY portions. Seriously, a $10 salad looks like a starter course for a 5 course meal. Can't say I see (or taste!) the value.

Little packages of delicious savory goodness wrapped in fragrant pandan leaves. They are called dumplings here, which can be confusing for non locals. Â They are steamed sticky rice packages filled with savory, sweet mixture. Â The nonya small comes with 10 small dumplings in a box. Â $12. The smaller sized dumplings are great for snacking. You're going to want to pop a few at a time. The larger ones are more meal sized. Not as fun for snacking. Get them in the morning while they are still freshly steams.

The five-star ratings must be from family members. I find the dumplings to be too sweet. I had to throw away all the kuehs that I bought because they use artificial sugar to sweeten the kuehs. The fake sugar taste was just horrible. Never come back again, ever.

Being a rather small eater, I can never finish 1 Bak Chang by myself as I find it too much to handle with the glutinous rice and filling. So, I love the mini Chang (dumplings) at Kim Choo so that I am not overwhelmed. They do have many different type of changs too but usually the hot favorite is the nonya chang. Â The nonya chang you find here are fully packed with the sweet meat fillings. The mini changs come in a box of 20s. Good snackable size for the rest of the family. Aside from bak chengs, they also dish out pretty good nonya kuehs and chinese goodies for sale.

I love Kim Choo's Bak Chang rice dumplings but I'm not here to talk about them today. Instead, I want to share with you my favorite item here -- Ang ku kueh! They are small sweet kuehs with a red glutinous outer layer and either bean or peanut fillings inside. It's quite a secret that Kim Choo makes very good Ang ku kuehs -- the best in Singapore IMO! Very thin and soft skin and fillings that are not overly sweet. Remember to come early for some, they make a limited number everyday and sell out quickly.

Along the stretch of shophouse, the family restaurant looked rather out of place when it was surrounded by cafes such as Cedele, Dutch Colony Coffee Co. and Bird Bird. The place looked quite old and we were seated right at the back where one barely felt the aircon. Menu was a simple 1 piece of sheet, similar to most zhi char places. We started with drinks such as Homemade Chin Chow èªå¶ä»èæ°´ ($2.00), Ice lemon Tea èªå¶æ æª¬è¼ ($2.00), and Plum Juice. I had plum juice which was quite refreshing and cool me down after my long walk from the MRT station.Fish Maw Crab Meat Soup é±¼èè¹èç¾¹ ($14/$20/$30) The soup was rich and thick with umami taste, filled with lots of ingredients. Penang Fried Kway Teow æ§åçææ¡ ($5.50) The noodle was well fried with distinct flavours.Curry Fish Head åå©é±¼å¤´ ($20/$26/$34)The curry was rich and creamy without too spicy. The meat was firm and chunky. Ayam Buah Keluak é»æé¸¡ ($13/$20/$26)The chicken was quite tender and gravy was rich without too spicy. However I felt that the taste of Buah Keluak inside the nut was not too distinct as it mashed into a paste with other ingredients, tasting more like fish cake.Chicken Prawn Paste è¾é±é¸¡ ($12/$15/$22) This dish was the hot favourite of the meal that we ordered a second serving. Best had it while it was still hot and juicy. One can taste the prawn paste quite distinct without too salty.Beef with Black Pepper Sauce é»è¡æ¤çè ($12/$18/$24) The sliced beef was quite tender and melt in the mouth.Broccoli with Crab Meat è¹èè¥¿å°è± ($13/$18/$24) For one who did not really eat vegetables, I really like this dish. The broccoli was soft. Topped with the crab meat rich sauce, it kind of reminded me of creamed broccoli.Foo Young Omelette èºèè ($9/$13/$16) I like that there was a lot of different ingredients in the fried egg.We ended the meal with desserts such as Sago with Gula Melaka, Longan Tofu, and Cendol. The Sago with Gula Melaka was well made as it was not too sweet with the sago pudding soft and melt in the mouth. The cendol was the hot favourite. Besides not too sweet while been rich and creamy, the ice was shaved just right without been too rough and the green jelly strips retained its texture without turning frozen as was the case of most cendol stalls faced when using factory made jelly strips.Although I felt at the beginning of the meal, it was quite cold for me at the end of the meal. Surprisely the restaurant was packed for a weekday nite.

This restaurant is a staple of those who frequent the Frankel Estate area. We practically grew up on the food from this restaurant, all the way from back when it was operating as a cafe inside Jackie's Bowl. Zhi-char prices in an air-conditioned setting. The Nasi Lemak is well recommended. My favorite is the Seafood Crispy Noodle. My kids love the honey pork ribs and the sweet and sour fish. The Fish Head Curry is also pretty good. This place can get really crowded at dinner time on weekends and any groups larger than 4 should call ahead to reserve a table.

Different Taste is a family favourite and is my family's go-to place for celebrating occasions like birthdays or anniversaries. While the place itself is unassuming in ambience or appearance, the food is usually worth a return visit.Among our favourites include the unshelled cereal prawns, prawn paste chicken, foo yong omelette, curry fish head and the broccoli with braised mushroom. The honeydew sago is also worth a try if you have any space left in your tummy after everything. If you're coming in a small group, you might want to consider having the nasi lemak set alone instead. Can get crowded on weekends so do make a reservation in advance.

address: 180 Bedok Reservoir Rd, Eunos Community Club Singapore 479220 Singapore
comment: Was trying to find a good low key Indian place in the Bedok reservoir area, and found this on Yelp (with way too few reviews). Btw locating it can be quite confusing as "180 Bedok reservoir road" is nestled among the 600s hdb blocks - it's actually just at Eunos community club! On top of my usual butter chicken and naan combo I tried chicken Mughlai, which is chicken cooked in a cashew paste and it was amazing - fragrant tangy nutty taste that's a little spicy and not too cloyingly sweet like how butter chicken can sometimes get (not sure about the one from here though have to come back another time). The chicken also had the distinct flavour of Taandori roast. I also tried Taandori parota which seems like a Taandori grilled version of Prata but slightly thicker - interesting but I have to say naan always goes best with the chicken dishes haha. Atmosphere is great with air con, clean environment and pretty quiet (on a weekday night). The menu was filled with many dishes I've never tried and I had to Google so many of them to get an idea of what was it exactly. Feels like traveling in my own country and I definitely need to be more adventurous in Indian food - Velus has definitely given me incentive for that !

address: 180 Bedok Reservoir Rd, Eunos Community Club Singapore 479220 Singapore
comment: Taken here by local colleges and good thing we got in early as lunchtime rush meant soon no tables were available inside, so if they take lunch time bookings, I would highly recommend getting a reservation.I ended up getting one of the most expensive meals on the menu - the Pomfret meal. This sucker was super spicy and so I experienced crying eyes and a runny nose due to the chillies, and the server took pity on me and switched out my curry (I had unknowingly chosen the more spicy options). My pomfret was a little bit overcooked and dry + too oily, which sorta sucked, cause its a small fish to begin with. But the food was plentiful and everything else was really tasty and heart-warming. I also got Tea Tarik, which was awesome and also helped cool down my spice levels. I also tried two other meals that my colleagues got - the Dal Tadka was nice, but didn't like the Chicken tikka masala that much. This is a South Indian place, so for my money, I would stick to that regional specialties.

address: 180 Bedok Reservoir Rd, Eunos Community Club Singapore 479220 Singapore
comment: Once or if we're lucky, twice every year we get to fly to the Food Paradise that is Singapore. This is one of our "go to" food centres when we're in Singapore because of it's proximity to our lodging with family.It was my Uncle's shout but not by my own choice. There's a bit of an unspoken tradition within our family in Singapore, in that everyone will always try to shout the other person's meal. With Dad being one of 14 children to his parents, there is certainly a rush to pay the bill, when it gets near the end of the meal and at times, there can be a bit of jostling between cousins, uncles and aunties to take care of the payment. Sometime I even go to the extreme where I'll pretend to go to the restrooms and sneakily pay before anyone else has had the chance.As it turns out my uncle insisted that he pay and we got great value for money with the Fish Head Curry, Butter Chicken, Rogan Josh, Garlic Naan and a Mutton Biryani.I really enjoyed it all with a special mention to the Rogan Josh and Garlic Naan which was crispy but doughy and garlicky.Fish Head Curry can tend to be sour, which my girlfriend doesn't like but I quite like it and it's better served with rice but I prefer naan.

address: Blk 18 Bedok South Rd 18 Brewcoffee Singapore 460018 Singapore
comment: I'm so glad this opened. This is serious hawker food! From the presentation, you can see that they really really care-- AND YOU CAN TASTE IT! Best seafood bak chor mee, and it is 2 blocks away from my home!! WHOOOHOO!

address: Blk 18 Bedok South Rd 18 Brewcoffee Singapore 460018 Singapore
comment: This is a seafood based bak Chor noodle. Overall it have the taste of an expensive seafood noodle . It has all the ingredients to make the noodle taste great but strangely not satisfying.

address: Blk 86 Bedok North Street 4 #01-165 Singapore 460086 Singapore
comment: I remember the days when hokkien mee used to be wrapped in opeh leaf and served. These leaves doesn't do much keeping the broth in, but they do add a certain flavor to the food.One of the best seafood horfun around. Great wok-fried flavor, with a very sweet flavorful broth. Wrapped it in a leaf and serve. Yummmmm....The other signature dish is their shrimp roll. There is a great texture to these as they have a generous amount of water chestnuts, so that provided the crunch and sweetness. Location is a little far side of east. Will be back to try other dishes.

address: 60 Changi Boulevard Changi Airport Terminal 1 Departure Hall Singapore 419712 Singapore
comment: Located in the first basement level at MBS, close to the SW entrance, down the first escalator. This hosts a variety of cuisines, all at reasonable prices.I opted for the Italian Seafood Marinara ($7.80) which was a decent-sized portion of pasta with squid, mussels and prawns in a delicious tomato sauce. Overall, very good value for money at a place that you would expect mains to be in the $10+ price range. However, the mussels were terrible - rubbery, overcooked and probably not fresh.Props for the cute paging system, and the other options available. If you are in the MBS area, this is worth checking out.

address: 60 Changi Boulevard Changi Airport Terminal 1 Departure Hall Singapore 419712 Singapore
comment: We were craving nasi lemak and decided to give this place a try. Â We got the Special Nasi Lemak with the fried chicken and it was so impressive! Â The coconut rice was moist enough and very flavorful. Â The chicken wasn't too dry either. Â We paired the meal with some bandung (rose milk tea), which beats the canned version any day!

address: 60 Changi Boulevard Changi Airport Terminal 1 Departure Hall Singapore 419712 Singapore
comment: Considering the prices of some of the restaurants at Bayfront, this is actually a pretty, in fact an incredibly, cheap option. It is actually more of a food court than a restaurant, namely because you can't order all your meals at one point (which is actually really annoying - I had to go to three different counters to get what I want, and only one of them sold water). However the servings are pretty generous (considering), and the food quite appetising. Mind you, to does get pretty crowded, and the staff can be a bit overzealous (and absent minded - one almost forgot to return my VISA card, that is until I reminded her). Still, a great place to get a decent priced feed.

address: 60 Changi Boulevard Changi Airport Terminal 1 Departure Hall Singapore 419712 Singapore
comment: This food section at the other end of Terminal One is quieter than the main food hall in the middle area. This is where the Cactus Garden is located one level up and where Burger King is. I like 1983 - A Taste of Nanyang for a quick bite or snack before boarding the plane. It is also where you can get local style coffee and tea. Both teh (tea) and kopi (coffee) are good, strong and sweet, which is how I like my beverage to be. Food wise, it is very average. The nasi lemak comes with a sad looking piece of fried chicken, so unlike the version at Marina Bay Sands Shoppes. It is really something to be ordered only if you are desperately hungry or if you just want nasi lemak when inside the terminal. The soft boiled eggs and kaya toast are a better option though the toast gets cold very quickly.Mee siam and mee rebus are also not to die for. I guess that leaves the local coffee and tea the safest bet for ordering. Then again, Starbucks is just next to it, so you could always get your caffeine fix there too.

This is a good and well set up Chinese restaurant, there food serve is fresh and cook to perfection. I can taste the crispy prawn outside and fresh and soft prawn inside. The duck have is not too fatty and just right for me the drum stick is so juicy and sweet.

Great Chinese restaurant, the food is using high quality ingredients and prepared magnificently with care. It results in food that is familiar yet new. The roasted herbal duck is fresh, very juicy, and tender. The soup is very delicious to the last spoon. The pork belly is melt-in-your-mouth fiesta. Should try for anyone.

address: 4 Changi Business Park Avenue 1 #03-11 UE Bizhub East Singapore 486016 Singapore
comment: Service good. Friendly and accommodating staff. French Fries were delicious. My friends ordered the Singapore Sling. Wasn't on the menu but they made it. Nice place to talk story and relax. A/C was on high. They also have an Outdoor area (warm) and a pool table.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close, Downtown East #01-21 Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: In the midst of all the commercial crap, Basil Inn is a breath of fresh air! The food is good, prices are even better and it's family owned and has such a nice small cafe ambiance - I truly, truly, truly love this place! And I'll explain why....What I Love: The menu is comprehensive, and in Singapore, it's really hard to get authentic and good Thai food. You really can't consider Thai Express Thai Food, so there's really a lack of good Thai food in Singapore. The Basil Inn's food is authentic as the chefs are Thai, the portions are great, and they'll tweak it to your preference - if you want more or less chili. Have to try their Som Tum, Pat Thai, and their Mango Salad. They have food from the North too - and their claypots, Tom Yum & Tom Kha Gai are pretty great too. I usually have their Thai Iced Tea, Thai Coconut and Mango Sticky Rice for dessert. Prices are really affordable - and every thing's about $5-$8ish. What I also love is that it's a family owned business - so everyone chips in, and it's nice to have such establishments in Singapore - as opposed to all the commercial stuff we see around all the time.What I Don't Love: Absolutely nothing!! ;D

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close, Downtown East #01-21 Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: Not that fantastic as claimed by others. Seriously, they should get more help, obviously lacking manpower.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close, Downtown East #01-21 Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: Authentic Thai food with great customers service. Love this precious restaurant. Give it a try.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Close, Downtown East #01-21 Singapore 519599 Singapore
comment: Basil Inn is a really nice surprise in the middle of touristy Downtown East - I mean honestly Downtown East is the kind of place that you would expect to find a huge MacDonalds, and loads of other child popular but mediocre chains around. And it is in fact just as you expect in reality! With the exception of a few places such as The Basil Inn that serves authentic Thai food at affordable prices. Â The portions are however tiny, so do order more than you usually would - the up side however is that you get to order a greater variety of food to try.The Tom Yum soup here is incredibly spicy and sour - I usually only survive around 2 or 3 spoons of the soup since I can't take very spicy, but it is sooo tasty you have to try it! Â The phad thai is also superb - fried to perfection and a little dry, it really reminded me of the phad thai I had on the streets in bangkok. Another great dish is the stir fried pork mince and beans - so fragrant, but beware it also packs a spicy punch! Â The servers will be able to recommend you the dishes that aren't so spicy, so do ask for their recommendations!

The tastes here took me back to China. Only this time, it was a cleaner china with better ingredients.If you have ever lived in China you would know that Chinese food has a distinct flavour, or perhaps character, that distinguishes it from duplication outside of the motherland. Perhaps, if you lived in central China its the recycled and refined chilli oil, or, if you lived in Guangdong, it could be the muddy taste of farmed fish, the the heavy aromas of China's baking powder, or perhaps even the omnipresence of MSG (though even in Singapore that is everywhere).At ä¾å§å®¶ the tastes felt authentic even without all the things we'd expect being in it. However, it has to be noted that the service was very much unlike that in China. A guy who I assume is a boss type character made sure I was happy with what I was eating, a beer lady kept my glass filled and I was even given peanuts to accompany my beer!Anyway, when my friends from overseas visit me, this will definitely be a part of the itinerary.

Spring Ever Food Court is a neighbourhood kopitiam at Bedok South Avenue 3. I frequent here a lot, having just lived down the road, its extremely convenient. If you are hard up about cleanliness than buying back is a great option, which is what I like to do. My favourite here would have to be the chicken chop which is obviously found at the western store, this is only about $6. The Hainanese Chicken Rice here is fantastic! Who would have known that a $2.50 meal could taste so good, this also is one of my favourites. Some of the other stores include, zi char, kway chap, Indian, Muslim, and your economical rice store.The tables are set well, there is ample space between each, the upkeep of cleanliness is as much as you can expect from a food court, although they do have this disgusting open area to wash the dirty dishes. They include several LCD tvs telecasting local shows and live sports games.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Get there early they get crowded fast. I would have to say hands down they have certainly the best Humus in Singapore and maybe the World. All the food is great and prices reasonable for the great quality of the food. If you're in Singapore it's a must stop. Â I'd give it 7 stars.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: This was a frequent go-to place for lunch for many of my coworkers. Â It's conveniently located in the Bedok area close to the airport. Â Spize is easily spotted in this hawker center area with its orange tables which is very different than the others in the area. Â They serve an eclectic array of both eastern and western dishes so if you're sick of eating the singaporean plates you can easily order a steak or burger! Â If you are like me and find that Asian restaurants just don't serve drinks large enough to quench your thirst, Spize has an upsize option. Â Finally a mug that has the capacity to satisfy my thirst! Â Their menus are comprehensive enough that you can eat here every few days while staying within a reasonable budget. Â Keep in mind that since it's still a hawker stand, it can get quite warm here. Â Their array of fans just blow the hot air around which doesn't do much good when it's 90 degree out with 90% humidity. Â And like all hawker stands they don't have napkins but what they do have is a sink by the restroom area to wash your hands before and after you eat.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Great place for late night eats. Â  Tissue prata and a neon green super cooler you cannot beat, satay and sugar cane juice yes sir sure is delish.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Avoid at all costs!!!I live in the neighbourhood.I was told that they need 2 hours for 2 fucking shish kebabs and after the 2 hours when I called they told me they had called me and emailed me for confirmation and since I've just called to confirm, they need another 90 min to prepare the order.I've never received a call or an e-mail from them, other than the order confirmation e-mail.After telling them it's not happening on the phone, I've received an order cancellation e-mail, so their e-mail system is clearly working.3.5 hours for 2 shish kebabs?R U KIDDING ME?HORRIBLE SERVICE!WOULD NEVER ORDER AGAIN!

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Favourite place for late dinner or supper. The insane range of items on their menu fulfils any last minute cravings. From pratas to pastas to bbq seafood to kebabs, there is definately something for you. Large seating area, prompt service and large tv, makes even eating alone a pleasure.It doesn't get 5 stars as orders sometimes gets lost or mixed up. They do try their best to make it up but when nearly everyone is done eating, its too late.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: This is a review of lunch with a colleague at Spize Supper Club. Â I actually do not know if there is a difference between Spize Supper Club and Spize Mediterranean Grill. Â There are two signs outside but it seems to be more like one place.tinyurl.com/apmvuqtThe ambiance is half restaurant and half hawker. Â It has a menu and service like a restaurant. Â But it has a large outdoor seating area more similar to an outdoor hawker. Â It is well ventilated. Â  So, the heat was not actually very bad at all.tinyurl.com/albevd9I will also note the open kitchen areas are extremely clean and organized.tinyurl.com/b2azc5jtinyurl.com/apvw65xThe service is pretty straightforward. Â They take your order and bring your food. Â There isn't much more to it than that. Â I would say the staff is professional and polite but not outwardly friendly.The food was very good. Â At least mine was.Chicken Fajitas - I love steaming and sizzling plates of food. Â These fajitas certainly delivered on that. Â The core ingredients for fajitas were there. Â There were onions and peppers. Â They were well prepared. Â However, it would have been easier to construct the fajitas if the onions had been sliced instead of left as rings.There were also tomato wedges. Â This was a new one for me and fajitas. Â There were a couple of flour tortillas. Â I could have definitely used one more. Â Then there was the chicken. Â This was a little different from most fajita presentations. Â It was not sliced. Â Plus, it was mostly dark meat. Â It was very tender though and worked very well. Â tinyurl.com/au24wxvThey provided condiments. Â There was salsa and guacamole. Â Neither of these really stood out. Â They didn't seem any better than what you might buy pre--prepared from a store. Â There was also a creamy white cheese. Â This is a departure from the yellow or white hard cheeses often associated with fajitas.tinyurl.com/a3s6dvzIt all came together well and I thoroughly enjoyed my fajitas.Mediterranean Lamb Salsa Sizzling Grill - My colleague ordered the lamb. Â It also looked impressive and was sizzling away. Â However, he only gave it a mild ok/thumbs up. Â I think the term he used was "decent". Â I tried the mashed potatoes with gravy and thought they were pretty good.tinyurl.com/axma5bjOverall - I enjoyed my lunch experience at Spize and would not hesitate to return and try other things. Â I also think it might be an interesting place to have a dinner and cold beer in the evening.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: This is my favourite place to eat in the east side. I live in the west and hence I hardly visit the east ever. But when I do I always head to spize to have my dinner or supper. It's always crowded but they always have a good system going to make sure everyone does not wait too long. Also the menu has more to offer than just Muslim food. They also have indian, western, Mediterranean and the local dishes on the menu. And it's also halal. Hence it's perfect if you have Muslim friends with you.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Think about having supper in the East, and the first place that comes to mind will be Simpang Bedok. Spize Supper Club is nestled amongst a stretch of halal eateries that all open till the wee hours. The place is usually the most crowded during dinner and suppertime, or when there is a soccer game being aired. There are 2 separate sitting areas - one is 'indoors' under a makeshift tent and the other is outdoors by the roadside. I prefer sitting by the road because its breezier and more comfortable, a better place for chilling with friends. The indoor sitting tends to get a bit stuffy. Looking at their extensive menu, ranging from Western to Local delights, it can get pretty mind-boggling deciding what to order. Here are some of their best dishes - Roti John, Chicken Shawarma Wrap, Maggi Goreng, and of course what they are well known for, Roti Prata and Murtabak. Lastly, your meal will not be complete unless you order their most popular drinks like Bandung, Milo Dinosaur or Teh Halia.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: One of the best places in the East of Singapore to have supper! Spize has been a favourite since I first visited the place. The really casual and chillaxed atmosphere you get from hanging out at a prata joint is something that's really hard to beat. And somehow their kind of food is the thing that will satisfy your supper craving.Everytime I come here I will definitely make it a point to have the Roti John which is their house specialty. It comes stuffed with mutton, mushroom and cheese and is huge enough to satisfy one person. However, when you come to Spize you typically don't come alone, and the Roti John is also great for sharing.Other things I'd order when I'm here are their prata, which come crispy and hot out of the pan, maggi goreng and nasi ayam kunyit. If you have a huge group then also order the murtabak which is a bit pricey but really filling.I would normally pair sirap limau or teh cino peng with everything I've recommended above, to wash down all the curry and sauces.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: An institution of the east is Simpang Bedok, where old uncles and hipsters alike coexist and create a culture all of their own. A favourite of most people is Spize, which is known because of its large area and its several other outlets. The one in Bedok, though, is the best place for your Spize experience. The staff are all really friendly, you can chose from the front, indoors or the back (I recommend the back, that's where the party's really at) and you've got a pretty extensive menu to choose from. Even for vegan/vegetarians, you've got the usual Nasi or Mee Goreng options which can easily be customised to suit your non-animal diet, and then there are some pastas and medeterranian sides (like Hummus, $8) which you can add to the table. A personal favourite is Tofu Tiga Rasa, which literally means in malay, Three Flavour Tofu. It's not completely honest, however; you'll taste at least 8 flavours and then some. Add some Teh Ice Limau to your dinner and you're all set. And with mainly reasonable prices you'll be back again, if not for the food then for the vibe.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Think about having supper in the East, and the first place that comes to mind will be Simpang Bedok. Spize Supper Club is nestled amongst a stretch of halal eateries that all open till the wee hours. The place is usually the most crowded during dinner and suppertime, or when there is a soccer game being aired. There are 2 separate sitting areas - one is 'indoors' under a makeshift tent and the other is outdoors by the roadside. I prefer sitting by the road because its breezier and more comfortable, a better place for chilling with friends. The indoor sitting tends to get a bit stuffy. Looking at their extensive menu, ranging from Western to Local delights, it can get pretty mind-boggling deciding what to order. Here are some of their best dishes - Roti John, Chicken Shawarma Wrap, Maggi Goreng, and of course what they are well known for, Roti Prata and Murtabak. Lastly, your meal will not be complete unless you order their most popular drinks like Bandung, Milo Dinosaur or Teh Halia.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: If I were to, say somehow, hypothetically have a trashy mamak food stall craving, it'd be maggi goreng. Of course, *I* wouldn't have a trashy food craving. Me? In all my aircon loving, atas restaurant only glory? No way. Cue sideways glance. Ahem. Ok I confess. I'm an aircon loving kampong girl at heart. And Spize does a mean Thai style maggi goreng that I find spicy, sour, and super addictive. I don't even know why I like it that much; it's not that great, but I think fried carbs at midnight must be the ultimate comfort food. The gado gado too. Thick peanutty sauce, dense rice cake, spuds and bite sized pieces of keropok. It doesn't get anything better than this. I always see patrons drinking bandung or this blue colored drink that frankly scares me a little. If you've a sweet tooth, go for the Horlicks dinosaur. If you thought the Milo dinosaur was sweet, boy are you in for a real kick in the pants. It's thick and incredibly potent and by the time you're halfway through, you'll need a bottle of water to dilute all that sugar in your blood stream. You heard it here first!

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Whenever I'm at Spize, I know im guaranteed good food. It doesnt matter if I order from the local or western menu. The food is always well cooked and tasty. Some of my favourites are the nasi goreng, mushroom burger, sambal stingray, crispy fried squid and the chicken with dried chilli. Whats really important also, are the drinks. The milo peng and teh peng are pretty good. They dont skimp of the thickness of the drink and thats a good thing. You dont get a cup of diluted milo flavoured water at Spize.Its quite crowded at night but they always seem to find space to fit you and your friends.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: A regular supper haunt and a favourite of those who live in the east, Spize at Bedok boasts a large seating capacity with food at fairly affordable and decent prices. They have a huge wait staff just hanging around and waiting to assist you with orders or questions. The food is your typical asian fare, with some western thrown in as well. Depending on where you're seated, there are also TV screens which will screen the latest EPL matches or movies. Though it can get crowded and noisy, you can still enjoy your meal in relative peace.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Spize is one of the more popular supper place at Simpang Bedok. It has a really extensive menu, from the usual prata, to the Western food as well as the Malay cuisines. If you're feeling really hungry, go for the chicken biryani which comes in generous portions. My personal favorites at Spize are the cheese fries and the chicken wings. Nothing too fanciful, just the usual sin food at supper.I enjoy the outdoor seating as well. Just a laid back and relaxed atmosphere; you can chat and laugh loudly with your buddies without the worries of being judged. If you feel that you are too spoilt for choice, do ask the servers for their recommendations. They are more than glad to recommend some of the popular and good food around. Great hangout for your late night!

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: An institution of the east is Simpang Bedok, where old uncles and hipsters alike coexist and create a culture all of their own. A favourite of most people is Spize, which is known because of its large area and its several other outlets. The one in Bedok, though, is the best place for your Spize experience. The staff are all really friendly, you can chose from the front, indoors or the back (I recommend the back, that's where the party's really at) and you've got a pretty extensive menu to choose from. Even for vegan/vegetarians, you've got the usual Nasi or Mee Goreng options which can easily be customised to suit your non-animal diet, and then there are some pastas and medeterranian sides (like Hummus, $8) which you can add to the table. A personal favourite is Tofu Tiga Rasa, which literally means in malay, Three Flavour Tofu. It's not completely honest, however; you'll taste at least 8 flavours and then some. Add some Teh Ice Limau to your dinner and you're all set. And with mainly reasonable prices you'll be back again, if not for the food then for the vibe.

address: 336/338 Bedok Rd Simpang Bedok Singapore 469516 Singapore
comment: Spize is the perfect supper place for the late-night snackers, or well anyone who enjoys a good supper. A lot of the food is oily and greasy, but if you're having a midnight snack, who cares about health? I usually have roti prata when I'm there with a milo dinosaur and possibly sharing mee pattaya with someone, but there's a huge selection of food available given the time of the night. They range from local foods to western food, and many many more. The prices are cheap, like that of a coffee shop with each prata slightly more than a dollar and an average meal is unlikely to cost more than $10. They open till 3 am every night and open at 11 am. There is usually quite a lot of people at night sitting outdoors and the atmosphere is lively, a great place to hang out with friends after dark and not too far from home if you live in the east.

rest_name: Boon Keng Road Fish Head Bee Hoon
address: Blk 416 Bedok North Ave 2 #01-47 Singapore 460416 Singapore
comment: I always enjoy a bowl of fish soup on cold rainy days.Boon Keng road fish head soup (used to be in Boon Keng and moved to Bedok about 10 years back) uses batang fish head and ikan bills in their broth. You can choose between fried fish or sliced fish. The stall also sells seafood soup and pig stomach soup. If you enjoy soupy stuff on rainy days, this would be one stall you should visit. The owner Madam Tan visits the shop from time to time and her soup tastes the best, compared to the other cooks she hired.

address: 3 Simei St 6 #03-04, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: PRICE: SUPER AFFORDABLE Prices range from $3.90-$8.90 which is very affordable and for the quality of food received it is a very good price. There is also NO GST AND SERVICE CHARGE here. Salmon Pizza $7.90 Prawn Pasta $5.90 Truffle Ice Cream $4.90 Cheese Chicken & Pork Slices $8.90 Mushroom Creme $7.90 Mushroom Soup $3.90Minestrone Soup $3.90 Free Flow Drinks $2.90 FOOD: GREAT The food is very good for the price and the proportions are filling. The Salmon Pizza is definitely recommended by me because the crust is thin and the cheese and salmon is generous. The Prawn Pasta is also really good with great flavour & the Truffle Ice Cream is very good. Its delectable & rich, definitely worth the price! OVERALL: AWESOMEDefinitely coming back more often! One of my favorite places to dine now! Give this place a try if you want some good and affordable food!

address: 3 Simei St 6 #03-04, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: Best place for French food. Affordable and a wide variety of dishes. Try the escargot and pizza. There are steaks too, but I recommend trying the various pastas. The steaks are a tad small, but then no complains with regards to the pricing. They have an option for all you can drinks as an added extra cost. Overall a low cost place to try French food. I also noticed this restaurant is always packed as compared to the other food joints in the building. Update: Still the best place for French dinner.

address: 3 Simei St 6 #03-04, Eastpoint Mall Singapore 528833 Singapore
comment: The four stars is for value.PricingSmall pizza for $7.90 dine-in. Add $3.90 for a small salad and free-flow soda. Nice prices for teenagers and that's the kind of crowds you see here. Grills at $8.90, pastas at $5.90, all very reasonable.QualityThe food quality is decent, pre-can ingredients and acceptable freshness. Nothing to complain.Size portions reasonable for Asian girls, slightly underwhelming for boys.Service is quick and prompt.

rest_name: Kimâs Fried Hokkien Prawn Mee Stall
comment: This place has some of the best fried Hokkien Mee in Sg IMHO. It easily competes with the lorong 29 mee.It comes with very generous serving of prawns and the excellent chilli sauce compliments the dish very well.The coup de grace is the fried pork lard which I know I shouldn't partake in but due to my weakness, just cannot resist....it makes the dish even better! Parking can be hard to find given that it is facing a busy street corner but we somehow always manage to get a spot.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: This is basically the refreshment stop for those who visit the Changi museum, and basically it is right next door. Well, you can also grab a bite to eat here, though when I was here I simply had a drink while waiting for the next bus to arrive (which pass by every fifteen minutes). It is a good place to sit to take in what you have just seen in the museum (though of course there is nothing stopping your from coming here before going inside). It was okay, but then again there isn't much else in the area to compete with it.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: Food quality is ok but price is rather expensive considering the location. Final bill includes service charge and GST.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: The entirely alfresco restaurant serves coffeehouse-type fare, so you get a hodgepodge of local classics like nasi goreng and seafood hor fan, as well as western mainstays like beef stew and cheeseburgers. The food was ok, but if I had to take into account the 40-minute drive in heavy traffic from town, I wouldn't go to The Bark Cafe. That said, this would make a worthwhile visit IF you're already in the area and looking for sustenance in a chilled-out spot with lots of quiet and charm.We had:1) Tangy Calamari Rings ($9.90): thinly battered and deep-fried to a delectable crisp, but what impressed me was that the squid encased within was perfectly cooked.2) Sweet Potato Sticks ($13.90): balanced out by the salty creaminess of the Parmesan mayo dip.3) Bark Cafe Famous Chicken Wing ($15.90 for 6 pcs): they really shouldn't have slapped a superlative such as this, because it set expectations too lofty to meet. The prawn paste-accented wings were nice, but vapid, and so, failed to leave an impression. I've had better for less.4) Smoky Black Pepper Duck Breast ($18.90): surprising refined. I wouldn't have expected a casual place like this to serve this typically highbrow dish, or to do it this well. Sparkling fresh meat, with nary a hint of game, was slow-roasted to luscious perfection. This was sided by wafu-dressed mesclun greens, and mashed potatoes.5) Fish & Chips ($18.90): decent, but the deep-fried Pacific dory fillet was a dime a dozen.6) Grilled Guinness Balsamic Chicken ($19.90) marinated in Cajun herbs, sided by steamed root vegetables, mashed potatoes, and slathered in a Guinness beer gravy: nice enough, but it reminded me of those hawker centre western food stall productions.7) Chicago Roasted Tenderloin ($29.90): even though cheap, this was lackluster. The beef was gamey, so no amount of roasting finesse could save it.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: Average. This place is only average in my book. Warm and muggy and having to deal with flies and Mosquitos. Their "famous chicken wings" is basically prawn paste chicken wings, which was about the same as what I have had at many other zhi char stalls. It was not bad, but a bit overrated. As stated by many other reviewers, the starters came AFTER the main course. WHY? The smoked pepper duck was ok. The salad that came with it looked old and faded. Overall, I'm underwhelmed.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: Nice Cozy place to hang around with friends.My Friends brought me there to celebrate my birthday the year before. Its an outdoor alfresco dinning serving Chinese & western food.Didn't know that there's a gem hidden up in the secluded area. Its was a breezy night fill with laughter. The ambience is relaxing and its a good place to chill out with friends.The service crew is polite and they offer good recommendation. We order quite a big spread of variety ranging from chicken wing, fries, osyters, burgers, spaghetti, duck meat. The food is simply tasty and worth every penny.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: Went there yesterday. Â Reached there about 1700hrs.The environment was good. Â The food was good. Â Only worry is if it rains, then might get wet because ceiling was high and there was no side shielding.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: Don't get me wrong: I love the ambience here, which allows you to be laid-back, to relax and get away from the bustling city. However, I was sorely disappointed that the food was not as good as I would have expected, given the prices that I was paying. I had the smoked duck while my party had the fish and chips. First off, the duck tasted rubbery and had lost most of its texture after it had been cooked. The peppery skin overpowered whatever natural flavours had been in the meat. The fish and chips were a little too oily for my party's tastes, and there wasn't a lot of fish meat under that crispy, fried skin. I'd admit that the cafÃ© does its french fries well. We didn't try the chicken wings, which is supposedly the cafÃ©'s speciality.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: Located beside the Changi Chapel and Museum, The Bark Care is a fully al fresco joint that has no air-conditioning. But it's surprisingly breezy and has a a calm, relaxed vibe about it. Thanks to its secluded location, it's actually great for slipping away from the hustle and bustle of city life to have a drink or two with friends. It's also great as the people that come are usually its regulars, so you enjoy some sort of an extended family feel, where everyone sorta knows each other. The selection of beer is great and prices are affordable. The food is really average so don't come here to satisfy any hunger pangs. Other than that, it's a good place to relax and have a beer.

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: This is a great place to hang out with some friends. The music is pure quality, and the service too is excellent. It is one of the few places in Singapore where you will find parking right outside. What I like about the parking is the lack of system, this allows you to maximize the empty spaces on the grass, along the side and so on. It is a decent distance away from any other night life joint so it does give that feeling of isolation. The food isn't bad too, the speciality for me being the Chilean Cod Fusion, I've had this 3 times before and never once has it disappointed me!The restaurant is decked out in magnificent lights, and the sitting arrangement is positioned very comfortably, allowing ample space between tables. For me, this is a great place to find a temporary escape from the city life, almost makes me feel like I am on holiday!

address: 1000 Upper Changi Rd North Singapore 507707 Singapore
comment: The Bark Cafe gets surprisingly busy on weekends - you won't be able to miss it, as there are cars parked even on the verge of the carpark at Bark Cafe. It has a great relaxing atmosphere, draft beers, and serve both western and 'chinese/singaporean' food - some of their most popular dishes are their deep fried chicken wings (you'll see a basket of them on almost every table) and with good reason, the batter is amazing and the wings juicy and hot - and their hor fun. The hor fun wasn't great, it tasted very much like cubed chicken stock - and didn't have that fiery smell (I've had much better elsewhere).But overall a decent place for dinner and drinks around the east!

address: 63 East Coast Rd #01-06 Red House Singapore 428776 Singapore
comment: I don't know about you but I love black coffee. Taste the latte and flat white are not so bad either. Check out the scramble egg on the big breakfast, that runny egg is unexpected but I love it. I had better sourdough though. Sausage is okay too. Place is tight and crowded. I like the fact they are freshly bake. Service consider good despite the crowd.

From time to time i hit a big miss and this one i can't let all the foodies down by not reporting. Â Of all places I saw on GOOGLE how a wonderful 4 star this is. Â So i went with great expectations but this was so disappointing that even if i lowered my expectation to close to zero it would still not make the mark. Â Please save your money go to Nakhon. Â At least i know the Parkway Branch crispy garlic chicken is indeed crispy.

Was invited for lunch with a group of 10, fantastic variety of food, gurame fried fish so crispy you eat the bones too, The beef, shrimp, currys, green beans dishes are delicious, Â the shave ice with coconut milk and cane sugar was so yummy!

Ambiance at this restaurant is not impressive. A little tired to tell you the truth. On a Thursday night, the place was lightly patronized. A pity really, because the food is really good. Indonesian fare, cooked in a traditional manner. The sayoh lodeh included nanka, unusual and very good. Likewise the gurame fish. Excellent. Service was attentive and the price for a set meal was reasonable. Food potions were large. We had the set for 2 persons, 3 of us ate and were stuffed. Recommended for a casual outdoor meal with family and friends. A real find to tell you the truth.

address: 750A Chai Chee Rd #01-03, Viva Business Park, Chai Chee Estate Singapore 469001 Singapore
comment: Just a few metres away from the sports megastore Decathlon, the place is relatively well-hidden and only half-full when we visited on Sunday. I got to know about it by word of mouth and its location and lack of publicity might explain the numbers. The whole place is designed in a deliberately spartan way, though it would not look out of place if it was in the CBD.The choice of food is not great and given the slow business, they have not stocked up on quite a few mains and starters. However, the bacon lollipop, which is one of their specialties, was available. It is 5 layers of fatty bacon glistening with oily goodness. Pure decadence.For mains, we had the truffle carbonara and the tiger prawns pasta. Both were quite decent and I noted that actual truffles were used, rather than just truffle oil which scored points with me. However, the tiger prawns pasta took a long time to arrive (30 minutes after the truffle carbonara) and we had to remind the waitress about the order. We also tried the coffee, which was distinctly average. That seemed understandable though, given that it is more of a bar than a cafe.Probably a good place to hang out with your buddies in the heartlands if you want drinks and a decent meal.

address: 3014 Bedok Industrial Park E Century Village Coffee Shop Singapore 489980 Singapore
comment: Istimewa Kitchen is a little out of the way, being in Bedok Industrial Park, but for people who are based here, the food at Istimewa is worth the queue. The mutton rendang here is flavorful, and the sambal sauce is worth trying.Having spoken to the owner, I've been told that they'll be coming up with specialty dishes after CNY, which is pretty soon!
