Hope I'll have the opportunity to drop by again to try a couple of them.Given its relative obscurity to the rest of Singapore, it's perhaps unfortunate that not many people will know of this place but considering how new this eatery is and the quality of fare it serves, it's only a matter of time before more know of it.

I came here with family because we heard the dumplings were good, and the experience exceeded my expectations. Ironically, everything was a home run except the dumplings. They were good, mind you, but they don't beat Din Tai Fung, and the other dishes we ordered at E&N were much better. The potstickers were nearly perfect. They were crispy, hot, tender, juicy explosions of flavor. The mincemeat noodles were surprisingly light in contrast, but great noodle texture and flavor, tasty sauce, and fresh cucumbers. The steamed buns and stir-fried veggies were notable, too, but my favorite dish was the eggplant. If you like eggplant you must try it! Great service. Pleasant, casual atmosphere. Very reasonably priced, too. All the mains were ~$10 so we fattened up a hungry party of 5 for less than $80. By the way, anyone know what's up with that "shrine" to the basketball player?

On point with the food. Everything ordered was delicious and very authentic tasting. Oxtail noodle soup was tasty and the few pieces of oxtail were meaty but not mushy. The pork "pizza pie" was hot and greasy, but ain't complaining. We knew what we were getting into ordering something fried. The xiao long bao dumplings had a thicker skin than I prefer but the filling was pork'ilicious. It came 4 to an order. The jajyang mein was my favorite because it was simple, balanced, and noodles were light. Not sure what "Tall Girl Cuisine" is but as we were dining, this tall, young lady walked in and proceeded to dine at the next table over. The staff brought food and a stack of mail to her. She appeared to be the owner, or somehow related. The walls of the restaurant were decked out with pictures of famous Asian basketball players. Apparently, the restaurant is owned by some famous basketball players from China. And the tall, young lady was their daughter. Interesting ...Great food, clean restaurant, and reasonably priced.

Chinese dumplings is definitely one of my favorite Chinese foods: they are absolutely great comfort foods and can be eaten on their own for any meal, be it breakfast, lunch or dinner.I ventured to this place based on the recommendation of my Chinese friend, and I was definitely not disappointed. The dumplings here were very tasty: the skin was not too thick and the fillings was very flavorful and succulent. Together with the vinegar, they were just absolutely amazing.We also had the zha jiang mian, which was excellent as well. The sauce, minced meat and the texture of the noodles came together to form a very tasty bowl of noodles. They also have some other items such as fried Â beef tendon, which I intend to try on my next visit. A great place to enjoy some authentic Chinese food!

You will get here Chinese dishes from northern China, pretty rare in Singapore. We had different variations of noodle dishes. My absolute favorite was the oxtail soup. The celery and cashew nuts dish was excellent. We also had pork as well as vegetable dumplings. These are less refined than those found in Din Tai Fung. But they are authentic, exactly what you would get in northern China. My friend from northern China rated this restaurant better than the one she used to patronize in Shanghai.

The eggplant and potstickers are the stars of this restaurant. We tried their xiaolong bao, their steamed dumplings, zha-jiang noodles and other stuff, but really, their potstickers is their best dish. Chock full of meat with a slightly thicker, slight crisp skin, it is very satisfying. The eggplant in spicy meat sauce (yu xiang) was suprisingly good. Very nicely stir-fried, served in a great-tasting sauce, with the eggplant hot and smooth. The meat sauce noodles were the biggest disappointment. The sauce was bland, and the meat was sorta disintegrating and tasteless. I've definitely had better, namely at qun zhong eating place in chinatown. I would go if I live around the area, but definitely not worth a special trip there.

address: 5 Tampines Ave 3 #02-07 Tampines West Community Club Singapore 529705 Singapore
comment: Cosy place, good fresh food. One of the better places that are off the track. Would of recommend for a hearty weekend brunch.

address: 5 Tampines Ave 3 #02-07 Tampines West Community Club Singapore 529705 Singapore
comment: Use to come here few time, food is ok. But the managements is sucks, I come here once with reservations, but when I arrived I being told that only can order after 6pm, my reservation is 5pm. SucksOne more Time and is my last time I think, we arrive , can not book as the website hang. When we arrive got table but claimed is reversed but we wait for 15 minute not one is arriving, and the table that is said to be for us have been assign to other people, I was a bit upset and ask them why, the Waistee or the manager ( local Malay ) told be with serious face saying "it is his call" to give to other people or not. Sucks!!!! Who you think you are. This kinda of food with this non convininient location , this kinds of attitudes. I will not come again, and my friend family will not come again

I consider myself adventurous, always wanting to try out different eateries once in a while. As far as halal seafood is concerned, I keep gravitating towards Chai Chee Seafood Restaurant. It is an obvious favourite amongst families too, with the many joyous birthday celebrations being held here.The Chili Crab and Oat Prawns are a must try! We tried the Salted Egg Yolk Crab, Steamed Garoupa (they do it Teochew style too) and Asam Pedas (yessssah!) - and loved them all. Our supper favourite has got to be their Chilli Seafood Kuay Teow. And we always complete our meal with the ultimate Teh Tarik. Always make our day!

The curry coconut cream broth seems thinner. Maybe the chef added stock to stretch an existing batch. But, the fresh cockles, thinly sliced fish cake, prawn, and herb chiffonade still taste great. But it is the dried shrimp chili paste that adds a fiery punch of flavor to the bowl.

My go to when I visit home/Singapore. Traditional nonya laksa that survived through generations and last stall standing on Katong compared to back then when there were at least 3 nonya laksa stalls side by side competing on that Katong street where most Peranakans live.

April 2019. My first time trying laksa. It was a bit spicy so don't skip out on the lime juice! Noodles were all cut up in to small pieces which I'm usually not a fan of but makes sense since they only give out spoons. Broth is spicy, creamy and flavorful.

My friend took me to 328 Katong Laksa during my first trip to Singapore back in November 2018, and boy was I blown out of my mind. Â 328 Katong Laksa is popular with locals, tourists, and celebrities alike. Â They have one heavenly bowl of laksa for a very reasonable price. Â Perfectly tangy, spicy, creamy, smooth, and curried broth, with just the right amount of noodles (which are cut for ease of eating) and filled with prawns, fish cake, and cockles. I also ordered a lime juice, which surprisingly helped to cut away at the heat. Â Eat a bite, tongue gets on fire, then cools it down immediately with a sip of lime juice, and repeat. Also, a small size is quite filling, especially on a hot and humid day when you can't fathom eating too much.Previously, I had laksa in the US, and none of the laksas I had in the US can even remotely compare to 328 Katong Laksa's. Definitely worth a try if you're ever in Singapore.

Didn't know this place was so popular? After walking in and seeing all of these famous people's photos plastered on the wall thought for sure it will be great!In their Laksa they don't use chicken or shrimp they use blood clams or also called cockles. It was really spicy so I could only eat a few spoonfuls before giving up.Not sure I would be back as I can't take the heat.

Sweared by locals that this is the best laksa place in Singapore so I had to give it a try. This place looks like a fast food joint, where you go up to the counter and order what you would like to eat and your name will be called when your food is ready. There were 2 specials that you could order but mostly people just order the laksa in either small or large. The large was split between my cousin and myself for about $7 SGD, which is reasonable for a big bowl of laksa.The broth was very creamy and noodles were cooked al dente. This place only gives you spoons to eat your bowl but is easy to do so. Overall, recommend this place if you're wanting to try some good Laksa while in Singapore!

When trying to discover the best laksa in Singapore, locals always pointed me to katong laksa so I had to give it a try. This spot started as a hawker stand and blew up, to having 3 locations now. The food is so good that its attracted many celebrities and hype with the news. The service is quick and snappy, and this location fortunately has AC. The laksa itself has a slighter milder taste, but it's perfectly balanced with the seafood, while sporting a nice spicy kick. The noodles are also cut so you eat it with a soup spoon - chopsticks are not even offered! In addition to the laksa, you can even pair it with otah or nasi lemak for not much more!Overall, this was my favorite laksa spot I've tried and I highly recommend giving here a try!

In my previous SGP trip I had a great experience eating here. This time around It was still satisfying but they skimped on the ingredients. The sign of an over-hyped industrialized tourist spot. Â Also I noticed the pictures of Anthony Bourdain has been removed from the wall, what a shame. The posters of other celeb visitors such as Gordon Ramsay, Martin Yen & Samantha Brown are still there just as I remembered. Got the standard laksa again, the broth was still excellent as I remembered: rich, creamy, smooth & spicy. Â But it only contained basic ingredients such as some bean sprouts & a few cockles, no other seafood (e.g. shrimps) unless you pay extra. Standard katong style short rice noodles that can be eaten with a spoon, no chopsticks needed.The $2 nasi lemak wrapped in leaf: very forgetable, rice was dry & not much flavor even with their samba sauce. It also contained a sorry-looking piece of small dry fish.Overall the broth of their laksa is still one of the best I have ever had. I just don't like the fact that they took advantage of their fame & skimped on other ingredients. I ate at multiple good laksa places, including its equally famed competitor across the street as well as the trishaw laksa in Hon Lim center, they both had descend amount of "seafood" in their standard basic laksa.

Perfect Michelin fast food for $7SGD! This dish is made to be used with spoon only so you have some of the soup and broken noodles in one spoonful. A bit spicy with a coconut milk flavor to calm the heat. No napkins around here. Popular during lunch rush hour. This is how laksa should taste.

Had to have Laksa in Singapore, and was told this is a place to try. Â They said if there's a lot of celebrity pictures on the wall, then it's probably a good place to eat. There's nothing super fancy about the Laksa, except that it taste awesome. Â I also had Otah for the first time, which is surprisingly good.

Came by for breakfast after a couple suggestions from locals. Ordered the small laksa and didn't quite get the hype.At $5.35 SGD, there was a small bowl of coconut curry noodles that actually quite thick. The bowl was 95% noodles with a few tiny shrimps and fish cake. ...Took a few bites and went on with my day......Not quite sure I get the hype with Laksa...

This was my first time trying laksa and it was pretty good! At this restaurant there are two options for laksa, large or small. The large is $7.50 and the small is $5.30. I found the small to be plenty, my husband had large and he didn't finish it all. Â They also have some appetizer items which we did not try. You might want to bring your own napkin as you have to buy them for 30 cents if you need them.

The best laksa. Period.Living in Toronto where you can virtually order any cuisine you wish, I thought I knew what good laksa was. After visiting 328 Katong Laksa, it's officially ruined all other laksa for me.Located in a small restaurant, this self serve joint is a no fuss type of establishment. What's interesting is they don't provide chopsticks. You're expected to slurp down your laksa with no other utensil other than your spoon.Not sure if this made everything taste better, but this bowl was the best tasting laksa I've had - even after trying several laksa joints in previous days. The spicy kick and the creaminess of the broth provided a beautiful base to the noodles and seafood that soaked up all the flavor. The serving was just enough to get you full - although I wish I had room to try the other items.Tip: Bring tissue to wipe off sweat from the spice.

I really enjoyed the large bowl of laksa, not too spicy, the chili paste adds an interesting zing to the flavor. Â The lime juice was very good as well. Â I also ordered the shrimp siu mai, the siu mai goes well with the chili paste.

Their original laksa was SO GOOD!!! You probably won't find another Laksa place better than this one and it's not just a hype! The noodles are cut for you so can use a spoon to scoop out the spoonfuls of goodness! This "katong" style Laksa is filled with big prawns, fish cake, cockles, mushrooms and topped with some coriander with a light coconut milk that isn't too overpowering. For visitors like me who grew up in North America, we tend to lose a bit of appetite when traveling to hot cities like Singapore (37 degrees that day I was there), so i only ordered a small bowl since i wasn't sure if I could finish it on my own, immediately after the first sip of the soup, I regret not ordering something bigger!! I fell in love with the soup immediately and the temperature inside or outside didn't bother me at all and was actually quite comforting! A little sweaty after, but not too crazy :) I wish i knew how to make this at home so I can enjoy this everyday! I will definitely come back when I visit Singapore again!

My first experience with laksa curry noodle soup, and this place lives up to its hype as a 1 Michelin Star restaurant. Â The broth was delicious, and I could not stop eating despite wiping the sweat off my brow after every couple of bites. Â (I have a low tolerance for spicy food). The place it unassuming, cozy, and prefers to have its food speak for itself. Â What a nice piece of memory in Katong.

If you're in the mood for laksa, Come here!Recommended!Came here for a late lunch of Laksa, with a side order of otah (grilled fish cake). The place was crowded, but I was still able to get an inside table.Food:The Laksa comes in small and large. Even the small was a good quantity of delicious laksa, including noodles,prawns and otah. The gravy is very flavorful. Spicy, but you can add extra chili if you want to kick it up a notch. The otah is tasty, and not spicy.Cost:Good value - the small Laksa was S$5.35 and the otah was S$1.40. Very reasonable considering the amounts.Service: They were very efficient and the order came out quickly.Atmosphere:This place is a typical small shop house in Katong. The indoor seating is a bit cramped, and consists of little plastic stools with no backs. One wall is full of historical photos of the shop and the owner.Overall:Come here for the Laksa, not the ambiance! But DO give it a try!

Supaya dapat (SIM surat ijin mancing) next trip, sogok dulu pemilik SIM dengan 328 Katong laksa yang hmmmm wangi dan enaknya.Food : 4.5/5Service : 3/5Price : $$Place : 3/5.HalalRest : 328 Katong LaksaLocation : East coast roadCity : Singapore.

Hands down, they serve the best laksa in Singapore. They deserve all the accolades they get. I suggest ordering the laksa with otah. A small is sufficient for lunch. The otah has a nice saltiness to it and helps balance some of the spice of the laksa. The laksa noodles are cut perfectly so you won't need chopsticks. I don't think they offer chopsticks, even if you ask. The location is clean and casual. The service is efficient, but unfriendly. I would happily give them 5 stars if they ever cracked a smile . For now, a 4 star rating is just right.

There's only one variety of laksa here - and its great. Fast service, cheap and delicious. I ordered the large - in hindsight, a small would have done.The coconut broth is subtle and spicy. Small chunks of seafood throughout a bowl full of noodles. If you're looking for good value for money Laksa, look no further.

The 32 Katong Laksa here is overrated. The staff are rude and proud. Maybe because they are one of the most famous laksa store in Singapore. I feel that the laksa here is normal. There are certainly many other better laksa around in Singapore.

Do we love laksa? If it isn't an asam laska, for sure!And this place has it all. Seafood, coconut, lime, spice! Yummmm. Menu is simple: Laksa, fish and rice. Small for $5 and large for $7. Not bad at all. And its self serve so serve yourself. DÃ©cor: you are in an open area/cafeteria style place. Food: great! Drinks: plenty. They have thai ice tea, coconut drinks, lime drinks and so on. Laksa ~ creamy, milk, delicious laksa. I love the shrimps and fish slices as well as all the fixins they add on top. The noodles are exactly what I like. Almost like that tapioca noodle. Perfect to soak up all the soup and stay al dente. Opak opak ~ fish in pandan leave aka the banana leaves. it is nice and flaky. Also their nasi lemak is also a good option If you want more crunch and flavors with your meal. Everything is reasonably priced, taste good. Their hot sauce is out of this world. The only complaint I have is that they chop their noodles up!! Like why?? I mean I know why I guess. They do it so that everyone can enjoy this soup with on spoon instead of using a spoon, a fork and some chopsticks. Faster way to eat your noodles. I'd prefer having to fight, roll and twirl my noodles in whatever I'm eating. Minus that, it's still pretty good. You can sit indoor or outdoor, take a picture with that massive wall of celebs pics and enjoy your laksa! YUmmm!

Every time I'm back in town to visit the family, it's a food fest. Â There's no way around it. Â And my first meal of the trip, in particular, holds a special place for me. Â This trip, it was Katong laksa.First things first, don't ask for chopsticks. Â The noodles are cut down to size so that they easily fit on your spoon so that with each spoonful, you get an effortless and amazing mixture of soup, noodles, shrimp, fish cake, and cockles. Â If you're not a fan of the heat, not to worry, this location is indoors and air conditioned, sheltering you from the heat, humidity and often times, rain. Â Speaking of heat, the soup itself isn't too spicy but definitely grab a little pack of sambal to spice things up!Perfect dish to stir up all that nostalgia - I can't wait for my next trip to get more!

I was told that this place has the best laksa by at least four locals, so I was determined to try it. Â Btw, laksa is a traditional Singaporean curry noodle dish. Â I had opted to go at night as the morning heat was too much to have curry. Â Upon arriving, I had instantly noticed the wall of celebrities that have patronized the establishment. Â I ordered the small laksa, and it was ready right away. I noticed that the three shrimps in the bowl was quite small, and nothing like the picture. I proceeded to try it, and sadly, it was nothing special to me. Â Half-way through, I added a packet of their chili sauce, and this gave it a much needed kick. Â I don't mean extra spiciness, but complexity. Before the chili sauce, it was a very boring bowl of noodles. Â So, thank goodness for that chili sauce. Â I liked the sauce so much that I bought a jar to take away.

I came from Hawaii. To taste the original Laksa Â that made my mouth water when I ate it in Honolulu. Â I was disappointed. Â Again Fame baby remember my name made this place famous and is again part of its Â notoriety downfall. Soup tasty, seafood Â , Â I had a hard time locating the shrimp that was in their photos. minimal, noodles ok but I'm used to two kinds. The nasi lemak Â rice was a pleasant surprise.

"Shiok" is truly the only word to describe this place. Although I suppose you could debate that personal preference plays a part in the Singapore v. Penang style laksa battle, I think Katong Laksa is miles ahead of all else. The broth is deliciously bold with seafood, coconut and curry flavors. The noodles come cut so you can enjoy each spoonful with the perfect combination of soup and noodles. Cheap, delicious, authentic. YUM

The Laksa is the absolute bomb. Gordon Ramsey even went to this location. His picture is on the "wall of shame". Â The siu mai and the chili crab pau aka steam buns is a must order. You can eat the noodles with a soup spoon. Ask for chop sticks and they say No

When I told my Singapore friend, how much I love laksa, this was the one place he told me I had to try. So one day I hopped on the bus and went.328 Katong Laksa is a small self-serve restaurant. You order at the counter and then grab a seat at an open table. There is indoor and outdoor seating. There wasn't many people when I went, maybe because it was during off peak hours. I think it will be more crowded during the lunch/dinner time frame. I do recommend sitting indoors because there is a/c and trust me you will be sweating when eating that bowl of laksa. Their menu consists of laksa, small or large bowl for $5/$7, Nasi Lemak, $1.80 a packet, and Otah, $1.30 each. I tried the laksa and the otah. I personally think the small bowl of laksa is just enough. Note that you cannot alter the bowl of noodles at all, nor omit any ingredients. It comes just the way it is. It was a little bland for me, so make sure to add a packet of the sauce that comes with the bowl of noodles (from what I remember it comes with 2 packets, but charge per packet after that). It definitely adds more flavor to the broth. I have to warn those that cannot take the heat because it is SPICY. Also, expect to eat this with a soup spoon, no chopsticks/fork. The otah, a type of fish cake, was real good, especially if you add some of that sauce that came with your laksa.After pondering long and hard, the laksa was actually really good and is one of the better bowls I've had in Singapore, but I don't think I would take a 20-30 min bus ride all the way out here to satisfy my laksa craving.

Apparently the chain of choice for this dish I've never tried and was delicious. Highlights:- Laksa: their claim to fame was a smooth coconutty, limey, and spicy broth combo. Noodles were slippery short almost bean sprouty which was different. 4.5 stars- Opak opak: minced white fish cooked in banana leaves. Worried it'd be overly fishy but wasn't. 3.5 starsLowlights:- Just laksa, nasi lasek, and opak opak so have people who want other items go elsewhere and meet you after- Outdoor version so can get hot compared to the AC options inside Glad I discovered another dish I'd eat again.

My nose didn't stop running the whole time I ate this(Laksa). Not pepper burn "hot", but more chili (nose run) "hot". Once you start, you can't stop. Very addictive and tasty. Â For my fellow Americans, don't be afraid of the fish cake. Not what I expected. Was very good.My first laksa experience was a winner.

Didn't quite do it for me...Texture of the noodle was so so. The flavor of the broth was good, but nothing that would make me jump out of my seat or burst into songs. Think there's a bit of hype here...

surprisingly fantastic laksa in katong, one of a couple famous places serving this dish. I have eaten laksa less times than the fingers on one hand, but, this was delicious.the coconut milk mellowed the savoury base into this rounded, creamy soup with an unexpected lightness, and the tender noodles were slippery bits that worked its way between the fresh prawns and cockles. I certainly didn't expect to enjoy it nearly this much, and the just-on-the-edge sour of the lime juice was pretty perfect.the small coffeeshop space is fully air-conditioned, which is fantastic considering the heat and spiciness of the dish, but that luxury does reflect itself in its price. little matter though, as it honestly is more filling than whatever you'd receive at a newfangled cafe for the money, and is likely executed with more skill and finesse anyway.worth a visit, and definitely worth the money.

I came here a few times to enjoy the spicy Laska which is supposed to be the better ones over here. There are a few branches of this in Singapore and from what I heard, this is the best. You can choose to sit either indoors or outdoors, of course with Singapore's kind of weather, indoors is the only option for me. Enjoying the hot bowl of Laska with a cold drink of Barley is definitely satisfying for me. I often choose the $5 bowl which is enough to satisfying my hunger. The noodles in the Laska is sliced to small pieces which means a pair of chopsticks is not required and you can just enjoy with a spoon. It's has a strong flavour and every spoonful of it makes me want more, that's how I felt especially on my last trip there. For foreigners, you should come by to try at least once, get the feel of enjoying one of Singapore's popular dishes. Overall, I find this to be my liking and definitely give my thumbs up to those thinking of trying.

An old Singapore brand and listed in the Michelin Guide, it's still served with 'hum' and just a spoon, although it would have been even more nostalgic served in the porcelain bowls of old. The Laksa gravy is not as rich and thick as I remember but still flavourful.

Wowza! pretty amazing Laksa (note however its all seafood, so if you are vegetarian or dont eat seafood, then unfortunately you are all out of luck). I enjoyed the complexity of the laksa curry sauce too - spicy, sour, tangy and fishy all in one. Noodles and seafood also in just the right amount. Its not a full on 5-stars because I have had better laksa, but the "Otah" gets a full 5-stars. I have never had it before and its basically fish in a banana leaf, but omg the flavors!! Bursting with umami goodness - robust and complex, the smell reminded me of earthy mushrooms and black tea with a dash of soy. Taste-wise, not sure how to describe the Otah? A little bit spongy/ soft but not melting like jelly. My description doesn't do the Otah justice so just trust me on this and try some!!Will def recommend.

I have been wanting laksa for the past week and we finally got to eat at a laksa shop! The shop itself is rather small, but could house up to 20-30 guests. My husband order the 3 small bowls of the laksa. He also ordered lime juice for himself and luohan longan for me. My mother-in-law was also with us, but she prefered something warm, but the shop does not offer anything warm so she did not want a drink. The order comes right out once he places his order and he brought all the laksa and drinks on a tray to our table. The laksa only comes with a spoon, there's no forks or chopsticks at this shop. I wanted a pair of chopsticks or fork because my noodles were quite long and each time I scoop up the noodles and toppings, all of the noodles would slide right off and only the toppings were left. Eventually I managed to look for the shorter noodles in my bowl and enjoyed those first. Which was pretty good, because there were slices of squid/cuttlefish. There were also small clam-like things in the laksa as well. I was not a fan of those and scoop most of them out for my husband, since he enjoys eating them. It's a good thing we occasionally like different things, because I could eat what he doesn't like and he can eat what I don't like. This shop only sells a couple of items on the menu and the main dish would of course be laksa. It would have been nice if there's more variety to laksa like the toppings or more different seasoning. I do like how they posted pictures of celebrities and famous people, on the wall, that had visited the shop back in the days. I could recognize some of the celebrities and it's nice to know they had been here one time, long ago.
This spot was convenient since it was right across the street from our hotel. The laksa was tasty and delicious.
Fresh, we took the Laksa - full of taste, spicy in a good way, good portion, also the lime juice is nice.

Great bowl of laksa! There's good seafood flavors with the bowl. My only complaint is there is not enough seafood, there's really only a few small pieces of mussels in there. Overall, really good bowl of noods. It's cash only FYI.

I love this 328 Katong Laksa's location.This might not be the original location but for me as long as I can have a great food and good services, I am happy! And with AC too!The lone waiter here is nice, patient and friendly. Answered all our questions and gave us good recommendations with a big smile.And of course the only reason here is for the laksa and that's the only thing offers in the menu with the only decision to made is the sizes. When I want to ask for a pair of chopsticks, my Yelp friend realized I did not read up on Katong laksa before my trip as "Katong laksa is a variant of laksa lemak from the Katong area of Singapore. In Katong laksa, the noodles are normally cut up into smaller pieces so that the entire dish can be eaten with a spoon alone, without chopsticks or a fork." *It is one of the most enjoyable laksa I have! The soup base is so rich with coconut and the hot sauce on the side just add the heat to the noodle itself. And eating with a spoon is just awesome as I probably have problem trying to pick up the slippery noodle with my chopsticks anyway.Silent while we enjoying our laksa... I will be happy to have one of this for lunch everyday..*Source from Wikipedia

I went to 328 Katong Laksa with my fiance several times in 2015 when we were in Singapore. I still dream of this laksa and the cold, fresh lime juice to wash it down with! I've never found laksa as good as the one at 328 Katong! I definitely preferred the Singapore laksa over the Penang style I had in Malaysia. This laksa is one of the only reasons I would go back to Singapore!

My mother raved great things about Laksa so we decided to check out 328 Katong Laksa! My father mentioned that this place is one of the top rated places on Trip Advisor. We took a cab to come here since it's in the outer part of downtown Singapore. For myself, I got the small Laksa bowl. It's pretty much chopped-up noodles in a coconut milk spicy broth. They put shrimp and clams inside the broth. They also provide you with 2 chili packets (up to 2 max. they charge you additional for more) which enhances the flavor of the Laksa. I recommend you use it! Overall experience, I enjoyed it & it's full of flavor. Don't think I can eat this too often though~ Must try it once when you are in Singapore though!
The local Laksa is the famous and delicious from this Restaurants!Good taste with very nice smell of coconut milk combination in the spicy soup! Good to try!

First try for katong laksa. Had heard of how delicious katong laksa is since long ago, now finally have the chance to try out. Okay so the laksa is not bad. Well, I eat laksa must be spicy but this katong laksa isn't spicy to me at all. So for those who doesn't really eat spicy, this laksa should be good. Saw many famous overseas actors/actresses came to have laksa here many years ago because in the photos they are at their younger looks. The queue in line is long but still can be wait. It also sells tissue at $0.30 per tissue pack and beverages too. Overall I think is okay but venue is too far for me to come back anytime
Visited this place a couple of times, the laksa is good, so is the nasi lemak.Plenty of place to seat inside or outside. It can be congested during weekends especially during dinner time.

Small place well-known since Gordon Ramsay went there during one of his shows. It was just across our hotel. My husband found out about it while walking the street. He tried the famous laksa that he really enjoyed. We went back together the following day. Definitely a must-do in Singapore. Very tasty, a bit hot (they even give you extra sauce, but we didn't need it). A winner!

Definitely one of the best Laksa in Singapore. SGD5.5 for small bowl and SGD7.5 for big. So tasty and full of seafood in soup. However I shouldn't put a chili which covered the flavor. Otah is made by fish and coconut rice is dried. Maybe next time should try those steamed.Many people come because of its reputation, western and eastern.

The laksa is so tasty! They don't provide chopsticks so you eat with just a spoon as the noodle is cut. It's not a bad idea as you just eat more of the soup with it. Otah was nice. Place is very clean.

This was our first meal in Singapore. It's at the corner of Ceylon and East Coast Road. The place happily promotes that it has AC. Guess it would help out on those hot tropical days. Look for all the pictures of the owner(s) and random celebrities. If you have an issue with milk or coconut milk then this place may be your new arch nemesis. Your bowels will not be pleased if you decide to consume this. Our waiter gave us a whopping 2 seconds before asking what we wanted. I guess there's only laksa available because he asked us which size: small, medium, large. We went for the medium and the Amerrrrrrican in me felt like I should have asked for XL. He then asked if we're okay with shrimp and if we wanted the clam. The shrimp was fine but the clams are quite fishy. If you're not ready for a taste of the ocean sea life, don't ask for the clams. He also murmured some other appetizer which we said sure to. It ended up being this baked curry paste thing wrapped in a banana leaf. Pardon my ignorance if I can't recall the name of it or what it's exactly made of. Damn tourist, at least we gave it a shot and it was just aiight.Next, a random old man came up to us and asked us for drinks. Don't freak out if he asks you to pay on the spot. He's working out of some other stall that doesn't belong to 328 Katong Laksa. Get the barley drink, it's supposedly a Singaporean favorite and out of all the ones I've tried during my time in SG, this was probably one of the better ones. It's a great counter to intake with your laksa noodle soup.The laksa comes out quick and the presentation looks simple yet the smell will make you want to dive right in. All you are given is a spoon. Â They say they cut the white, thin, & round noodles enough where you can just spoon it out. I took it upon myself and grabbed some chopsticks elsewhere at broke tradition. Please don't punish me for it, I don't know any better. The coconut-curry soup base is rich and should be attacked immediately when it lands on your table while it's still steaming out of the pot. I'd recommend you adding some of that chili paste to give it a kick. It's really not spicy at all actually. The Thai in me wishes there was vinegar or lime wedges to go with the soup but I wasn't trying to be that picky. I think I killed the bowl within a few minutes. I'm still trying to distinguish if I was just hungry or if that bowl of noodles was just that legit. I'm going to say both. This place is probably known to the world as the joint Chef Gordon Ramsay stopped at. I guess that's why she chose it and I'm glad we checked it out because it was another enjoyable meal. It's a quick bite in a simplistic setting. I'm not surprised if it's cash only. We were lucky to stop by when it wasn't packed and I did notice other tourists meddling around. Â I'm now a fan of this curry laksa noodle stuff.

The soup is delicious with seafood taste. The otah and coconut rice is fine. People say it is the best laksa in Singapore. It is a little far away from downtown. If you have time to take a look in this area. You can come and have a try.

This is my new favorite hunt. Never really tried Katong Laksa before and it damn well blew our mind. We had 2 big bowls of Laksa, 2 otahs, chili crab bun and barbecue chicken bun. They all tasted amazing. Of course the laksa is a league on its own. Very creamy coconut gravy without overly powering. We added 4-5 of chilli packets and DAMN! We were in Laksa heaven! Every bite and slurp left us wanting for more and before we knew it we almost done with our bowl. I have always knew bout the joint and the owner since she is a well known food celebrity and have always seen her on tv when I was young. Never really thought of going to this joint till today. Well she definitely deserved that celebrity status for this bowl of laksa that she created. The Otahs was served piping hot and it tasted really good. I might get smashed in the face for saying that otah is better than Mexican tamale. But I still gonna say it no matter what. The service was top top. The guy at the counter was really friendly and sweet. Overall we had a totally wonderful experience eating this out-of-this-world Singaporean classic. Thank you 328 for your great food and kind service. You guys made our bellies really happy.

They used to be good. Since their renovation, I can only say this:If you're going to renovate & raise prices, ensure that your portions and quality of food remains or at least improve. Not many places to find decent Laksa today might have lead to many of the "good reviews" but frankly they used to be much better. They used to care more and well, from someone who have lived right next to the store for years, you could taste it too. Otah is Otah. Hard to go wrong. But the laksa soup/broth/curry was poor, the ingredients overall were poor, flavour was boring and so on. And for those prices... no no no.

$5 SGD ($3.48) will get you a small and filling bowl of laksa consisting of spicy seafood and coconut broth, cut mee hoon (rice vermicelli), shrimp, mussels/clams, and sliced fish cake. Beware, it is quite spicy. Tip - make sure you get the lime juice too and don't ask for chopsticks (you eat with a spoon). Fast service. Highly recommend.
Had small Laksa and Tiger beer...spicy and delicious. Stop at this place each trip! The fish and chili crab dumpling were good as well.
Not very Delicious. Just the usual run-of-the-mill laksa. Portion is very small. Trying to be elitist but not quite making it.

My first experience with Laksa and it is tasty! The bowl of noodles with coconut based spicy broth had a very nice flavor and bite. I can see how one can get addicted or develop a love for it like jook or ramen. Nice little joint w/AC and serving the famous Singapore lime juice.

Great laksa in a modest setting. Variations are either small or large bowl. Had a small for $5.5 SGD which was enough for a light dinner. Good balance between curry, coconut, seafood flavors, with a touch of heat. Did not add the included packet of samba chili sauce because the flavor profile was already so enjoyable, I did not want to change the balance.

Delicious laksa but don't ask or look for chopsticks cos you're not suppose to eat it with chopsticks. Only a soup spoon to get the full flavor of the spices in the soup. Must be a baba cook in the kitchen.

Above all else, Singapore is known for its insanely good, diverse, and thriving food culture. It should carry some weight, then, when I say that after three extensive trips to the country (each with a top priority and extensive research of dining), that this is the best dish I've had. To add further merit, I should mention that I'm allergic to shrimp/prawn and yet I still seek this place out multiple times during my limited stays, braving the hives and puffy-eyed-ness, because it's seriously That Good.Be sure to pair the dish with some white barley juice ("bah-lee"), and get the leaf-wrapped fish cake (?). Most locals seem to enjoy adding clams to the main dish, but it's a bit too strong on the ocean notes for my liking.

Lovely laksa, although I prefer mine a little spicier. Really good balance of flavours and I have never had "otah" before. I wish we could get otah in Sydney Highly recommend this place for a beautiful, filling meal with bags of flavour.
Creamy awesomeness in a bowl! If you're in the area and craving some laksa head here and you won't be disappointed!

Lovely laksa, although I prefer mine a little spicier. Really good balance of flavours and I have never had "otah" before. I wish we could get otah in Sydney Highly recommend this place for a beautiful, filling meal with bags of flavour.

I came here a few times to enjoy the spicy Laska which is supposed to be the better ones over here. There are a few branches of this in Singapore and from what I heard, this is the best. You can choose to sit either indoors or outdoors, of course with Singapore's kind of weather, indoors is the only option for me. Enjoying the hot bowl of Laska with a cold drink of Barley is definitely satisfying for me. I often choose the $5 bowl which is enough to satisfying my hunger. The noodles in the Laska is sliced to small pieces which means a pair of chopsticks is not required and you can just enjoy with a spoon. It's has a strong flavour and every spoonful of it makes me want more, that's how I felt especially on my last trip there. For foreigners, you should come by to try at least once, get the feel of enjoying one of Singapore's popular dishes. Overall, I find this to be my liking and definitely give my thumbs up to those thinking of trying.

I have been wanting laksa for the past week and we finally got to eat at a laksa shop! The shop itself is rather small, but could house up to 20-30 guests. My husband order the 3 small bowls of the laksa. He also ordered lime juice for himself and luohan longan for me. My mother-in-law was also with us, but she prefered something warm, but the shop does not offer anything warm so she did not want a drink. The order comes right out once he places his order and he brought all the laksa and drinks on a tray to our table. The laksa only comes with a spoon, there's no forks or chopsticks at this shop. I wanted a pair of chopsticks or fork because my noodles were quite long and each time I scoop up the noodles and toppings, all of the noodles would slide right off and only the toppings were left. Eventually I managed to look for the shorter noodles in my bowl and enjoyed those first. Which was pretty good, because there were slices of squid/cuttlefish. There were also small clam-like things in the laksa as well. I was not a fan of those and scoop most of them out for my husband, since he enjoys eating them. It's a good thing we occasionally like different things, because I could eat what he doesn't like and he can eat what I don't like. This shop only sells a couple of items on the menu and the main dish would of course be laksa. It would have been nice if there's more variety to laksa like the toppings or more different seasoning. I do like how they posted pictures of celebrities and famous people, on the wall, that had visited the shop back in the days. I could recognize some of the celebrities and it's nice to know they had been here one time, long ago.

surprisingly fantastic laksa in katong, one of a couple famous places serving this dish. I have eaten laksa less times than the fingers on one hand, but, this was delicious.the coconut milk mellowed the savoury base into this rounded, creamy soup with an unexpected lightness, and the tender noodles were slippery bits that worked its way between the fresh prawns and cockles. I certainly didn't expect to enjoy it nearly this much, and the just-on-the-edge sour of the lime juice was pretty perfect.the small coffeeshop space is fully air-conditioned, which is fantastic considering the heat and spiciness of the dish, but that luxury does reflect itself in its price. little matter though, as it honestly is more filling than whatever you'd receive at a newfangled cafe for the money, and is likely executed with more skill and finesse anyway.worth a visit, and definitely worth the money.
First time for Katong Laksa! We went there before noon on weekday. With only a few people sitting inside, we didn't wait at all. So far the best Laksa ever! Deftly will go back again.
Nice laksa, quick service and efficient, easy and nothing fancy, hawker food. Otah is very nice, nasi lemak nice.
Spicy seafood soup that is loaded with seafood. Be prepared to eat everything with a spoon and don't bother asking for a fork or chopsticks. Soup has a very similar taste to Thai dishes, but hotter.

If Bourdain liked it... then it's good enough for me! So we tried 328 Katong Laksa on East Coast Road in Singapore - especially since our hotel was across the street. This place has a reputation for making THE best Malaysian laksa around. It was. And just the way Singaporeans love their food. Spicy hot portions at street hawker prices. Grab an ice cold lime juice to cool off all that hotness. The space was small and although they said they had "AirCon," it was a bit humid inside on the day we visited. There were at least 50 photos plastered on the walls, of celebrities who have slurped in these seats including Anthony Bourdain. But things may have changed since he's dined here. As I said before the laksa was good - with lots of noodles, cockles and prawns floating in a spicy chili and coconut broth. But the servers were mostly unresponsive. Think Soup Nazi - Asian style. But not just one. Many. I will also throw in here that most Singaporeans I have met or know as friends are warm and friendly, including the people working in the service industry. Most will smile and hand you back your Singaporean dollars with both hands - something so simple and polite - yet you don't see that exchange happening much in the states. I would have given them 5 stars if I were only rating on the laksa. But management clearly needed to offer the staff some Emily Post classes!

I had no idea what laksa was, but after reading some good yelp reviews decided to check this place out as it's near the hotel and open on a weekday morning. Absolutely loved it! Savoury cocunutty broth with just enough spice to wake you up, and little noodles perfect for eating with just a spoon. Add in some seafood in the form of various fish cakes and you've got yourself a winner. A must try for even the most confused tourist!

I have visited Singapore 9 times when my boyfriend was studying there. While he is at school, I would explore the area (Singapore is quite small) looking for some fun food to eat. I first came to know Laksa and loooooooved it when I studied in Sydney, Australia but I had to try it Singapore where it came from.This place tho... Maybe I was hungry after walking so much looking for this place, Maybe there was something in that humid Singapore air. ......whoa literally blew my mind.The best laksa ever and it is CHEAP!
Best laksa I've ever had. Spicy! Put Ota on top. Get the lemon juice. Guy at the cashier could be a bit more inviting though. Smile! It's free.

Love this place. If you are in Singapore you have to try laksa. The laksa is so amazing it's a perfect bowl of thick rice noodles in a creamy seafood stock and lots of spices. The prepared chili paste adds great flavors to the soup. The herb, a Vietnamese cilantro is also a signature of this dish its unique flavor is wonderful.

Singaporean laksa is different from the Malaysian kind - much more 'lemak' and noodles and typically the rice noodles instead of the egg noodles. That being said, I think that the 328 katong laksa is really good with a good curry broth. They don't have much selection of anything else so laksa is pretty much all you are going to get
...bus da leeeeps...incredible wonder in a beautifully ancient building...combined with a chilled Tiger beer you will be set...
Creamy awesomeness in a bowl! If you're in the area and craving some laksa head here and you won't be disappointed!
the best laksa. period. the broth is so flavorful and deep and creamy. make sure to add the chilli, as it really imparts some additional depth of flavor to the dish.

I supposed this has become a tourist attraction and gone are the days where cheap and good can go hand in hand. Â Was there only today and the guy said "no cockles ok? How can say not ok when you walked all the way there for a fix? Â so i said can discount ok? The guy stared at me and was about to tell me "NO SOUP FOR YOU!!! NOW GO!!!" Luckily i quickly said i was joking but he weren't too please. Anyway Chili is now in one small packet and there goes the other kick. Â So this is a real turn off given the price, the service, the chili etc. Â So looks like will have to head to Tangs food court for my fix going forward.
Spicy seafood soup that is loaded with seafood. Be prepared to eat everything with a spoon and don't bother asking for a fork or chopsticks. Soup has a very similar taste to Thai dishes, but hotter.
First time for Katong Laksa! We went there before noon on weekday. With only a few people sitting inside, we didn't wait at all. So far the best Laksa ever! Deftly will go back again.

Â They say they cut the white, thin, & round noodles enough where you can just spoon it out. I took it upon myself and grabbed some chopsticks elsewhere at broke tradition. Please don't punish me for it, I don't know any better. The coconut-curry soup base is rich and should be attacked immediately when it lands on your table while it's still steaming out of the pot. I'd recommend you adding some of that chili paste to give it a kick. It's really not spicy at all actually. I'm still trying to distinguish if I was just hungry or if that bowl of noodles was just that legit. I'm going to say both. This place is probably known to the world as the joint Chef Gordon Ramsay stopped at. I guess that's why she chose it and I'm glad we checked it out because it was another enjoyable meal. It's a quick bite in a simplistic setting. I'm not surprised if it's cash only. We were lucky to stop by when it wasn't packed and I did notice other tourists meddling around. Â I'm now a fan of this curry laksa noodle stuff.
the best laksa. period. the broth is so flavorful and deep and creamy. make sure to add the chilli, as it really imparts some additional depth of flavor to the dish.

Katong is known for it's Laksa. I ended up going to this cute little joint after a long day hanging out and doing unfinished business. My family friends from church Â told me that I should go to this place on the East side and it was delicious. no one can make southeast Asian in this condition. I have always wanted to try Laksa and not bad for a head start. It has beaten how I make it at home. The only problem is not that bad but there was no boost in flavor. Other than that it was really worth my Singapore dollars

I love this 328 Katong Laksa's location.This might not be the original location but for me as long as I can have a great food and good services, I am happy! And with AC too!The lone waiter here is nice, patient and friendly. Answered all our questions and gave us good recommendations with a big smile.And of course the only reason here is for the laksa and that's the only thing offers in the menu with the only decision to made is the sizes. When I want to ask for a pair of chopsticks, my Yelp friend realized I did not read up on Katong laksa before my trip as "Katong laksa is a variant of laksa lemak from the Katong area of Singapore. In Katong laksa, the noodles are normally cut up into smaller pieces so that the entire dish can be eaten with a spoon alone, without chopsticks or a fork." *It is one of the most enjoyable laksa I have! The soup base is so rich with coconut and the hot sauce on the side just add the heat to the noodle itself. And eating with a spoon is just awesome as I probably have problem trying to pick up the slippery noodle with my chopsticks anyway.Silent while we enjoying our laksa... I will be happy to have one of this for lunch everyday..*Source from Wikipedia

address: 133 Pasir Ris Rd The Cove Singapore 519149 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Tue', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['Closed']), ('Sat', ['Closed']), ('Sun', ['3:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: Good location by the strait, but if you're hoping for crashing waves on the beach, this isn't the place. Â The place has good vibes, but no one greeted me at the front. Â They have an interesting choice in music (unfiltered rap?). Overall, a decent enough place by the park.

address: 133 Pasir Ris Rd The Cove Singapore 519149 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Tue', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['4:00 PM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['Closed']), ('Sat', ['Closed']), ('Sun', ['3:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: Rude server and food well wondering now...Shame as the setting is nice although music is probably a tad too loud.It started on the mediocre side when we asked for a Virgin Mojito which is not on the menu, but Mojito is on the menu as one of their key item, so as you can imagine extremely difficult to execute, simply don't pour the alcohol. Well ... not possible at Georges for some reason.Then they have 3 ciders on the menu, one of those is pear cider, I was asking whether the other 2 apple ciders were sweet or dry, the answer was this is apple so it is sweet ;-) Obviously good training here or simply lack of it. I ended up with an average cider at $15 a 500ml bottle.Then the "plat de resistance", when we ordered the food and among it a Beef Burger for which we were not asked for our cooking preference, weird, so we stated it: "please Medium Rare" and we were told that those burgers come only in "Well Done" which made me wonder whether Georges is pre-cooking the meat or whether it is even cooked on premises at all. Then of course it open a can of worms as what about the rest of the menu?But to add to our misery when the waiter responded, his answer was extremely dry along the line of "if you don't like it order something else" not even looking at us in the eyes.I must admit that it was too much, we decided to leave and told the waiter immediately.But cherry on the cake, even so the food was not even finished ordering as the waiter was still standing in front of us, he told me that he might charge me for the food if he didn't manage to cancel through his electronic device, I took it as a joke, not a funny one though. I paid the unfinished drinks and we left the premises to never come back again.My advice, plan for drinks definitely not for food...

address: Blk 1A East Coast Park #01-02 Singapore 449875 Singapore
comment: Located at the start of Parkland Green is Pick Me Up Cafe. They overlook the green field which had lots of families with young children playing frisbee and the sea. A great windy location. They have both indoor and outdoor seating with free wifi.Pick Me Up Cafe is geared more towards family oriented gatherings with young children, as they have kiddy play section at the entrance. They're not so much catered to the hipster crowd.Pick Me Up Cafe prides itself in serving all day dining breakfast, cold pressed juice, home-made yogurt gelato, coffee and all other hearty delights that's sure to pick you up!I found a groupon deal that offered a laser tag game for 5 and a family meal. After the laser tag game we were exhausted, sweaty and couldn't wait to eat dinner!1. Caesar SaladAll the food pretty much came at the same time which we were appreciated, since we were starving. The caesar salad was okay, but abit too much dressing. Veggies tasted fresh and the portion was good.2. Cajun Chicken PizzaWe had 2 pizzas and shared amongst 6 people, 3 guys, 3 girls. It was perfect! It was cheesy enough, the meat was tasty, but the crust, was a bit doughy. Could've been in the oven for a while longer.3. Tutti Frutti This tasted like watermelon juice with fresh coconut jelly in it, it was refreshing and great for us, as we were still trying to cool down from the adrenaline rush from the laser tag!4. Family Waffle $22.90+What makes Pick Me Up a healthier choice is their home-made yogurt gelato! The second we walked in, we took turns trying to pick what flavours we wanted, we were getting a waffle with 4 scoops of gelato!As it is SG50, they have an interesting variety of local flavours. We decided to try the butter pandan kaya.With Taro, Butter Pandan Kaya, Swiss Chocolate, Pistachio, we had our family waffle which was so pretty! There were generous with the toppings! I loved the fruitty pebbles and the waffle itself was crispy on the outside and fluffy like a moist cake on the inside.Perched on top of the family waffle is an caramelized almond bark. The Taro was our favourite as it was very creamy and didn't taste too artificial. The Butter Pandan Kaya tasted like a sea salt kaya, it was so good! I hope they sell this flavour with their regular offerings! The Pistachio and Swiss Chocolate were good as well.I definitely forsee myself coming back to try more gelato flavours.They also sell savoury waffles and all day breakfast sets!

Very nice and friendly service, pretty good food and great view as its in the round 9 floors up with lots of windows. Looks over the Toll Offshore Base but I'm an engineer so I like the birds eye view of other people's mechanical equipment ;)Coffee is from an automatic machine and is a little inconsistent plus I'm a snob so I'd give it 2.5 stars but hey it's a latte! Movenpick is the brand of beans.The pizza is delicious as well as the sandwiches. I really liked the buffalo wings. A bit of american comfort food. I heard the burger is quite good from my research so I will have to try that soon.They have a salad buffet that comes with your meal.Nice open space with a good ambience. It is air conditioned so good for business lunch where you have to wear pants.It's behind the security

A casual eatery serving good, Peranakan (Penang) food. Big & spacious with good service, so it's ideal for big groups of 20-40 pax. Must try their lunch specials ($5 onwards) & special weekday dinner sets for 2, 4 & 6 pax.My fav include: 1. Ngoh Hiong2. Sambal Wings3. Ayam Ponteh (chicken with potatoes)4. Fish cakes5. Beef Rendang6. Chinchalok Omelette7. Soy CendolSituated 5 min walk from Eunos MRT in MDIS Building, Changi Road. Open daily: 12noon - 10pm.

I love a hearty Peranakan meal in Joo Chiat! An eatery that serves delicious Peranankan food such as the cincalok egg, baby spinach soup and braised duck. They are flavourful and satisfying for the tastebud and the stomach. This is one place where I am sure to say I feel pleasantly at home.

Good flavour and very nice environment. Halal friendly so no pork used here and so some adaptation of dishes. The Chendol looks great on the picture and I would have tried if it's made with coconut milk rather than soy. The owner is a photographer and you get to enjoy his travel photos while dining. Overall a nice dining experience :-)

address: 106 Upper East Coast Rd Singapore 455296 Singapore
comment: Love the place here. Always a favorite with some of the nicest folks around. Â It's a 'cheers' type bar where everybody will eventually know your name. Beer is inexpensive. Â And the clients are mostly 'white' folks as oppose to the Asians. Best part about this place is that you don't have to 'play' pub games. Â The ladies at the bar is usually spoken for and its just a really good ol place to hang out and enjoy some nice company. ;)

address: 106 Upper East Coast Rd Singapore 455296 Singapore
comment: Very poor customer service. Called 20 times without getting any pick up. Never come to this bar!

address: 106 Upper East Coast Rd Singapore 455296 Singapore
comment: Dog & Bone is a neighbourhood pub with a primarily expat clientele. If I'm not wrong, the owner is an Englishman who has made the overall vibe here unlike a typically Singapore pub, which is very casual and unassuming. They show live games here such as cricket and Australian-rules football and rugby, which is refreshing as many pubs solely concentrate on airing soccer matches. The drinks are cheap and reasonable, with some English offerings as well, like Pimms and Boddingtons beer. Only downside is that it closes pretty early at 12-ish am for last drink orders, and they don't inform you for last orders.

address: 106 Upper East Coast Rd Singapore 455296 Singapore
comment: Great staff and a really friendly atmosphere. Â All walks of life are welcome even though most of the patrons are British. Â Stella Artois on tap and a large selection of beers and liquors reasonably priced for Singapore. Â Food is decent. Â I believe Thursdays is Thai night and the Thai food is amazing. Â Menu is mostly British food, but also includes a little American and Asian diversity. Â There is a dart board, and dart nights are Thursday. Â Would definitely recommend stopping in if you want to catch any sports or just chill and have a drink.

Great place to go for a delicious and well-priced meal. They are opened daily till 9.45 pm. A wide range of western dishes and Japanese Bento. The service is excellent, food is tasty and the variety is extensive. So glad I came here.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-43 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: After trying Wolf Burgers at Suntec and their pop-up store at Club Street, I was happy to hear that they opened a new outlet in Changi City Point and it seemed that I wasn't alone. I passed by several times during lunch hour, but skipped every time since the line was looooooooong.So one day, when I only had time to lunch around 2 pm, I decided to have another look since the lunch peak had already passed. Â I was pleased to see that there were still a decent amount of people having Wolf but also that there was one free table. I took one bite of my Wolf Burger and was happily in burger heaven- the quality of the burgers at Changi City Point is on Point (sorry for the pun). Â And just when I thought it couldn't get better, I tried the Kimchi cheese fries, and oh my, these were DELICIOUS!!! The only let-down is that they do not serve spiked milkshakes as they did in Club Street but the super friendly owner explained that they are keeping their options open so they can also serve a Halal public, so kudos for them being inclusive (and I don't drink during lunchtime on weekdays anyway).I doubted whether they are really worth 5 stars, as there are places which do a better burger but they charge you an arm and a leg. Wolf Burgers manages to do a VERY GOOD burger, their prices are affordable plus their service is excellent: they are quick and efficient and the owner is friendly... and that my friends, is rare in Singapore and deserves five star review.

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-43 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: It's great to come here with a bunch of friends, they've a great offer that you could make use of; 4 burgers, 4 sodas, and 2 fries for the grand total of $39.90! Imagine trying to find another great deal like this anywhere else!!!! They've another offer for free coffee with waffles. (have yet to try it tho) Another one for the first 50 per day to claim is burger + drink + fries for $9.90. Ps, all of the burgers are at least $9.90. Ordered the wolf burger, the buttermilk chicken, and the mushroom beef and honestly my burger, (wolf burger) was amazing. Meat was really tender, juices was flowing and there was fireworks in my mouth. the truffle fries is amazing; the smell is really powerful, you can taste the smell and it is pretty great too. the kimchi cheese fries were pretty good. everything was overpowering and flavours were really popping. 10/10 would come here again with my gang

address: 5 Changi Business Park Central 1 #01-43 Singapore 486038 Singapore
comment: Came across it by chance and I love it! Staff are helpful, food is delicious. Had the low carb version of the Alpha Burger (I think that's the name, can't quite remember), the one with the double patties (They put the patties in a salad bowl) and added $9 for an bottle of craft beer and fries. Pretty good value.
Eat to live...Regardless the service level, this is a decent place fot vegetarians to sit down and have a proper meal.A wide variety of local food turn vegetarian friendly.

I find the food really good. And very good quality. The prices are very reasonable as well. I find the service good enough for me, come on. It's like a hawker stall but they installed air conditioned room for diners to eat in. So please be reasonable. The food comes on time, but sometimes they will get your orders wrong. But I don't really mind, as all their food is always good. Unless they serve me something I don't eat then.... I'll reject.All in all, good food, great vibes and a satisfying dinner.

5 stars for their Chee Cheong Fun that comes in several versions and my top pick is the curry pork skin or shredded chicken which has great flavour and kick. It's freshly made onsite and better than anything else I have had in SG and will put the ones served in most Tim Sum places including big restaurants to shame.Other food items including the bean curd are also nice. All reasonably priced and great value.

Located at the junction of Telok Kurau & Changi Road, along a row of shophouses, Anson Town serves up its famous chee cheong fun (rice noodle roll), especially with curry gravy & either shredded chicken, deep fried pig skin, or mushroom minced meat. For those who like something spicier, they can try the curry mee (noodles) or the Ipoh dry curry hor fun/mee. Their yam cake is a must try, usually mixed with your choice of sweet and/or chilli sauce.

Mmmm! My family's go-to for yam cake for breakfast. Can't comment on the location because I simply woke up to this takeaway box (yay bliss), but my parents usually park nearby to buy it. I love love this yam cake. Made on the premises and topped with sesame seeds and crisp shallots, it is soft, chunky with yam bits, and goes well with the sweet sauce or chili too. Some other places I've tried taste more chewy or gummy and therefore more synthetic, but you can just taste the difference in freshness. Each hunk of yam is also tall and generous but you'll get through it faster than you expect! Since we started buying from here, no other yam cake place compares. I would give it 5 stars if the chee Cheong fun and other dishes are as outstanding as this - I look forward to trying them next time!

First time try Anson Town. This restaurant gave me very nice, comfort and clean feeling. I was ordered cold beancurd and durian beancurd too. The taste was very nice and smooth. I would recommend you guys come and try.

We always passby this restaurant. Â One day we stopped to look at the menu. So today we decided to give a try. Surprisingly, the fresh beers that are locally brewed are very refreshing and good. Â We tried the lychee flavoured and mild roasted malt flavoured beers. Â Nice! The all for one platter was great. Â Two big sausages of your choice (veal, pork and chicken). We tried the pork and cheese chicken sausages. Â They juicy and nice. Â The pork sausages were a bit spicy but we liked it. Â  There were fried chicken wings, potato wedges and fried mushroom. Â The platter was served with 2 different types of chillies. Â The sweet chilli sauce and the sambal type which went very well with wings. Â There was mustard and honey custard that that went well with the mushroom. Â  The staffs are friendly and the food was served fast. We would definitely come back to try out the rest of the dishes. Cheers!

address: 16 Bedok South Rd #01-213 Bedok South Market and Food Centre Singapore 460016 Singapore
comment: This is one of my staple. The soup has depth, rich, and flavoursome. The choice , quality, and doneness of the noodles are very good.

This place does serve a decent tonkatsu that rivals the well-known tonkatsu joints in the CBD and along Orchard Road.You can choose between pork loin (rosu) or pork fillet (hire) or fried seafood like shrimp, oysters (kaki) and fish. Rosu is fattier, and the cut of pork that comes with a strip of fat on the side. Hire is the leaner cut of pork tenderloin. At least in my experience, the katsu comes out consistently fried every time. The bread crumbs are fluffy, extremely crispy and not over fried, pork is moist and tender inside. Skip ordering the other stuff like sushi and sashimi, as they seem to specialize in katsu, or you might get disappointed. The menu also states that their chef is Singaporean, but trained and certified in Japan, working in many high-end establishments before returning home.The only issue here is the slow service. The menu states outright that they will not rush your order, to maintain food quality. They are short handed with only one wait staff out front and the chef at the back. Which explains the other one star reviews...I guess if you're here just for fried pork tenderloin and aren't in a hurry, you won't be disappointed. If it's raw fish you're after, you might be better off crossing the street...

I love my tonkatsu, so I was happy to discover a place nearby me that is dedicated to this deep fried pork goodness. However, I find this place a bit strange, as every time I pass by it always seems to be closed.One weekday evening, my husband and I finally caught this place open. There weren't too many patrons, and only 2 people working. We could tell because the kitchen is pretty much open, with a huge window that separates the kitchen from the dining area. There was only one chef and one server.The menu is pretty good, as there are lots of different sets you can choose from. As it was our first time there, we opted with the norm. I chose the tonkatsu curry, which totally hit the spot- the pork cutlet had a deep golden colour, was crispy, and the meat was juicy! The soup was typical, nothing to Yelp about, and I did like the refreshing watermelon slices at the end. Prices were good- not cheap but not extremely expensive.This place serves a solid tonkatsu, but I do worry about it. There's signage everywhere that says they will not rush your order even if you ask, as they feel they can't produce the best tonkatsu that way. And with only one server and one cook, it must be quite difficult to manage a full house, especially during lunch. Hopefully these guys can stay alive and hire help, as I really do like their food!

Very few foods give me as much satisfaction as Tonkatsu, so when I saw first Katsuya on the East Coast Road strip, I was naturally excited. Relative to other Tonkatsu places, I've tried: Saboten, Saboten Express, and Teppei Syokudo in Millenia walk, I find Katsuya to be in the middle of the pack -- Better than Saboten Express, but falls short of Saboten and Teppei Syokudo.I'm a repeat customer and order usually one of two dishes: (i) Rosu Set - Pork Loin Katsu Set (Bread Crumb and Deep fried) and (ii) the Rosu Katsudon (Katsu served on an egg rice bowl & Tojio). The Pork Loin, unlike other Katsu places, has a huge layer of fat. This could be a huge turn-off for some people, but I actually prefer it as it makes the Katsu more tender. However, I feel that Katsu skin could be a lot crunchier / more breaded. Unfortunately, I've had some Katsu orders that were a little soggy. Â As for the Rosu Katsudon, the taste is what you would normally get from a top-notch Katsudon. However, where Katsuya's Katsudon falls short is for whatever reason is that rice layer underneath the Katsudon is filled with the liquid droppings from the Katsu and egg. I love my rice dry, especially when the restaurant uses high quality Japanese rice. However, if the rice soaked with with liquid, you can't really taste / feel the quality of the rice. Â Overall, if you have a Katsu craving and are anywhere near the Katong, this restaurant will surely satisfy your craving. Unfortunately, you will have to drop pretty penny with dishes averaging $25 a pop.

Best hire tonkatsu I've ever had, at a price that's reasonable. The katsu was not oily yet still juicy. The thickness is just right such that each bite is full of flavor and isn't dry. This place is a real gem. Highly recommended if you love tonkatsu.

Together with my Japanese food loving friends, we trudged to this place. I liked the simple dÃ©cor of the place and the calm interior.We arrived during dinner time so the place was quite packed, but we managed to find a seat quite easily. The first thing that we noticed about the menu here is that the food consisted of mainly fried stuff. I am a lover of fried stuff so this is perfectly okay for me, but those who don't like fried stuff might want to take note.Anyway, among the things that we ordered include the Rosu Katsu, Hire Katsu, Ebi and Dory fry, beef katsu and others that I can't remember. All the fried stuff here was great, but the star of the show is no doubt the katsu don, which was absolutely delicious. Highly recommended!

This is a review of a lunch with a colleague at Katsuya.Once before, we had come to this area for lunch. Â However, we were hit by our Monday jinx and most of the restaurants were closed.We came back on a different day and, after checking out the row of restaurants, we selected Katsuya.tinyurl.com/cpk7q7qThe ambiance is simple but the dark colour-tones for the walls, furniture, and flooring provide a sleek and modern feel. Â The restaurant was not very busy.tinyurl.com/cyaytkzThe service was very friendly. Â She was helpful and attentive. Â This was a nice break from the "just take your order and bring your food" service we often see at lunch. Â The food was very good.Cheesy Chicken Katsu Set - This was very tasty. Â The chicken was crisp on the outside. Â It was tender on the inside. Â Oh, plus, it was oozing with melted cheese. Â The portion was relatively good Â I do wish they offered an alternative to the big heap of cabbage on the side. Â The rice was well prepared and the miso soup was also good. Â All of the food was neatly presented.tinyurl.com/d32vf6lLamb Katsu Set - This was my colleagues lunch. Â It looked quite appetizing.tinyurl.com/cu8sgjaReceipt (Lunch for 2 - $53.10)Personally, I thought, for what it was, the prices were a bit high. Â There is the basic cost for the katsu ($12 to $20) depending on the selection. Â Then, there is $5 to make it a set. Â This only adds rice and miso soup. Â That means there set lunches range between $17 and $25. Â The food is good. Â But frankly, the basic katsu price should include the rice and soup. Â Luckily for me, my colleague was picking up the tab.tinyurl.com/d99du4dOverall - The ambiance and service are both positives. Â The food is freshly made and quite flavourful. Â However, for a relatively basic lunch, the prices are a little on the high side. Â I do think the ambiance and service also make Katsuya an option for casual dinners.

I am personally a Katsu person! I could practically eat Tonkatsu everyday ;DIt's like the previous feedback.. the food may be alittle X but for the quality and the assurance that my food are prepared in a clean kitchen.. I ate my Lamb Katsu(perfect timing) with a piece of mind. HAHAHA. My family and I really like their Katsu as they use only Sunflower oil.. It really tasted like how the chef Kervin described.. "Light & Crispy not feeling overwhelmed after 2plates or more.... " We didn't had Wine... but had Sake instead.. also noticed that their beverages are at a pretty decent price too. I recommend people who like Tonkatsu like myself.. to try this small restaurant. It changes your concept for deep fried katsu. I will patronized them again... no doubt.Kanpai~~~

Live ard the area for 30 years & yet only discover this place for its good indian food & kueh tutu! This coffeeshop looks untidy, and around the same area there are many other coffeeshops too. It is quiet compared to the rest, i guess thats why we never bothered. No idea why its call afghanistan but it only serve malay & indian food. Must try: nan, satay, kueh tutu.
Nice place for daily lunch. Naan and mutton great here! The price is good for daily lunch. Clean and nice environment. But quit crowded lunch time.
Food very nice! I very love their black pepper crabs and hokkien mee. Staff very friendly and enviroment is comfortable. I will be back

Located less than a 5 minute walk from Aljunied MRT is KL Delight Seafood Restaurant. Opened just 6 months ago, this new business is not a newcomer to the restaurant business. Owner, Nelson shared that he used to run and operate a coffee shop in Toa Payoh selling Chinese Rice and also Chinese Tze Char, and now he has moved to a full-fledged restaurant, while maintaining the same chef and kitchen crew.The menu has something for everyone, seafood items with prawns, squids, mussel/clams, sea cucumbers and mantis prawns are some of the eye-catching menu items for it. It's so hard not to look at the beautiful pictures on the right, screaming "ORDER US!"There's a list of cooking styles for crabs, the one that stood out for us was the "Malaysian Kam Heong" style. Nelson also recommended us to try their salted egg crab, which is a family favourite. The crabs are priced at $68/KG for the night we visited and they are also running a promotion of $48 for 2 crabs (500-600g each)For fish dishes, you can choose between Red Grouper, Sea Bass, Black Grouper and even Cod, each has it's own seasonal price. 1. Deep fried white bait with spices salt $12/$18/$24 This makes a great snack for any meal, the right amount of flour was applied to the white bait, making it extremely crisp and airy. It carried a nice aroma of spices, but with no spiciness to it.2. KL Hokkien Noodles $6/$9/$13My personal favourite of the night, I'm the kind that loves burnt noodles aka noodles with a ton of wok hei. The KL Hokkien noodles here are thick, with a chewy noodle texture along with a thin layer of oily sauce coating the noodles evenly. There is a mix of vegetables, egg and prawns. I definitely see myself coming back for more of this!3. Deep fried fish skin with salted egg $12/$18/$24A rather new tze char item that seems to be popping up in eateries all over is salted egg fried fish skin. The fish skin are very thin, making them crisp and enjoyable. The salmon skin were dusted with salted egg powder Â and then deep fried, making them savoury with a pleasant lingering salty aftertaste. The characteristic salted egg flavour was distinct but faded gradually.4. Wok fried crab with spices in "Malaysia Kam Heong" styleThis was one huge crab! The pincers were huge and plump with meat! . Kam Heong, literally translated to mean "golden fragrant", it does indeed come with a fragrance unique to the dish which I think I shall attribute to the presence of the curry leaves. Very often, I noticed fried crabs, carry the taste of the spices on the crab shell, but the crab meat can taste rather bland. Â Aromatic in nature, Â due to the dried shrimps, chilies, curry powder, shallots and garlic. Elaborated on the whole yet not too overwhelming that it conceals the freshness of the crabs within.The aroma of the Kam Heong is rather sweet, than spicy. The crab meat for me, was plentiful but I felt that they might have fried the crab for too long, as the crab meat seemed to have shrunk a bit within the shell.5.
