Deep fried & wok fried crab with salted egg yolk $48/pair (500-600gm each) Salted egg crabs are usually a signature for crabs and with the promo going on, it very enticing to try it! At 500-600g per crab, it's alot smaller than the Kam Heong crab, but it is still filled with lots of juicy and succulent crab meat that absorbed the salted egg flavour very well! The salted egg aroma was subtle but vivid in taste. Overall, I think this would make a great crab option for family with kids, who cannot afford to try the spicier crab cooking style.6. Sea Bass steamed in Nyonya style $30/kg (600-700gm each)The Â fish they used was absolutely fresh like still swimming in the curry fresh. Usually curries can afford to use older fish because the heavy curry spice would cover up the scent. At KL Delight Seafood, the curry is milder and light, unveiling the fresh taste of the fish.7. Mantis Prawn Wok fried with minced garlic and chilli powder in "Hong kong" style $20/$30/$40 The fried mantis prawn was lightly battered, with give each prawn a thin perimeter of crunchiness, along with a juicy prawn meat in the center. They were generous with the portion of prawns and with the minced garlic and chilli powder. You could easily detect the flavours of the minced garlic in every bite of the mantis prawn. This would make a great starter even for those who can't take spicy foods! Pretty addictive!8. Deep fried yam ring (Dice chicken with cashew nut) $16 or $32Served with overflowing chicken and cashew nuts. I was looking forward to this as I'm a huge fan of Yam Ring. It was slightly crispy on the surrounding and the yam was of the right consistency, the flavour of the yam could've been more pronounced as I felt that it was a tad too bland. The chunks of juicy chicken meat however tasted much better with a distinct sweetness covering the entire chicken!

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: Great simple food. Â Like many lunch places, not too clean. Â The food is fresh and pretty good. Â Very popular and there is often a line. Â Either come early or go late to miss the rush.Most of the dishes include bone in meat. Â This is fine, but can be a little messy to eat. Â Don't be afraid to use you fingers here. Â It's all part of the experience.

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: People is crowded in the shop and it is very hot. I order the soup and trotter. It is vey good taste and will visit again next time

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: Good food, reasonable price.Best Bak Kut Teh dish in Singapore. Â Try both the loin and normal ribs - same flavor, different texture. Â Order some veggies on the side, it completes your meal. Â Lime juice and/or barley to wash it all down. Â Definitely worth coming back to.

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: Good food! The spicy pork belly and soup are delicious.Excellent customer service. Will definitely comeback.

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: If you are in a meeting at work and look outside to discover there is a Song Fa opening next door, I think you should do a dance.This is what happened to me. Â Well, I admit it, I did not dance, not on the outside anyway. Â But, I was quite pleased.Along with aa colleague, I finally went to check it out.The service was fast and professional. Â Our order was quickly taken and the food arrived almost immediately. Â They came around to top off the broth a couple of times.It is a nice room. Â It has a warm feel to it. Â This is helped by the fact that it is full of people happily devouring bak ku teh for lunch.tinyurl.com/9zu2pantinyurl.com/8unmrfoWhen we arrived, we were quickly seated. Â It was quite busy. Â We found out later that we were lucky to arrive when we did. Â Because, while we were enjoying our bak ku teh, a lineup had formed outside.tinyurl.com/8z37u4fBak ku teh - So, what about it? Â Is it as good as the other Song Fa's? Â I've only been to one other one. Â I am happy to say that the bak ku teh was the same yummy goodness. Â It is heaven in a bowl.i do not know how prices compare to other outlets. Â Each time I've been to Song Fa, someone else paid Â Yep, that's right. Â My heaven in a bowl has been free.I will definitely be returning. Â I hope I am able to dodge the queues. Â But, if not, this is worth a little wait. Â It seems like such a simple dish. It is so so good though.

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: This place is really good specializing in a specific kind of pork rib soup that they just keep refilling. The staff and service is prompt. So cheap this is a winner.

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: Great place for simple comfort food. The liver is very good, the trotter too. The service is efficient and polite. Very popular for lunch.

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: Song FA only allowed us to refill the soup twice and they hurried us off when we were about to finish our lunch.. The ba kut Tey is not cooked properly and the pork taste lingers... The standard of ba kut teh is really not there..

address: UE Bizhub East - North Tower East 6 Changi Business Park Ave 1 Singapore 486017 Singapore
comment: Song Fa nails the peppery garlic flavour of the Bak Kut Teh and their service is rather efficient. Their fresh and cool water chestnut drink is the perfect accompaniment to the hot broth and don't forget to order in a side dish of Yoo Tiao.

address: 311 New Upper Changi Rd #02-03/04 Singapore Singapore
comment: Smells like children's feet because of the student, and NSmen discounts which make it appealing for them to dine here. It's really loud with chitter chatter, seats are cramped and limited due to its popularity. Free iced water is a plus, but I dislike the communal cutlery station. It makes me wonder if any dirty grubby fingers have been in there. Food is very appealing, however. So if you do not mind the crowd that hangs in this diner, you should be very happy to dine in this establishment.

Pleasant surprise. Brunch menu is really good. Everything is safe bet. I love they tweak things around. For example, they wrap pineapple with bacon. (Normally it comes with tomato at other places) Â Just like their "lab" concept, it seems like every menu has interesting component that you would never see at typical brunch menu. I will definitely come back.

After the good experience we had the week before, we decided to come back here to try their burgers. Da bomb burger would win an instagram competition for burgers if there was one! So I had to try it!1. Da Bomb Burger $19+For a 250g of beef patty, this sure is a huge burger, to finish this off as one person, you must be starving to death! The egg was running and it presented very nicely on an IKEA chopping board, the fries however were very salty.Both burgers came with super salty fries, my suggestion if you don't want to get bloated from drinking water from the beakers, is tell them LESS SALT on the fries.2. The Club Burger $19+The chicken was very juicy and succulent, it was very marinated and grilled. I enjoyed it as much as I had enjoyed the Da Bomb. Both are good choices for burgers here! The side salad had watermelon cubes in there, though they were not sweet, it was a refreshing change from the normal cucumbers.Both da bomb and the club seen side by side, they look normal sized, but in person, they're pretty huge. For the price, I find it reasonable.3. Red Velvet Cake 6.50+At 4pm on a saturday, this was already the last slice of red velvet cake, this goes to show how popular this cake is! It was moist and the cream cheese was slightly salty, the sweetness of the cream cheese was just alright, not too overpowering. But you could feel gerlat eating this cake all by yourself. So share the calories!4. Meatballs $10+$10+ for 6 meatballs, pretty pricey if you ask me, but the cheese was well baked over the meatballs. The meatballs were most probably deep fried before getting baked, as the exterior were really crispy!The marinara sauce for the meatball was perfect, pretty sure you could eat fries with this sauce too, it wasn't too salty.Water is served here in beakers :) an interesting touch for a "Lab"For each customer, you get one test tube of complimentary fruit juice, all the juices tasted weird and we couldn't tell what colour was what juice, even after tasting. Mostly because all were too diluted?

Oh my gosh the CUTEST place ever in the middle of nowhere. These people kind of expect you to take a billion photos so they have props all over your table to use (stethoscopes, little paper crowns etc.) Â + Free Wifi! (FFL_Guest, PW: freshfruitslab)+ Complimentary test tube of FRUIT JUICE per person + All the drinks are laboratory equipment themed. Your juice comes in flasks, water in beakers. + Bathroom is outside around the corner - not the cleanest or brightest.. )+ Afternoon Tea: 3pm-5pm Tuesdays and Wednesdays only+ Lunch Specials: 11-2pm Weekdays (pretty good deal) I came here on a Friday afternoon and honestly absolutely loved this place. It has great tasting food, juice and cakes. I ordered the lunch special - 12 sgd for a quinoa greek salad and some chicken main dish. Super tasty and worth the price yum. The Lychee cake that everyone seems to get here - eh, I could have done with out it. I didn't find it super special. It was just.. alright. Service: -1 star for the service. I suppose they employee young high school aged girls but they spent too much time looking at their phones rather than if people needed anything. Seriously was so difficult to get their attention away from their phones. Hello people..

3rd stop for food hunt day - 17th Jan 2015.Was pretty crowded when we reached this place nearer to 4pm. Was given an outdoor seat as it was packed on the inside and we had to switch seat as the scorching sun pointed directly at where we were seating. The main dishes looks good on the social media so the five of us shared the Da Bomb and The Club burgers as well as meatballs for the side dish. Depending on what you get, the prices are definitely on the steep side.For the burgers, they are juicy and tasty (all the ingredients mixed with the buns). There were sides of fries on the wooden board (serving plate) and the fries were too salty. Had only three pieces of that and I am still feeling dryness on the throat and thirstiness even a day later. The meatballs were cooked rightly. It was not too much and the tomato based as well as the layer of cheese on its top was a good combination for moisting the beef balls. No picture on it as it wasn't a photo friendly dish.I also tried the Tokio tea. According to the menu, it is one of the lab's recommended beverage and looking at the fruity description, I ordered this to try it out. For the price, it was a little on the pricier end but I would probably go for a cold beverage if I visit this place a second time.We also tried the Red Velvet cake. It was pretty moist and would recommend it to others. Towards the end of the meals, we were given juices to sample in test-tubes. Not sure what tastes they were but I got the orange flavored one. Oh yes, and the iced water came in conical flasks or beakers (glad that I finally remembered the name for the flask).The interior design was unique as it was science related. There are also interesting facts about fruits and its benefits on one of the walls. Quite a nice place to wind down the week if there are less crowds.

Thoroughly enjoyed my family Sunday lunch. The food was scrumptious, service was prompt and the ambiance was pastel and light, fit for a relaxing Sunday afternoon right from church. Will definitely be one of my future frequent joints.
My wife's favorite pancakes.Breakfast is very good and concept is cute.Overall good experience. Try their fruit juices. Really fresh

Great awesome place to hangout in the middle of nowhere! Take about 20 minutes to get to the location, especially in this hot hot weather. More convenient if you drive, but there is limited parking space. They served complimentary fruit juice in a test tube, interesting and nice touch to make me feel welcomed!Ambiance is pretty good, the placed is filled with little trinkets of toys to entertain if you have kids or for the young at heart guest! I had a fun time playing with my childhood toy. There food is quite nice, ordered their truffle fries but the truffle is not evenly distributed. Halfway to my pail of fries, there is no more truffle taste, just normal fries. I do like their breakfast menu, their sausage, eggs are pretty good too and comes with fruit salad as sides. Overall pretty good place to hangout for Sunday brunch, staff are nice and friendly.
Good choices. Great atmosphere. We sat out and the weather made it a great way to spend Sunday morning. Egg florentine was very nice. So was the pumpkin soup. Juices and sodas are great too.

Amazing! Absolutely love this place.I was early for an interview and was walking around and spotted this cafe on the corner of the road and decided to check it out. And it had Wifi!Such a nice atmosphere when you walk in. Not freezing cold or two hot, quiet and a nice place to work but also a great place I would want to go to with friends. The customer service is brilliant, the food came so fast and was by far one of the best meals I had! Coffee was brilliant. I really recommend this place (get the pumpkin salad and the mocha). Will have to come back and make this a regular (even if it takes an hour MRT ride). Also only 5-10 minutes from an MRT. Again, love this place!

This place just opened on 31 December 2012. I think he used to or still is operating a famed minced pork noodles at West Coast under the same name.They only sell mee pok. Plus they have their homemade knife fish fish cake which you have to order separately. Great al dente mee pok. The chili is not too spicy and comes with a good dose of vinegar.They also have a small variety of side dishes like herbal whole steamed chicken, smoked duck, wanton soup.Shop is located right to next to the Tanjong Rhu Pao place at Guillemard Road. A bit of a parking hell and a little out of the way.

address: 9 Upper East Coast Rd #01-01 Singapore 455203 Singapore
comment: I must first admit that my choice to dine here was because I couldn't find seats for my party of 8 at the eleventh hour!! And they don't have a "no outside cake policy". The last time I ate at Pasta Fresca was about 15 years ago and why the long no-show. Well, in my opinion, their pasta was getting too expensive for the average taste that they provide. Â Plus they were no longer the only pasta place around and I could get cheaper for better. Oh well, fast forward 15 years and I read pretty decent reviews and decided to try again. And I must say, my faith is restored. While I'm not gonna say they have the best-est pasta in Singapore, they are pretty darn good. We had:* Vongole Pescatora (Tomato) - a most delightful clam soup! Made me wanna re-create it at home!* Polpa Di Granchio with Linguine - crabmeat pasta in tomato sauce which was really really good! We ordered food to share and this dish just disappeared in seconds! I didn't even have a chance with seconds (pun fully intended!!) * Lasagne Gratinate Emil - I thought the taste was nice. A kinda mild taste. Not bad or anything. Just mild. Forgettable tho. * Prama Ham Pizza - generous serving of ham slices. Good. * Capricciosa Pizza - one of the recommended pizzas and I do agree. It's has a bit of everything so it's good. * Mascarpone Pizza - apparently a new addition to the menu. I like it! I like how the drops of mascarpone cheese balances the saltiness of the Parma ham slices. Easily my best pizza of the nightService is attentive and no charges for water (yay!). They even provided plates and spoons for our "outside" cake. Total bill was $140 which honestly was not too bad! I'm definitely coming back! Just for the soup and crabmeat pasta!

address: 9 Upper East Coast Rd #01-01 Singapore 455203 Singapore
comment: It's been a while since I've been at a Pasta Fresca, but this visit was well worth the return. We had two pizzas and the penne arrabiata. Pizzas were good, thin-crust type and most ingredients were of good quality. The seafood on the marinara pizza could have been better but would still say above average. The penne arrabiata was amazing for me, fresh pasta and just honest good sauce with just the right hints of herb did the job. Finished off with a great tiramisu shared. It was a generous portion and enough for two to share. My benchmark is The old Amici's at HV - this one was very good but not yet there.Service was also pleasantly good for a Saturday evening. Plenty of staff that were responsive and polite. The manager even came around to chit chat. Overall would recommend.

address: 9 Upper East Coast Rd #01-01 Singapore 455203 Singapore
comment: This place is nice to have italian dinner, not too fancy affordable, and still have italian original touch. Kids love their pizza, specialy parma ham pizza, i enjoy their salad burrata, they even have italian beer and cheap italian wine but nice too.

address: 9 Upper East Coast Rd #01-01 Singapore 455203 Singapore
comment: Our family's favorite pizza and pasta place. Great food, great service and a homey atmosphere.

address: 9 Upper East Coast Rd #01-01 Singapore 455203 Singapore
comment: On days I'm craving for Italian and Al Forno is too much of a hassle to get to, Pasta Fresca will come to mind. It's a pretty spacious place with tacky decor (think fake brick arches, happy farmers harvesting in the fields type murals) and impersonal service. While the service staff are prompt with their iced water refills, they usually congregate around the front of the restaurant. I know not why. The usual orders are the baked eggplant with cheese and tomato as a starter, and a pasta and a pizza. I usually go for either the carbonara or the puttanesca, even though they're easily recreated. I'm rather partial to the eggplant though; it's all smooth, cheesy and tomatoey goodness, very yummy. Pastas are ok, not great, and not as al dente as I'd like. That said, this hasn't affected its customer base very much. Pasta Fresca has been here for ages, and looks like it'll continue this way.

address: 9 Upper East Coast Rd #01-01 Singapore 455203 Singapore
comment: This faithful Italian restaurant serves up some wonderful authentic grub which is marred but spotty wait staff. At times they're very attentive but they also swing to the other extreme and come across overly eager to clear your plates even when you're left with that last mouthful. Items I'd recommend here would be the four cheese pizza and the pasta which you can put together yourself. The pizzas come with generous toppings while the pasta are done al dente and the cream base isn't too overwhelming. Valet parking service is available and from what I see, this is a rather child friendly restaurant.

address: 9 Upper East Coast Rd #01-01 Singapore 455203 Singapore
comment: I've been going to Pasta Fresca ever since it opened close to 10 years ago. They pride themselves in serving authentic pasta dishes with freshly made pasta, as their name suggests.Some of my favourite dishes that I usally order include the Piadina, Parma ham with bread sticks, Seafood Soup, Fettucine Vongole and their pizzas. I hardly stray from my usual orders because they're so good, I can find no reason to order anything else. When ordering a pasta dish, you can choose any type of pasta you want. I recommend the spaghetti, fettucine and pappardelle. Their tomato base is excellent.The one thing I like about their pizzas is that the crust isn't too thin. I like the crust to have a certain kind of volume to it and not be biscuit thin.If you're a fan of Italian food, I highly recommend Pasta Fresca. Did I mention that tiramisu is pretty awesome too?
Old school taste, just the way I like it.The old auntie there is really nice and very hard working. Her shift is at night. Please really have a heart! Support them..
Have been going here since 1998. Solid place. I grew up with this establishment. The ham salad is the only salad I will eat her win SG. And I love their fries, burger, meats.
Probably my fav coffee shop western food. Their chicken wings and cutlet is nice. The chicken chops is not bad too! The old lady who serves food there is lovely

My favorite neighborhood western stall. Friendly service and good prices.I often have the fish and chips to take home, but I use my own tartar sauce because theirs is just mayonnaise. Wide selection of cakes and pies to satisfy your sweet tooth. Try the apple crumble.

address: 799 Upper Changi Rd #02-05/06 Bedok Point Singapore Singapore
comment: Delicious fried chicken and rosemary chicken! Mac and cheese was nice and creamy as well.

address: 1000 East Coast Parkway #01-02 Marine Cove Singapore 449876 Singapore
comment: I'm gonna change my review to 4-stars for the following reasons:1. Their Chicken Rice is really one of the best I've tried in Singapore!I have tried many Chicken Rice over the decades - from The old Swee Kee at Bugis (still the best I have ever eaten!) when I was a kid, to the atas (high class) Chicken Rice at Chatterbox @ Mandarin Hotel, I've happily chomped my way through many many plates of this much-loved local delight.Unfortunately, many good chicken rice stalls did not manage to maintain their standards over the years. But, Babalicious' owner - the famous Tong Fong Fatt ä¸é£å chicken rice chain - has managed to, somehow, kept their chicken tasting so good & tender all these years. Kudos to them for doing that!Recently, I've been having Chicken Rice cravings & have been going to this eatery quite often. Always left feeling very satisfied.I must also add that their Chicken Rice Chilli is really sedap (delicious) and quite spicy. Just a little sprinkle of the chilli sauce & garlic sauce does the trick for me. 2. Good serviceTheir service is prompt and efficient, and they serve free water! I'm always pleasantly surprised that they serve my water immediately after I asked for it. After I have tried more of their dishes, I will update my review again. But, I foresee myself going there just for their Chicken Rice (just like many other folks i think). Try it and let me know how you like it!

I'm kinda glad that Miki has not been discovered yet. On a Friday, we had no wait for seats! Thanks to my foodie pals, I was introduced to this amazing place. Service was fast and prompt, albeit a little hurried. The servers are really eager to get your orders down. And food is served within 10 minutes of ordering, satisfying our thirst and hunger. Food: average 9/10MUST GET (9.5/10) - moonrise hor fun (the awesome runny egg yolk on that brown noodle things): deliciously fried and awesome flavorFu yong egg - nice and crispy sides, with delicious bits in thereGOOD but forgettable (8/10) - garlic kai lan: tasty but just stir fried veggieschicken with cashew: tasty and reminds me of kung pao chicken, but less sweet and not spicy. love the cashew in there!cereal sotong: too much cereal and too little sotong. somehow the cereal doesn't really incorporate into the sotong!Get some chrysanthemum tea to wash down the stir fried food! Don't expect friendly service though. They get their job done, fast quick and delicious but it's not home service! Sit in the indoor area!! aircon is so much appreciated!

The constant queue in front of this hawker stall at breakfast time shows the popularity of this stall with the nearby residents. Cheap and good. $3 or $3.50 for a bowl of prawn noodles. The soup is a bit peppery. They also sell Lor Mee for $3 and $3.50

address: No. 30 Jalan Pari Burong Singapore 488696 Singapore
comment: This place started out specializing in desserts and waffles was their specialty and as pointed out the salted caramel was the best sauce to go with the waffle.The main draw for me was the coffee however. You can't really find nice coffee around the area. They use Italian beans for their coffee so the coffee is strong and flavorful. Pretty low acidity and full nodied kind of coffee.Another signature item on their menu is their carrot cake. They bake it on their own and it's really nice and fluffly. I would recommend coming here to chill and have a slice of cske with coffee.

address: No. 30 Jalan Pari Burong Singapore 488696 Singapore
comment: Favourite dessert place to go to. I always order the waffles with salted caramel sauce. One of the best comfort food ever. The waffles are crispy on the outside, fluffy on the inside and the sauce complements it even better! If you are feeling hungrier, the pastas on the Alacarte menu are great too! Highly recommended!
Cheapest and nicest Thai food I can find near here. However queue is very long and have to wait for a long time before we can get seated. Try pineapple rice and green curry. Both are very delicious.

I've heard many great things about this outlet and there is always a queue when I am in the area. Not only is there a queue to sit and eat-in but there is a queue for to-go order pickups. Post-lunch time, there wasn't a wait but there were still people coming in to be seated. Overall, the meal was satisfying and I was quite pleased. Thai iced tea (Red), Pad Thai, and Papaya Salad. I'd say the papaya salad was my favorite as it tasted most similar to what I've had in Thailand. The Pad Thai, in my opinion didn't taste as authentic but was still good. The Thai iced tea was not overly sweet which was nice too. I'll have to try the green Thai iced tea next time. Service was good and seemed to be pretty attentive at the time. They also provided water. Atmosphere, pretty chill and more open so it was warm but there were fans so that is nice. I'd recommend and would come back here for Thai food. Tip: if it's during busy hours, order for pickup which may save you some time

Ignorant of the largely rave reviews, I swung in a few minutes before closing time to dapao some dishes. The crew were a cool and friendly bunch and the food was quickly prepared. They don't accept card so remember to have cash in hand.Popping open the goods at home was a bit hit and miss. Two of the dishes, the olive pork and green bean chicken were micro portions whilst the olive rice and green curry were of a good size.Overall the flavours were good, Birdseye chillies dotted around in the rice are the main spice factor, otherwise nothing was particularly spicy. Definitely better than taking away from Thai2go.Not impressed with portion size.

This Thai restaurant has been in Bedok for the past 2-3 years! When it first started the queue were crazily Long because it was really good! The regulars would always come back to have Tom yam soup! Then just 6 months ago a shop took over Nakhon Thai. But Nakhon open 2 shop away from it. Now we have both Thai restAurant and both are having a long queue. The price are similar in both of them. Nakhon is definitely better still. Great price, good portion and amazing quality. Thumbs up!
The service is excellent. Hole-in-the-wall restaurant in residential neighborhood, with authentic Thai food. Â Very tasty and good sized portions.
No wonder this place always has a queue! Had a Pad Thai that was scrumptious!!! It had an average price but the foos was amazing! Would recommend this place if anyone craves Thai food!Pad Thai- 9/10

This is hands down my favorite Thai food place in Singapore. The prices are amazing for the quality of food you get - $6 on average for noodle dishes e.g. pad thai as well as rice dishes e.g. pineapple fried rice. 90% of the stuff on the menu is under $9, and they don't skim on the portions either.I love the pandan fried chicken - succulent chunks of marinated chicken wrapped tightly in pandan leaves and deep fried. They come in plates of 4, which I can easily mop up all by myself because it's that yummy and yes I'm a glutton. I order it every single time and I'm still not tired of it.Another must-have is the thai style kang kong, served in a stylish elevated dish. It's very tasty, but I usually tell them to go easy on the chili padi. The tom yam soup is extremely extremely spicy. Which isn't to say it's not delicious and addictive in a masochistic kinda way. Like your tongue is already on fire and instead of putting the fire out you just wanna douse it with more delicious fuel. Piece of advice: share it with someone or you'll spend the entire night in the bathroom.I've tried the pad thai, pad see ew and pineapple fried rice, all of which are authentic and great complements to the spicy dishes. Oh and if you love cereal prawns but hate to peel them, they serve their cereal prawns half peeled. For some magical reason the prawns remain juicy even though they're cooked without their shells, and they're buried until a TON of cereal which goes great with pretty much everything.And finally, red ruby and mango sticky rice for dessert. If you have to pick one, go with the red ruby. It's not too sweet and is extremely refreshing after a spicy meal. Plus the milkiness puts out whatever fire you induced into your mouth.Definitely go there with a bunch of friends and share as many things as possible. Try to go early, like before 11.30am for lunch and before 6pm for dinner, or be prepared to queue.

My friend introduced this Thai restaurant in 2012, I remembered there was a long queue back then, so long that we waited almost the duration of a football match but the wait was worth it. The food that came along satisfy both my stomach and feet which had to endure a punishment similar to the days during National Service. The place is located on the first floor of a HDB block. It may not look glamourous, but the cost of the food is cheaper than its competitors but the quality of the food makes up for it. I enjoy every spoonful of Tom Yum soup which may be spicy to some and had a bit of difficulty finishing it. The main dishes that came along with the soup are fabulous. The Basil Beef and Pineapple Rice are my favourites. Since the queue is long, there should be a timing for the every customers, as some of them take their own sweet time finishing their food! (Annoying). Overall, I enjoyed the food this restaurant offers, whether its the best remains debatable but certainly is one of the better ones out there.
Love their food! Price is reasonable too! Their basil chicken and pad Thai are my favorites! And for dessert is the red ruby, hands down! Doesn't get any better else where!

My friends and I arrived on a weekday night for dinner, and we joined the line of hungry patrons. After an hour of wait, we got our table. Food arrived really quickly because we already placed our orders while in line. Black Olive Fried Rice is very fragrant and yummy! It is not too oily or salty, just right! Tomyum Soup with Fish is really awesome! The soup is flavourful with a little on the spicy side, still tolerable, while being a little more sour than most tomyums. But I love it! I couldn't stop scooping from the bowl! The other food we ordered, Thai Fishcakes, Pha Thai, Sambal Kangkong - really spicy, Basil Chicken were okay, not too bad but not fantastic. Overall, food is pretty authentic and flavourful at affordable prices! We cleared everything on our plates! However, the waiting time is really long and their toilet is a no-

Nakhon Kitchen is a hidden gem in the Kovan neighborhood in the North-eastern corner of Singapore that serves authentic Thai cuisine in a friendly and kooky Thai atmosphere. Once you step into the shop, you'd be transported to the back alleys of Bangkok with all that upbeat Thai pop tempo, mouthwatering waft of hot delicious food and the friendly smiles and eager to please faces of the servers. The Pineapple Fried Rice (S$6) is a standard dish that i would order here. The sweetness of the pork floss goes perfectly with the slightly curried Thai rice which is slightly fluffy and chewy. I like that it is not too dry. The rice is fried with shrimps, cashew nuts and raisins and best eaten with Green curry! Almost every table had an order of this. Nakhon used to serve this in a pineapple but i guess it was too troublesome for them. A Thai meal is never complete without Tom Yam Soup and Nakhon has 2 different types, 1 thick base and 1 clear, with the option of Seafood, Shrimp or Chicken (S$6). The milky base is the less spicy option with some tomatoes added to neutralize the acidity. I personally prefer the clear base. It looks innocuous enough but boy that chili padi in the soup can kill. It's a clean and sweet taste with tartness to it in your first mouthful. Amazingly addictive but u may feel that acid biting into your stomach after.Awesome and affordable thai food right this way!

I pass by this stall almost every day as I live around the area and there hasn't been once where I've gone past this shop without seeing a long queue of people waiting for a table. I used to think that they were just slow at serving food and clearing tables, allowing the queue to form, until I tried it out for myself.In contrary to what I initially thought, service at Nakhon was quick and efficient. Despite the seemingly long queue, the wait for a table was not more than 15 mins. The staff took down my order while I was still in the queue so the food came almost immediately once we got a table. However, do not expect immaculate service here at Nakhon. Probably due to the busyness of the restaurant, the staff can be rather impatient when dealing with customers. Food is cheap and good! It is cheaper than restaurant chains such as Thai Express, yet I find it more authentic. I really enjoyed the Clear Tom Yum Soup they serve, as well as the Thai Mango Salad and their Phad Thai. I have reservations about their green curry though, as I have had inconsistent experiences with it. The first time I had it, it was thick and flavourful but my recent orders of green curry have been disappointing. The green curry has recently become pretty diluted, with fewer chicken and mushroom pieces. Overall, I would still recommend Nakhon as a good place to go for affordable, yummy Thai food. Go early for dinner (around 5-ish pm) if you want to avoid the queue!

This trusty gem of a neighborhood eatery is what most of us Hougang peeps turn to when we're looking for a quick Thai fix. That the restaurant is staffed entirely by Thais should be an obvious sign of authenticity.At dinnertime, there's almost always a 30 minute wait to be seated at Nakhon Kitchen, even on weekday evenings. I wouldn't dream of coming here for dinner on weekends, so I don't know how crazy a Saturday or Sunday queue can get. Once you're seated, however, service is prompt and your dishes are served in no time.Pineapple Fried Rice, $6.00 - One of the few non-spicy dishes on the menu, the pineapple fried rice here at Nakhon Kitchen is lightly curried, sweet, and nicely complemented by raisins and a light sprinkle of pork floss. Pretty average, but nevertheless useful to have this on hand if you're ordering the tom yam soup.Black olive fried rice with minced chicken, $6.00 - If you're not a believer of fruits in your rice, you've got another carb option in the form of olive fried rice. I actually prefer it to the pineapple rice, as the salty fragrance of olives and siew dam (a dark, syrupy Thai soy sauce) pervades every grain of rice in on that plate. The accompanying chopped raw onions and cashew nuts add a welcome crunch to each spoonful of rice as well.Tom Yam Soup, $6.00 - Ah, the tom yam soup. Where do I even begin? If you're one of those people who have no problem at all with spice, by which I mean you're capable of eating baby red chillies without breaking into a sweat, then you'll enjoy this. Objectively speaking, this is very good soup - it's filled with the distinctive aroma of lemongrass and has a satisfyingly tangy taste due to the addition of tomatoes. Generous serving of fresh seafood within as well.Thai vermicelli salad with seafood, $6.00 - Don't be fooled by the deceptively mild appearance of the yam talay here. I used to find this salad incredibly spicy, but after drinking the tom yam soup this yam talay seems to possess the spice level of a Happy Meal. That metaphor doesn't even make sense, but I trust you understand what I mean. Sour, fiery and refreshing, this vermicelli salad functions as an excellent palate cleanser and whets your appetite for the dishes to follow.Kang Kong Belachan, $6.00 - When my conscience is niggling from all that pigging (wa I'm a poet), this stir-fried veggie dish is something I always order to try and make myself feel better. Like oily vegetables will negate the effects of the other dishes from hell that I'm eating. The kangkong served at Nakhon Kitchen is crunchy and nicely infused with the fragrance of fried garlic as well as the shrimpy flavour of belachan. Only gripe is that it could be a little less oily.Stir-fried minced pork with basil leaves, $6.00 - This dish is a must-order for me every time I visit. Basil leaves are an acquired taste for most, and to me they taste wretched when consumed in isolation. They remind me of liquorice, which I happen to be terrified of. I do, however, think they're excellent when they lend their flavour to stir-fried meats. Nakhon Kitchen's rendition of pork and basil is one of the best there is.The more observant among you would probably have noticed that the dishes reviewed in this article all cost $6.00. Split between three, it works out to a reasonably priced dinner. Plus the food's great, which makes this place is one of my favourite Thai eateries in Singapore. Just a gentle heads up, in case you haven't realised what I've been repeatedly driving across - the spice level here isn't for the faint-hearted. This is value-for-money Thai food that packs a lethal punch, and I'd advise you to come prepared for your stomach lining to bear the consequences of your meal.

This Thai restaurant has been in Bedok for the past 2-3 years! When it first started the queue were crazily Long because it was really good! The regulars would always come back to have Tom yam soup! Then just 6 months ago a shop took over Nakhon Thai. But Nakhon open 2 shop away from it. Now we have both Thai restAurant and both are having a long queue. The price are similar in both of them. Nakhon is definitely better still. Great price, good portion and amazing quality. Thumbs up!
The service is excellent. Hole-in-the-wall restaurant in residential neighborhood, with authentic Thai food. Â Very tasty and good sized portions.

Go to this place if you do not value your time, money and body.This place is so overrated, the service is so rotten and the food is so pathetically ordinary on all levels, I cannot believe how bad it was after my experience in contrast with what I've read about it online! I went there early, fully intending to skip the crowds before they form. By 5, I arrived and true enough, I got a table immediately without a wait. So there is NO excuse whatsoever for the surly service. The waitress behaved like the patrons owe her a living. Really! She should consider a different career choice, because she's clearly unhappy with what she's doing. The average service standards in Singapore are beyond appalling in general, when compared to service in the US, Japan and Bali. But this place takes the cake in bad service, even by Singapore standards! Service is several notches below norm in Singapore. When we asked her something, she didn't bother to reply, appeared to mutter something and walked off rudely. If this restaurant was in any city in the US, ANY city, it wouldn't last beyond six months with such appalling service and mediocre food. The food is extremely mediocre. I've had much better Thai food anywhere. The Thai seafood curry was watery and flavorless. The fish cake was bland and dry.How reviewers here even think this standard is anything above ordinary is beyond me.Oh there is an air-conditioner in the restaurant, but because the restaurant has no doors, it's as hot as an oven whether you sit inside or out.

This tiny casual restaurant can be located about a 5 minutes walk away from Kovan MRT station. It is located somewhere near kovan superbowl but at the opposite side of it. There is always a long queue and even longer during dinner time and the wait can go up to 30 minutes or longer.Somehow this place just manages to draw people back to the restaurant despite the not so cheap pricing, the super long waits and queue, and the small portions of food. Probably like me, people would rather come nearby to satisfy their cravings for thai food rather than go to town area.I do like their thai fish cake, pandan chicken, green curry, pineapple rice and tom yam soup though. Maybe the taste is hard to wrong but i don't mind the wait and slightly over-priced meals. Once in awhile dining here would be fine. So it's really up to individual people's opinion i guess.

My friends and I arrived on a weekday night for dinner, and we joined the line of hungry patrons. After an hour of wait, we got our table. Food arrived really quickly because we already placed our orders while in line. Black Olive Fried Rice is very fragrant and yummy! It is not too oily or salty, just right! Tomyum Soup with Fish is really awesome! The soup is flavourful with a little on the spicy side, still tolerable, while being a little more sour than most tomyums. But I love it! I couldn't stop scooping from the bowl! The other food we ordered, Thai Fishcakes, Pha Thai, Sambal Kangkong - really spicy, Basil Chicken were okay, not too bad but not fantastic. Overall, food is pretty authentic and flavourful at affordable prices! We cleared everything on our plates! However, the waiting time is really long and their toilet is a no-

Great Thai food that is reasonably priced! Serving all you Thai favorites from Pad Thai to Basil Chicken rice, this place is a winner. Just look at the queue for dinner if you don't believe me. I am not going to talk about the food here but instead I am going to highlight their efficient queuing system. When you're in line, Â up till the 3rd or 4th person, your order is being taken concurrently so by the time you're seated, your food comes, saving all the frustration from having to order and wait yet again. This system has worked well obviously as many customers are satisfied to queue because they know the line moves fast and they will not be kept waiting once seated. The length of the queue is testimony of how good the food is so don't be put off by the long line!

I have been in the service industry for almost 2 decades now, and they have the best service ever. Super welcoming and authentic, the entire team of staff are amazing. The positive energy is so refreshing in the local scene. Coffee... fantastic!, from the temperature, aroma the blend.... Ooo . Makan... the quality and attention to details is immaculate. For real foodies that appreciate fresh ingredients and culinary skills, it's awesome. Simple dishes like scrambled eggs. Just check it out, it's done so well. For OCD people ah, you will get it.When you feel sickened by society and silly workplace cultures, Â To experience their crafts and sincerity, it allowed me to feel hopeful again knowing that it isn't extinct.

Excellent little hole in the wall cafe, next to the old badminton hall, kind of out of the way. But it was packed to the brim on a sunday morning, so clearly its popular inspite of the location. Between the three of us, we got the Avocado toast, curry chicken wrap and baked eggs with salmon. The food was fresh, well presented and tasty. Coffee was great as well. Its a nice place for a brunch and chat with friends, tables may be sharing if it gets crowded, but that's ok!

Weird location but pretty spacious. Gets pretty busy during weekday lunch which is surprising as there was not much else around this industrial/residential area.Avo toast and egg was $12.50. Bread was thin and hard but avocado and egg was nicely seasoned. The egg was served on the side. Definitely not worth the price though.The coffee was good. Cappuccino was $5.50. Earl grey tea was $7 though.Self-serve for cutlery, water, and everything else but they do serve your order to your table. I don't get why it can't just be full service...?The menu was decent but prices are pretty expensive. It was not bad if you're in the area but I wouldn't necessarily recommend going out of the way to return.

AMAZING brunch. We had about 20 minutes of waiting before we could get real food, so we got croissants and coffee. I had an iced, single-origin white and the Earl Grey scone. Both were phenomenal. The single-origin is an amazing coffee...the flavor is very complex and delicious. I liked it a lot more than the house blend coffee. The croissant was also great. It was moist and flaky and you could really taste the Earl Grey. Once we did sit down (pretty uncomfortable sitting unfortunately), we ordered the molten eggs. So good. Cheesy, crispy, very filling, and flavorful. The spinach on the side is crisp and all of the side veggies go really well with the eggs. It's a creative and eggcellent (ha) dish unlike anything I've ever had for brunch.

Situated at the front of the old badminton complex, the cafe is easily located just 6 minutes away from Mountbatten MRT. Despite a decent seating capacity, the cafe was rather crowded when we visited on a weekday afternoon. Though spacious, the small square shaped metal chairs are not ideal for a long afternoon of chilling. What made the visit worth it was the coffee. I ordered the flat white ($5) and the cold brew ($7.80) as well as the raspberry coconut cake ($7.70) and the coffee walnut cake ($7.30). While the cold brew and cakes were average, what stood out for me was the flat white. Creamy with distinct fruity notes, it was the perfect combination one would demand from a cuppa. While not the best place for intense mugging, Brawn and brains is undoubtedly second to few when it comes to brewing the perfect cuppa and would make a great place for catching up with friends or that casual afternoon tea.

Quite good coffee located at the weirdest location you can imagine - the former Singapore Badminton Association. But it works. This cute little cafe is away from any competition (compared to the densely populated cafes in Tiong Bahru or Tanjung Pagar area) and just a stone throw away from my current office. You can easily missed this place if you're here for the first time, so look out for their banner hung outside the association and just follow the sign. The cafe is located at the back of the building, btw. We came here for lunch one weekday and love everything about this place. The owner, Gwen is friendly and always so welcoming with her warm smile. I ordered a latte and was asked which coffee blend I prefer. Since it was my first time, I asked for a recommendation and they recommended an African blend with a hint of chocolate and citrus. Very nice. Also, all coffee comes in double shot, which is slightly too strong for me. Â I had a slight "heart attack" the moment I finished my coffee and had to dilute the caffeine with a lot of plain water. Haha. It could be the main draw why people come for their coffee - for it is strong! The food menu could be limited but I salute cafÃ© that concentrates on a few items and do it right and B&B is one of them. I had a chicken and mushroom grilled Panini while my colleagues had curry chicken Panini. All food is prepared fresh upon order hence the waiting time of 15-20 mins. But that's alright, nobody wants to eat frozen or food that has been sitting in the refrigerator for days. The chicken and mushroom as well as the curry chicken filling for the Panini were flavorful paired with a handful of fresh rockets. Portion wise, it was just right as it leave you with some space for dessert. We ordered a dark chocolate tart to share to finish off the meal nicely.  B&B together with a couple of cafes like DOC and Drury Lane will remain my favorite and foresee myself coming back again and again.

We visited on a Saturday afternoon for lunch. The variety is a little limited but I settled on what's essentially poached eggs with smoked salmon and additional avocado. It was thoroughly delightful, sufficiently filling and I would recommend it. The coffee was alright. Maybe I had hyped myself up too much but the beans just wasn't up my alley. In all, a nice place to hang out with friends though it gets crowded.

This little cafe run by a husband and wife team & their friendly staff gives this place a very homely feel. You will see regulars dropping by for their usual fix. They have just expanded to a larger space which can accommodate more customers. But the place still gets filled up fairly quickly. Definitely a place to sit down, chill & enjoy the atmosphere.

This is a good spot if you are into super-thick coffee. The coffees are all served with a double shot and it may be an acquired taste before you enjoy your cuppa.Two blends are usually available: one house blend, and the other single origin seasonal. There are fans for each blend and it is all a matter of personal preference. The coffees also tend to have a tannic aftertaste which some may not like, but I think it gives it a certain personality, not unlike a well-balanced bottle of red wine.Note: Coffees definitely taste better if it is the lady boss who pulled it for you!

Very fresh beans and superbly great atmosphere, however if your looking for a hearty meal this is not where you should be going. Only serve breakfast menu here. Beans are seasonally changed and every roast has their distinct flavor. Whether your looking for a robust or a weak perk me up kind of coffee, this place will satisfy all your needs. Food is just regular cafe sandwiches and wraps, no surprising wow menu. Consistent flavored will be a big draw to those that love their food standards to be stable.
Food was... oh who cares. Come for the coffee, stay for another coffee (food was fine, I had a croissant.)Coffee really was good though.

This place is pretty cute and definitely reminds me of the hipster vibe back home but it is pretty chill and not super pretentious ha. Love the open layout and the community tables. Feels roomy and love the natural light. Earl Grey croissant warmed up and a single shot caffe machiatto. Overall impressed. Great coffee flavor. Strong and tasty which is how it should be, in my opinion. In general, I am overall impressed with Singapore and its norm of using earl grey which is one of my favorites so seeing cafes use it in baked goods and pastries is so awesome! Love it. That being said, the croissant was yummy warmed up. I think the icing was a bit much making it a tad too sweet. But I still enjoyed it. I like that they roast their own coffee and all their pastries are made in house. The service was welcoming and friendly. Overall, if I'm in the area again, I'd stop by :) Tip: you have to purchase your own bottled water Tip2: it didn't look like there was wifi or charging available but it could be a nice place to study and/or just chill

Nice cafe tucked in the corner of a parking lot right next to the Onsight climbing gym. This place is super small. The cafe can fit ~ 12 people comfortably and there is also a small table for outdoor sitting. I went there at noon and had to wait for a bit to get a table. I had the ice mocha, lemon tart and salted caramel tart. I am not a big coffee drinker but the coffee tastes pretty smooth. The lemon tart has a good mix of sweetness and citric taste. I thought the salted caramel tart is far too sweet. All in all, good place to chill out and have coffee and desserts. 10 mins walk to the circle line.

B&B has moved to a bigger unit just in front of the road. More spacious and seats but still insufficient to cater to the crowd that poured in just before lunch. Second day at the new location, no kitchen service is available so no food or cakes. Shame. Coffee was good as usual. Double shots are default but if you want yours milder, tell the cashier ! Tea is served in a small cup and free refill of hot water once. Don't really like that you have to pay $0.30 each for extra refills and milk. Free wifi can be tapped from the indoor climbing place just beside!

Down a large road off the centre of Geylang resides Brawn and Brains. The large windows bathe the space in natural light and the space owes everything to the prevailing hipster look.But the comforts end there.Stealing from fast food outlets who prefer a fast flow of customers, Brawn and Brains' stools are small and hard. The offered comfort doesn't promote a "sit around and chat" atmosphere.Brawn and Brains promote the a coffee conscious image. If all I cared about was image I could happily buy into this outlet. However I love coffee more than I love how it is housed. The coffee is so-so. Having lived around the Mediterranean for many years, I can't excuse a venue that doesn't include water with their coffee. Not only is coffee dehydrating and cloying without water, but the water helps clean the palate and keep the mouth fresh. Disappointingly Brawn and Brains didn't offer water immediately and refused to offer tap water. Â The only option is imported water.The food is ok but was western themed. It was a little cliched with the dish coming with packet crisps. Very few local people were eating here, mostly Europeans and North Americans, presumably looking for a reminder of home. For a traveller in this area, why not just eat something local instead? There is a great selection of low price food and authentic cooking along Geylang road. Even "The tuckshop" up the road would be a better place to drop in.If I was looking for a coffee I would have wanted to head to Collective Brewers, but now they have closed down. Instead, I'd rather head to "Curious Palette" on Prinsep street, or, if I can get in, "Space Mob", at 8 Claymore Hill.
Its not a one dollar restaurant, prices are moderate, but the staff, atmosphere, food and coffe are very good. There is even a veggie options for every dish.

With all the rave reviews I don't understand just a 4 * rating. For me, anyway, it's 5 all the way. Yes the spot is (was - expanded space opening soon) tiny, but that doesn't detract from the quality or experience overall. You're greeted upon entering, served with a smile, and thanked on your way out. Even if the coffee and food wasn't that great it would still be a pleasant experience. But the coffee and food IS great. Limited food menu, but I prefer quality over quantity. I get the chicken and mushroom wrap or roast beef sandwich with a coffee and am always pleasantly satisfied - good, reliable, quality. Add a pastry for dessert if you're still hungry. And if there are no seats left, have your coffee to go and take a seat in the climbing gym next door to watch the action. I have nothing but praise for this place!

This place is great, you can feel the passion behind the people who made it. Slightly quirky and unique and at the core a great product. The prices are reasonable too.Flat white & an early grey croissant for me every time!

Dozens of cafes and how many of them have any character? A very very low proportion. But Brawn & Brains is absolutely buzzing with it. The team behind this cafe obviously care a lot about the way it looks & feels.The coffee was also excellent - easily one of the best cups I've had in Singapore. I neglected to ask exactly who roasted it but I will definitely be back to try some more. Unfortunately the location is a little out of the way but Guillemard Road is close enough to where I live to make it worth a trip out.The star gets knocked off for the uncomfortable seating. I get that you're a hole in the wall serving only drinks & pastries but that's still no excuse for trying to force patrons out by way of uncomfortable seating. Having said this, Brawn & Brains is the only place I've ever hesitated on before taking the one-star backless-seating demerit. And that says something.

Excellent reasonably priced world-class coffee.Easily among the best in Singapore.Croissant could be better, served cold, it was nice and crispy on the outside, but almost hollow inside.The toasted wraps & sandwiches were tasty, meticulously prepared by seriously focused staff. Worth the longer than normal wait. Seats could be more comfortable (got sore waiting for food to arrive), perhaps some cushions would help?Recommended for take away coffee or lazy weekend brunch (byo cushions).

Dropped by after a huge downpour to find a really cosy setup manned by one half of the partners, Gwen. She was alone managing the cafe that has 5 people including us who just walked in. She set us down very nicely whilst continuing to prep a sandwich for the other customer. After serving that customer, she took our order of coffee and went about preparing our drink, using the Brazilian bean that we chose out of the 2 offerings (the other being a Sumatran). Not once did she showed any haste or panic to deliver and we were extremely impressed especially when a little 2 year old (there-about) gal threatened to wreck the entire cafe apart with her wilful behaviour, with her dad being a slave to her actions. And not surprisingly, she spilled the dad's entire cup of iced mocha all over the floor but Gwen simply went about to coax the little girl from crying, etc. Full thumbs up for her immaculate service. Extra brownie points for the not-too-sweet banana cake that she somehow managed to baked whilst all these drama was unfolding in the shop.Hopefully they will start roasting in house soon and will drop by again for another cuppa.Parking is easy but watch the clock ticking as it's gantry-cashcard based.

Run by two fantastic human beings and their polite and well trained crew, these guys churn out consistently great coffee. Having a plethora of choices is overrated, so simplicity is the key here. Two types of brew and that's it! Oh and it's not overpriced in this age of five buck coffees. Can you tell I'm a fan.
Coffee was alright, but the boss was very rude. Space was also very tight. Not worth the price or the wait.

Lovely little joint - the furniture, lights and even the shell for the espresso machine are custom made, and beauuuuutiful. Gwen handles the shop on her own, from baking to coffee-making to cashiering and dish washing. SALUTE! And she's got a smile on too... Very very impressive. Coffees were pretty good. I preferred the Sumatra Lintong + Colombia blend: fuller body and flavour. And that slice of lemon cream cheese bundt cake was just what I needed this afternoon. Will be looking to come back!

This is a sweet and cozy place where you can hangout with a really good cup of coffee. Everyone must try their cake selections. It's not much, but you will drool for more. This is going to be one of my regular weekend hangout.

I had the Iced Caffe Latte, which is the more popular drink here. They had 2 type of coffee beans: organic fair trade and Sumatra Lintong (blend), which I had the former. This had a double shot of ristretto. One taste and I really enjoyed it. It doesn't have a strong bitter taste while retaining the strong coffee taste. Possibly one of the nicest coffee I have taken to date.

For a quick lunch bite of typical local food, this is a good place. Price is cheap, just a little hard to find a space during lunch hours. The home brew drinks at the drink counter are good, concentrated stuff.
